**Other information:**

This PR moves the link to the documentation site under it's own heading in the repo's README.

The reason I submitted this PR is that I often have trouble finding the Vue docs.
When googling I click the Vue github repo link by default. 
When landing on the github repo I am confused as to where the docs are.
Currently there **is** a link to the documentation site, however it is not very noticeable.
In order to make it **more** noticeable and easier for other developers to find, I have moved the link to the documentation under it's own heading.

This will make it easier for developers to quickly find a link to the Vue documentation from the github repo.

title: improve: the readability of `updateChildren`
body:

comments:
**Well :**

Although `elmToMove.elm` and `newStartVnode.elm` are the same thing

**But :**

When the element index of the old list changes

We operate the old listÔºö

**Such as :**  https://github.com/vuejs/vue/blob/dev/src/core/vdom/patch.js#L389
```javascript
else if (sameVnode(oldStartVnode, newEndVnode)) { // Vnode moved right
  // ...
  canMove && nodeOps.insertBefore(parentElm, oldStartVnode.elm, nodeOps.nextSibling(oldEndVnode.elm))
  // ...
}
```

**And :** https://github.com/vuejs/vue/blob/dev/src/core/vdom/patch.js#L394
```javascript
else if (sameVnode(oldEndVnode, newStartVnode)) { // Vnode moved left
  // ...
  canMove && nodeOps.insertBefore(parentElm, oldEndVnode.elm, oldStartVnode.elm)
  // ...
}
```

I think `updateChildren` is talking about:

> Operation the old list, let it become to the new one

So I think there should be use `elmToMove.elm`, It can make the code easier to understand

comments_review:
You should refactor this block into a function and add the check there too so it is stripped when bundling:

`process.env.NODE_ENV !== 'production' && checkOptionType(vm, 'computed')`These tests can also be refactored into a function. It should also test it doesn't print the warning in the right scenarioShould refactored function be a separate file in `test/helpers/`?yes, after all you need to include it in different test files üôÇ no need for option arg because you have nameThis must be called only in non-production env (NODE_ENV !== 'production')since this function is only called in dev mode, this check is unecessarybetter call it checkOptionTypethe result is used in assignment, to call it a "check" may be misleadingit may be good to provide a fallback (empty object) if a wrong type is used in prod modeno, because it will never reach production codeThe check must be removed in productionThe assignment prevents runtime errors but the function is meant to do a checkThe message could be a bit more explicit: `component option "${name}" should be an object`

comments:
Well, it's an interesting thing to name the title@pengchongfu 

Now when using `render function` skip to set the key.
@gebilaoxiong , but all array in hand-written render function will not get a key, I don't know whether it is a good solution.@pengchongfu 

I think this happens only when there are nested arrays in children

just like:

```javascript
children: [
  [vnode, vnode...]
]
```

In the `render` of the template, it will be treated as `v-for`

but `slot` and` render function` will also can generate this structure

so we just skip to set the key
@pengchongfu wait, I have a better way to solve this problemÔºÅ@pengchongfu 

I marked the `v-for` generated elements

Only `v-for` generated elements will be set `key`

avoid `render function` and` slot` to generate the same structure cause the error@yyx990803 

Well, it looks like I'm the last one waiting for today

In addition to deleting the code, do we have other ways to solve this problem? üòÑ   @yyx990803 

Fix bug is really a very interesting thing

Maybe my level is not enough, need to chew and get the truthI pushed a commit to ensure `nestedIndex` is always passed down for nested arrays. This is necessary in cases where there are two `v-for` lists nested under non `v-for` arrays, e.g.

``` js
[[[v-for list], ..., [[v-for list]]]
```understand, thank you very much

In the docs:
> This makes it a bit tricky to use async components at arbitrary locations in your app (we will likely improve this in the future). However, it works seamlessly if you do it at the route level.

is this crucial for this to be fixed ASAP for you?It is not very urgent, I have been temporarily downgraded the version to 2.2.6.
Thanks for your help:)

comments_review:
you can do `vnode != null`yes  but the lint forced to use  `!==`I mean `if (vnode != null)`thanks Actually you can just use `isUndef(vnode)` hereflow has some problems@yyx990803 
if use `isUndef` like this:
```javascript
 if (isUndef(vnode)) {
    return createEmptyVNode()
  } else {
    if (ns) applyNS(vnode, ns)
    return vnode
  }
```
or use `isDef`

then run test:
```

> vue@2.3.0 test /Users/xiongyang/workspace/gebilaoxiong/vue
> npm run lint && flow check && npm run test:types && npm run test:cover && npm run test:e2e -- --env phantomjs && npm run test:ssr && npm run test:weex


> vue@2.3.0 lint /Users/xiongyang/workspace/gebilaoxiong/vue
> eslint src build test

src/core/vdom/create-element.js:106
106:     return vnode
                ^^^^^ undefined. This type is incompatible with the expected return type of
 51: ): VNode {
        ^^^^^ VNode

src/core/vdom/create-element.js:111
111:   vnode.ns = ns
             ^^ property `ns`. Property cannot be assigned on possibly undefined value
111:   vnode.ns = ns
       ^^^^^ undefined

src/core/vdom/create-element.js:112
112:   if (vnode.tag === 'foreignObject') {
                 ^^^ property `tag`. Property not found in possibly undefined value
112:   if (vnode.tag === 'foreignObject') {
           ^^^^^ undefined

src/core/vdom/create-element.js:116
116:   if (Array.isArray(vnode.children)) {
                               ^^^^^^^^ property `children`. Property not found in possibly undefined value
116:   if (Array.isArray(vnode.children)) {
                         ^^^^^ undefined


Found 4 errors
```
Sadly, flow does not support custom type predicate function.  

https://github.com/facebook/flow/issues/34

One workaround is to annotate `function isDef(obj): %checks {}`, using internal type check. But strangely flow does not pick up wildcard export.Now you can use isDef. Flow will pick it up.

author: HerringtonDarkholme
title: fix #5539: improve `isDef` type definition
body:
**What kind of change does this PR introduce?** (check at least one)
- [x] Other, please describe:
  improve flow type coverage to make `isDef` narrow nullable value to no-null value.

**Does this PR introduce a breaking change?** (check one)

- [ ] Yes
- [x] No

If yes, please describe the impact and migration path for existing applications:

**The PR fulfills these requirements:**

- [x] It's submitted to the `dev` branch for v2.x (or to a previous version branch), _not_ the `master` branch
- [x] When resolving a specific issue, it's referenced in the PR's title (e.g. `fix #xxx[,#xxx]`, where "xxx" is the issue number)
- [x] All tests are passing: https://github.com/vuejs/vue/blob/dev/.github/CONTRIBUTING.md#development-setup
- [ ] New/updated tests are included: no new test needed.

**Other information:**

Currently `isDef` cannot narrow nullable value, as tracked in https://github.com/facebook/flow/issues/34. Howerver, we can use a special `%checks` comment to instruct flow inline the function. 

To make this happen, we need first to type check `utl/index.js`. So some type definition changes are required. I have tried my best to keep changes constrained to type level. But still some changes influence runtime.
comments: TIL about `%checks`!Also, doing `/* %checks */`! RubyMine doesn't like the syntax otherwise, I didn't know it works with the comment block, so this was a huge help!
comments_review: This cast is necessary because we cannot persuade flow that formatComponentName is initialized before other code.This is needed because propsData is possibly null.

author: pi0
title: [vue-server-renderer] ensure assets are unique
body:
Hello. During upgrade process of Nuxt.js to vue 2.3.x (nuxt/nuxt.js#633) we encounter strange behavior which adds duplicate entries to `initial` section of client manifest json file. This PR fixes this issue and also ensures every section's items are unique to prevent such kind of problem in future. This PR also prevents an unexpected exception when detecting and ignoring duplicated chunks.

```js
{
  "publicPath": "/_nuxt/",
  "all": [
    "0.nuxt.bundle.309097aded56ffb03943.js",
    "1.nuxt.bundle.38d034e2ba6054b908d2.js",
    "nuxt.bundle.83400ec2bd4f29e215ba.js",
    "vendor.bundle.5953dc67058e339c4b85.js",
    "manifest.5953dc67058e339c4b85.js",
    "index.html"
  ],
  "initial": [
    "manifest.5953dc67058e339c4b85.js",
    "vendor.bundle.5953dc67058e339c4b85.js",
    "nuxt.bundle.83400ec2bd4f29e215ba.js",
    "manifest.5953dc67058e339c4b85.js",
    "vendor.bundle.5953dc67058e339c4b85.js"
  ],
  "async": [
    "0.nuxt.bundle.309097aded56ffb03943.js",
    "1.nuxt.bundle.38d034e2ba6054b908d2.js"
  ],
}
```

-------------------
Type: **Bug Fix**
Breaking: **No**
comments: Thanks for guide @yyx990803 :) I've cleaned it up.Thanks!

body:

If adding a **new feature**, the PR's description includes:

**Other information:**
comments:
So flow is complaining about the `name` value being undefined inside of the if but I don't see how that's possible...
Edit: tried to search for an existing issue in flow but no luckWell let's just make it `name: any`@yyx990803 That won't change the error, I should have posted it to make it clearer:

```
src/core/instance/render-helpers/resolve-slots.js:22
 22:       const slot = (slots[name] || (slots[name] = []))
                         ^^^^^^^^^^^ access of computed property/element. Computed property cannot be accessed with
 22:       const slot = (slots[name] || (slots[name] = []))
                               ^^^^ possibly uninitialized variable
```I guess this is caused by flow's wrong flow analysis. `name` is declared in outer block, not in the `name = child.data.slot` check expression. In this case, flow might be confused about whether name will be changed. 

Changing to this will work
```ts
    if ((child.context === context || child.functionalContext === context) &&
        child.data && child.data.slot != null) {
      const name = child.data.slot
}
```

author: fnlctrl
title: Support auto-prefixed style value as array (client/ssr)
body:
<!--
Please make sure to read the Pull Request Guidelines:
https://github.com/vuejs/vue/blob/dev/.github/CONTRIBUTING.md#pull-request-guidelines
-->

<!-- PULL REQUEST TEMPLATE -->
<!-- (Update "[ ]" to "[x]" to check a box) -->

**What kind of change does this PR introduce?** (check at least one)

- [ ] Bugfix
- [x] Feature
- [ ] Code style update
- [ ] Refactor
- [ ] Build-related changes
- [ ] Other, please describe:

**Does this PR introduce a breaking change?** (check one)

- [ ] Yes
- [x] No

If yes, please describe the impact and migration path for existing applications:

**The PR fulfills these requirements:**

- [x] It's submitted to the `dev` branch for v2.x (or to a previous version branch), _not_ the `master` branch
- [ ] When resolving a specific issue, it's referenced in the PR's title (e.g. `fix #xxx[,#xxx]`, where "xxx" is the issue number)
- [x] All tests are passing: https://github.com/vuejs/vue/blob/dev/.github/CONTRIBUTING.md#development-setup
- [x] New/updated tests are included

If adding a **new feature**, the PR's description includes:
- [x] A convincing reason for adding this feature (to avoid wasting your time, it's best to open a suggestion issue first and wait for approval before working on it)

**Other information:**


When exploring [css-in-js solutions](https://github.com/MicheleBertoli/css-in-js) for vue, I came across the fact that some auto prefixed style objects (for example, by [postcss-js](https://github.com/postcss/postcss-js)) cannot be directly used as `style` option on elements, when they have an array as value, e.g.
```
{ display: ['-webkit-box', '-webkit-flex', '-ms-flexbox', 'flex'] }
```
...which happens when a rule value needs to be prefixed, other examples:
```
{ backgroundImage: ['radial-gradient(...)', '-webkit-radial-gradient(...)']
{ cursor: ['-webkit-grab','grab'] }
```
This PR adds support for directly consuming such objects as `style` option.

author: kmc059000
title: Warn and handle missing get in computed (fix #5265)
body:
<!--
Please make sure to read the Pull Request Guidelines:
https://github.com/vuejs/vue/blob/dev/.github/CONTRIBUTING.md#pull-request-guidelines
-->

<!-- PULL REQUEST TEMPLATE -->
<!-- (Update "[ ]" to "[x]" to check a box) -->

**What kind of change does this PR introduce?** (check at least one)

- [X] Bugfix
- [ ] Feature
- [ ] Code style update
- [ ] Refactor
- [ ] Build-related changes
- [ ] Other, please describe:

**Does this PR introduce a breaking change?** (check one)

- [ ] Yes
- [X] No

If yes, please describe the impact and migration path for existing applications:

**The PR fulfills these requirements:**

- [X] It's submitted to the `dev` branch for v2.x (or to a previous version branch), _not_ the `master` branch
- [X] When resolving a specific issue, it's referenced in the PR's title (e.g. `fix #xxx[,#xxx]`, where "xxx" is the issue number)
- [X] All tests are passing: https://github.com/vuejs/vue/blob/dev/.github/CONTRIBUTING.md#development-setup
- [X] New/updated tests are included

If adding a **new feature**, the PR's description includes:
- [ ] A convincing reason for adding this feature (to avoid wasting your time, it's best to open a suggestion issue first and wait for approval before working on it)

**Other information:**

I ran all test locally. I'm having some failures related to SSR and selenium which appear to be completely unrelated. I've confirmed the new test works by reverting my change and adding it back in.


I am using `noop` for the getter if one does not exist to avoid exceptions when calling functions on the getter.
comments:
#5265 [Here](https://github.com/vuejs/vue/commit/406352baba459288473915218b0ee81cf8066898#diff-cb87aa7890fa694dd923ea9f162256d2L137) is the change that changed the behavior. Notice on this line that `noop` is used if `get` is falsy. Does anybody think that this original behavior is preferable to the warning?

```
const getter = typeof userDef === 'function' ? userDef : (userDef.get || noop)
```

This would be consistent with how [`defineComputed()`](https://github.com/vuejs/vue/blob/0bb529a275072b9a99f645338a8c1f13439caa96/src/core/instance/state.js#L172) is defined here when the `get` is undefined. 

IMO this is better because it would not cause errors in production mode, avoid a new warning, keep the 
2.1.* behavior, and make the behavior between production and non-production modes consistent.

-------
Alternatively, I think it may be possible to avoid creating a Watcher if `get` is not defined, although I think this is a edge case. 

```
watchers[key] = getter ? new Watcher(vm, getter, noop, computedWatcherOptions) : null
```

author: pkaminski
title: Allow named properties on reactive arrays.
body:
**What kind of change does this PR introduce?** (check at least one)

- [x] Bugfix
- [ ] Feature
- [ ] Code style update
- [ ] Refactor
- [ ] Build-related changes
- [ ] Other, please describe:

**Does this PR introduce a breaking change?** (check one)

- [ ] Yes
- [x] No

If yes, please describe the impact and migration path for existing applications:

**The PR fulfills these requirements:**

- [x] It's submitted to the `dev` branch for v2.x (or to a previous version branch), _not_ the `master` branch
- [ ] When resolving a specific issue, it's referenced in the PR's title (e.g. `fix #xxx[,#xxx]`, where "xxx" is the issue number)
- [x] All tests are passing: https://github.com/vuejs/vue/blob/dev/.github/CONTRIBUTING.md#development-setup
- [x] New/updated tests are included

If adding a **new feature**, the PR's description includes:
- [ ] A convincing reason for adding this feature (to avoid wasting your time, it's best to open a suggestion issue first and wait for approval before working on it)

**Other information:**

Since arrays can be treated as normal objects in JavaScript and contain a mix of numeric and named properties, this patch makes `Vue.set` and `Vue.del` deal correctly with named properties on reactive arrays.
comments: I'm not sure if this is a good idea - custom properties on Arrays are ignored during JSON.stringify and cannot be persisted. I personally would never rely on them.I'm confused -- what do reactive properties have to do with persistence?  I certainly don't do this often myself, but it's occasionally useful to pass metadata through an API/SPI where you control both ends but can only transmit an array through the library.  IMHO the principle that you can safely replace any member assignment with a call to `Vue.set` outweighs trying to "fix" iffy JavaScript semantics.@pkaminski yeah, I guess it doesn't matter that much. I'm just thinking about the implications this has to do with normal persistence scenarios and in particular Vuex snapshots.Honestly, I don't even care if the resulting named array property is reactive (though I think it should be for consistency), I'd just like `Vue.set` not to crash when invoked with an array target and a string key.Thanks!
comments_review: I can't understand this change. Could you explain?I can't say I understand it either, but without this cast Flow complains that `Array doesn't have an __ob__ property` -- why it decided that `target` is an array, I don't know.  It appears to be an instance of [this Flow issue](https://github.com/facebook/flow/issues/1330), though my knowledge of Flow is minimal so I can't tell for sure.

BTW, should we also add conditions for other input types that can be input texts like `search`, `url` and so on?

It could be reproduced via this [github repo](https://github.com/defcc/v-show-ssr-bug/). And the demo code is bellow: ```js var Vue = require('vue/dist/vue.common.js') var createRenderer = require('vue-server-renderer').createRenderer var renderToString = createRenderer().renderToString const vm = new Vue({ template: ` `, components: { foo: { render: h => h('bar'), components: { bar: { render: h => h('div', 'inner') } } } } }) renderToString(vm, (err, res) => { console.log(res) }) ``` The result is `
inner
`, it should be `
inner
`

author: Hanks10100
title: [weex] Support unary and left open tags
body:
Fix https://github.com/weexteam/weex-vue-loader/issues/8 .

And add more reserved tags.
comments:
I'm not sure if this actually fixes it. Currently `html-parser.js` is hard coded to use `canBeLeftOpenTag` from `platforms/web`: https://github.com/vuejs/vue/blob/dev/src/compiler/parser/html-parser.js#L13

We will need to change the compiler to pass on `canBeLeftOpenTag` as an option to `parser/index`, and then pass it on to `html-parser`. The web compiler entry also needs to be updated.Actually only need to implement the `isUnaryTag` can fix that bug. I also add a test case for using unary tag in Weex.

Anyway, I also moved `canBeLeftOpenTag` to the compiler option, it can be passed form entry. The `baseOptions` of web compiler and the flow type of `CompilerOptions` has also been updated.

Hi,

Please see #5145 

This patch adds a warning when user is not passing props in kebab-case mistakenly, for example:

```html
<foo someProp="bar"></foo>
should be
<foo some-prop="bar"></foo>
```

I know this is stated on the guide, but since it's a very common mistake (based on the questions on stackoverflow (see the issue above) [and the](https://forum.vuejs.org/t/unable-to-pass-data-from-parent-to-child-component/1763/1) [forum](https://forum.vuejs.org/t/need-help-with-passing-a-boolean-prop-to-a-comonent/3996/1 )), I think it is worth to add a warning and I believe this will save a lot of people's debugging time and provide a more friendly development experience.

And for the performance, this is not a complex algorithm. It only adds a fews operations (both `toLowerCase` and `hasOwnProperty` are fast enough) in O(n) so I would say the impact on performance is negligible (almost no impact when running unit test on my machine). 

thanks!
comments: What release should get this on board (_2.2.6 seems to don't have it_)?@yamsellem Already released in [v2.2.3](https://github.com/vuejs/vue/releases/tag/v2.2.3)@CodinCat sorry 'bout that. Webpack was lower casing our html attributes (`caseSensitive` defaulting to false in [html-minifier](https://github.com/kangax/html-minifier)) ‚Äî avoiding the warning to pop.If you are using single file components then it's not a problem. camelCased props will be converted to kebab-case automatically.
comments_review: Can we move this inside the `NODE_ENV` conditional block as well? It's ok to use two nested ifs.Sure, updated!

title: Minimize size of bootstrap used in dbmon benchmark
body:
**What kind of change does this PR introduce?** (check at least one with "x")
```
[ ] Bugfix
[ ] Feature
[x] Code style update
[ ] Refactoring
[ ] Build related changes
[ ] Other... Please describe:
```

**Does this PR introduce a breaking change?** (check one with "x")
```
[ ] Yes
[x] No
```

**Other information**:
In #5029 I outlined how the bootstrap library that is used in the dbmon benchmark references font files that are not included in the repo.
Rather than including them in the repo I thought a better approach would be to customize the bootstrap library to only include exactly what the benchmark actually needed.

The customization options are stored, by bootstrap, in the minified file. For quick reference you can find it [here.](http://getbootstrap.com/customize/?id=7bd1d75ceeb95d343d9e16d305e782cd)

Size of the library goes from 102KB to 49KB.

This resolves my original problem as the "Glyphicons" module of bootstrap is no longer included and the references to fonts have been removed from the library.

#### Update based on comments:
This PR now removes the bootstrap library that the js-repaint-perfs library was using in favour of using the `styles.css` that the library now uses.
comments: FYI the bootstrap file used was directly copied from https://github.com/mathieuancelin/js-repaint-perfs , but they have since removed the dependency on bootstrap. I think we can just use [this file](https://github.com/mathieuancelin/js-repaint-perfs/blob/gh-pages/styles.css) instead.@yyx990803 thanks for pointing that out. I have made that change, and updated OP.

author: sandersn
title: SFC parseComponent pads complete content with spaces
body:
SFC `parseComponent` pads all content with spaces when `{ pad: true }` is provided. That is, all content is converted to spaces. Previously, each line was truncated to `//`. The new padding method works better with character-oriented tools that calculate positions by distance from the beginning of the file instead of by line
number.

Fixes #5058.
comments:
This is an interesting change - one of the implications (and the reason why I used comments before) is when used with a linter that checks whitespaces or blank lines, this would raise a lot of warnings... (e.g. `unnecessary whitespace / newlines`)

Maybe we can change the option to use different values, e.g. `{ pad: 'space' }` to use space mode, otherwise retain old behavior?Good idea. I didn't think about the linter case. I'll change the type of pad to `true | false | "space" | "line"`, where both "line" and true give the old padding behaviour.

author: jingsam
title: NonParsingTags should not be case-insensitive
body: In vue 2.0, the template is parsed by a Virtual DOM. The paring process is case-sensitive. For example, the VDOM can distinguish between `<Button>` and `<button>`. However, the function is `isNonParsingTag` is case-insensitive which shouldn't be.
comments: Thanks, good catch.Bravo

author: KingMario
title: Add the runtime-only warning for el in-DOM HTML template
body:
Make the warning more explicit for template complier.
Plus, el option which will be used to extract the template should also emit the warning.
comments:
`el` is also used in runtime only:

```js
new Vue({
  el: '#app',
  render: h => h(App)
})
```

edit: my bad, I thought this was another warning@posva, The warning is emitted when there's no render function (handwritten or compiled), so it's no problem whether `el` is used or not in runtime only.

The developer might use a template that he wants to use standalone build to compile it, but for some reason he used runtime-only build.

The key problem is that templates live in both `template` option and `el` elements' in-DOM HTML, not only in `template` option. This is not explicit pointed in the whole documentation, so I guess we should add this in the documentation too.

An example is here: [Runtime-only Build Caused Bug](https://github.com/KingMario/think-in-vue/tree/ba83d296ee384c495a79f0024cf891b2acd0f0ad/standalone-vs-runtime-only-build/project). 

Go to the [Example Result](https://kingmario.github.io/think-in-vue/standalone-vs-runtime-only-build/0/) and see the console log in developer's tool. The developer will get 

> Failed to mount component: template or render function not defined.

which is really confusing.
@KingMario You're right, I didn't look the code above and thought this warning was a different one (`Failed to mount component: template or render function not defined`)Can you add a test then, please?Test added. Also added npm run build in ci.sh. But don't know whether it's acceptable.@KingMario I just realised there're no tests for that, sorry. I removed the extra commits and added a check for `el`

author: kazupon

body:
I improved `Vue.set/Vue.delete (vm.$set/vm.$delete)` flowtype interface, and also I refactored these API.
In the API of `Vue.set `(vm.$set)`, docs said:

https://vuejs.org/v2/api/#Vue-set

author: potato4d
title: Fix unnecessary conditional.

**Please check if the PR fulfills these requirements**

**What kind of change does this PR introduce?** (check at least one with "x")
```
[ ] Bugfix
[ ] Feature
[ ] Code style update
[ ] Refactoring
[ ] Build related changes
[X] Other... Please describe:
A template to help people to contribute with Vue

```

author: Akryum
title: #4371 - Explicit transition durations
body:
Add a new `duration` prop on `<transition>` component (see #4371):

```html
<!-- Both enter and leave explicit total duration -->
<transition name="complex-animation" duration="500">
<transition name="complex-animation" duration=".5s">
<transition name="complex-animation" duration="500ms">
<!-- Specific enter and leave explicit total durations -->
<transition name="complex-animation" :duration="{ enter: 1000, leave: '500ms' }">
```
comments:
I think it's done.Thanks for the hard work!

I decided to simplify the API a little bit so that it only accepts numbers. Personally I don't like APIs that do too much to cater to loose typing, and the amount of extra code/complexity needed to handle all the string formats are not really worth it.
comments_review:
typo? `[, durationText, unit]`The first element in the array is the full match, so I skip it.We can call this enterDuration to be more explicitThe same as above but with leaveDuration insteadWe can add the typing of number, NaN, or undefined to the return value, instead of `any`the return type can be set to `number` (and NaN I guess)`typeof NaN` is effectively `number` in flow-type. https://flowtype.org/try/#0G4QwTgBCBcEC4E8AOBTA9gMwgORNiAvBAIwBMAzEA

And `typeof undefined` is expressed with `?` by idiom in flow.

Thus the return type is equivalent to `?number`You don't need explicitly annotate type here since matched must be an array of string. It should be straightforward to any qualified JS developer. Removing it will make code cleaner, I think.

author: kaorun343
title: add types for Vue 1.x
body:
Hi.

This is a PR to add TypeScript definition files for Vue.js 1.x into this repository.
Since Vue decided to bundle its definition files, they were hosted on DefinitelyTyped.

* https://github.com/DefinitelyTyped/DefinitelyTyped/pull/13230
* https://github.com/DefinitelyTyped/DefinitelyTyped/pull/13235
* https://github.com/DefinitelyTyped/DefinitelyTyped/pull/13236

However, as these PRs imply, `vue.d.ts` was removed and currently there's no way to manage the 1.x's one.
In addition, there were a lot of changes between 2.x's and 1.x's definition, such as `vuejs` namespace, plural or singular. So I changed its content in order to allow users to use what version they like with TypeScript.
Of course, the past definitions were written for TS 1.x, but this one is for TS 2.x.

* `DirectiveOption(s)` is going to be generic interface
* `Directive` -> `DirectiveInstance<V extends Vue>`

Thanks.
comments:
https://gist.github.com/kaorun343/643ec8496c4a546d5154e7f92069534d

The latest one.Thanks for taking care of backward compatibility!
comments_review:
`FilterOption` and `VueConfig` are missing?Should `any` be `V.Vue`?is `es2015.core` required?Considering the backward compatibility, I couldn't do so...
It's because the current definition for Vue 1.x didn't define `this` as `V.Vue`.
How do you think?fixed, thanks.fixed, thanks.We need to discuss inside `<>` not only `ComputedOptions` but also the others, I think.Yes, `any` is the expedient typing. Thanks for taking care of backward compatibility.

author: HerringtonDarkholme
title: fix #4872, use context agnostic Function constructor check
body:
If the prototype of a function is also a function, we treat it as `Function` constructor.

This check is context independent, so server side can safely extract vue as an external library. And it is not expensive.

Of course it is not silver bullet. Users can pass a value of which the prototype is set to a function. But naughty users can also rewrite `Function` global, so I think this change is at most as bad as current check.

Other counter examples are welcome!
comments_review:
Actually we already have the proper check implemented here: https://github.com/vuejs/vue/blob/dev/src/core/util/props.js#L166-L169

So we can just do `getType(prop.type) === 'Function'`Thanks! Didn't notice that!

author: HerringtonDarkholme
title: use vm.Script to avoid reparse
body:
DISCLAIMER: I don't have enough knowledge in nodejs nor V8. I read most cpp/internal js  is by guessing and cramming on cppreference.com :/  I welcome any correction!

This pr tries to alleviate the problem in https://github.com/vuejs/vue/issues/4872. When users include third party library into server bundle, the parsing overhead can be smaller.

If user provided global variable is compared with another global variable in library code, they will never be equal because they are executed in different context.

To fix this generally, we have to run library code and user code in the same context. This means we need to parse a lot of code in one request. 

We can skip parsing by creating a `Script` object, and `runInNewContext` is [effectively a shortcut](https://github.com/nodejs/node/blob/5de3cf099cd01c84d1809dab90c041b76aa58d8e/lib/vm.js#L62-L65). Thus it is safe to reuse the `Script` object.

Reusing `Script` should save several C++ call and reduce garbage collection pressure since the underlying C++ object has a [`Persistent`](https://github.com/nodejs/node/blob/5de3cf099cd01c84d1809dab90c041b76aa58d8e/src/node_contextify.cc#L461) which will not be collected until [out of memory](https://github.com/nodejs/node-v0.x-archive/issues/5080) (it is cargo cult to me, though).

However, I **cannot see a performance improvement** in a simple benchmark,  regardless of whether bundling library code into server entry. (I use vue-hackernews as example, tested under `ab -n 1000 -c 100`).
It seems v8 will [cache compiled code](https://github.com/v8/v8/blob/30224360c10ddd065f46eb81fffa69b88e5378d2/src/compiler.cc#L1571-L1573). So parsing overhead is relatively ignorable in real world.

But reusing object is still a good practice, so I submitted this pull request for symbolic value.
comments:
Looks good to me! Can we add a test case for #4872?Sadly #4872 is not fixed in this pull request üòû . It only reduce reparsing overhead so more library code can be bundled at the same cost.

If we bundle Vue library into the server bundle, #4872 can be fixed. It has been verified by existing tests.
If Vue library is required from external, #4872 will still have problem due to different execution context.

We can reduce the reparsing overhead as is done here, so bundling Vue library is less expensive. We still need users to configure their project to bundle library code together with application code if they need to use APIs which compare global variables.Ok, I guess we can adjust prop type check strategy to not rely on globals instead.

author: coisnepe
title: Remove dead link
body:
"Building Larger Apps with Vue.js" is not in the 2.X documentation anymore. 

Alternatives:
- link to the original page: https://v1.vuejs.org/guide/application.html
- link to vue-cli, as the previous page suggests? https://github.com/vuejs/vue-cli

<!--
Please make sure to read the Pull Request Guidelines:
https://github.com/vuejs/vue/blob/dev/.github/CONTRIBUTING.md#pull-request-guidelines
-->
comments:
Removing it may suffice. The advanced section replaces it now.
@chrisvfritz WDYT?Since the question of how to properly build a larger app with Vue seems to pop up quite often, I'd personally suggest a "Vue Best Practices for Large Apps" article in the docs. The advanced section is great, but it doesn't really discuss what is "proper" for building out a larger application with Vue.  

Scott@posva I'm in favor of just removing it for now. We've split that page up in the 2.0 docs and expanded upon each topic, so they should be able to find the same information.

@smolinari Best practices for large apps is a pretty big topic, so I think I'd like to keep it split up into more specific topics. If there's important information missing though, I'd love to hear more - though probably in a new issue at vuejs/vuejs.org, as I think it's a separate discussion.@chrisvfritz - agreed. A "Best Practices for Large Apps" could be its own major section of the manual. 

I'll start a topic in the forum to ask for feedback and possible sub-topics.

Edit:  [**done**](https://forum.vuejs.org/t/sub-topics-youd-like-to-see-in-a-large-application-best-practices/5370)

Scott

author: defcc
title: Small refactor for template parser
body:
1. Remove the unnecessary argument of parseEndTag.
2. Store the lowerCasedTag in the stack and use it directly.
3. Remove isSpecialTag logic for simplification.

As for **isSpecialTag** logic, the original implementation checks the tagName and its attribute. If it's a **template** with **lang attribute**, it will skip to parse the content inside the template. I think maybe we could simplify it, because the template element is guaranteed by the SFC parser.

```js
const hasLang = attr => attr.name === 'lang' && attr.value !== 'html'
```
For this line, is it an edge case?  There is no proper test case about it, I am not very sure.

Please let me know if anything I missed.
comments: Ah cool. For the template tag, the special check was introduced [here](https://github.com/vuejs/vue/commit/7dc38dea27ba7b99d8cb56e1cbb9be0659e217f7), but it is no longer necessary because we have improved the HTML parser to forgivingly handle `<` symbols inside templates now.

author: HerringtonDarkholme
title: [EXPERIMENTAL] Try to really improve flowtype
body:
This is an experiment striving to fix #4410. The improvement is based on [CLI tool](https://flowtype.org/docs/cli.html#_). The following command is used to inspect source. 

```bash
flow coverage $TARGET.js --json | jq '.expressions .uncovered_locs[] .start .line'
```

Which prints out all the line number of potential unsound `any` type. Only files under `src/compiler/codegen/` are checked.

To my consternation, we have a lot of `implictAny` in code base, (and I have no idea why). Fixing these `any` needs some weird typing and dependency on how flow works (in my conjecture).

While I really appreciate @thejameskyle 's suggestion, I'm afraid maybe our team's capability does not match Flow's type system.

As the title indicates, this pull request is experimental, feel free to close it.
comments:
Thanks! The primary reason for the use of `any`s is usually because the original code was written in plain ES2015 without typing in mind. The flow types were later added on. In many cases, we can make assumptions about certain type scenarios based on code logic, but such logic cannot be easily inferred by Flow.

I don't think it's possible or particularly important to have full type coverage, since the whole point of Flow is gradual typing. The goal of introducing Flow in the codebase is to leverage it when we can.

author: Hanks10100
title: [weex] Expose version and config on subVue
body:
In Weex, the `Vue` variable in each js bundle is generate by `Vue.extend({})` actually, and pass some global properties to it. But forget to expose the `version` and `config` on subVue.

I additionally exposed three props to subVue:

+ `version`
+ `weexVersion`
+ `config`

Some libs, such as `Vuex`, may relay on the `version` and `config`.

author: brycepj
title: Specify that tags with side-effects will not be parsed.
body:
Where I work, it's not uncommon to come across `<script>` tags in templates that would not be trivial to move into separate files. If Vue will prevent the execution of the contents of these tags, I think the warning should say so. As it is, it reads more like a recommendation than a requirement:

`Templates should only be responsible for mapping the state to the UI. Avoid placing tags with side-effects in your templates, such as <script>`. 

I don't know if the language I've added is best, but it's an example of text that tells the user they should not expect their code to run. Feel free to edit as desired.

author: HerringtonDarkholme
title: Ensure Vue instance's vnode and element is up to date
body:
Fix #4284 , to recap the bug, in one sentence: 

`vm.$el` should always be the same as `vm.$vnode.elm`

More detail:

1. If a component changes its root element during rendering, all ancestors' placeholder root element's element should be all updated.

2. If one component is the root element of another component, for example `wrapper` in the test case, and wrapper's parent is updated (which triggers wrapper's `updateFromParent`), `wrapper`'s $vnode is not the same as `comp`'s $vnode.parent. While in the initial rendering, these two vnodes are the same one.

To simplify these two statements, we have to keep one invariant: `vm.$el` should always be the same as `vm.$vnode.elm`. Otherwise vdom patching will mistakenly insert new dom node.

If we correctly sync vnode's element when child tree's root changes its tag (1), and update vm's vnode when parent is updated(2), we can ensure $el is up to date.

I hope I made myself understood. it is quite perplexing.

I don't think this is the only way to fix the edge case. If @yyx990803 and other members have better alternatives, I'm happy to see it.
comments: @HerringtonDarkholme hey - let me know your email address so I can invite you to the Vue team slack :)

author: posva
title: Support custom blocks in SFC parser
body:
The approach is simple and experimental. Worth discussing

This allow to use other block appart from `template`, `script` or
`style` in the SFC parser. This allows such things as writing tests or
examples directly into the SFC file. Those are meant to be handled by
programs others than vue-loader like vue-play.

an usage example could be:

```vue
<example name="simple">
  <my-button some-prop="red">Hello</my-button>
</example>
```

custom playground. The content wouldn't be parsed by the SFC parser. Its third parties' programs responsibility to do so
```vue
<play name="simple">
  <template>
    <my-button @click.native="increment">Hello</my-button>
  </template>
  <script>
    export default {
      data () { return { count: 0 }},
      methods: {
        increment () { this.count++ }
      }
    }
  </script>
</play>

<!-- src hasn't be added yet -->
<play src="./MyButton.play"></play>
```

author: chrisvfritz
title: Add promise support to nextTick
body: This might seem like a very naive implementation, but I _think_ it should work as expected. When we pass a callback to `nextTick`, we just defer it (ideally to the microtask queue), with our preferred strategy being native promises. In cases where promises are polyfilled, it seems projects like Bluebird actually use [very similar scheduling fallbacks](https://github.com/petkaantonov/bluebird/blob/master/src/schedule.js) to `nextTick`, so we should see similar results.
comments_review:
Out of curiosity, rationale for this instead of simply `else if (Promise)`?
With a simple `if`, this would be thrown when `Promise` is undefined:

```
Uncaught ReferenceError: Promise is not defined
```
~~I think `if (window.Promise) {...}` should do.~~
Sorry, suddenly realized vue also runs on node which doesn't have window
`cb` is declared as `Function`, I would expect it as a non-nullable value. Maybe changing the cb annotation is better.
Well, if you changed cb to be nullable, then flow will report error here because it is pessimistic 
Why doesn't this return a promise?
why ctx is passed as argument, I wonder. Because `nextTick` does not modify obj, the caller of `nextTick` can always access `ctx`. If we are using `nextTick` as a `Promise` fallback in which `ctx` is wrapped and consumer does not own handle to `ctx`, it is possibly useless because we can use native `Promise`. If promise does not exist, nextTick returns `undefined` which does add much value.
Because I didn't want to encourage people to mix the two styles (passing a callback vs chaining a promise).
The it sounds like separate another API is a better choice?
I'm not sure I understand what you're saying, but are you suggesting having a separate `nextTickPromise` method or similar?
This is for `Vue.prototype.$nextTick`, which binds the context to the callback or in the case of a promise, passes the context as an argument.
Yes, exactly
I'd rather not force people to learn another method name. This convention of being able to use either a callback or a promise is also quite common, whereas I've never seen a library do as you propose.

author: HerringtonDarkholme
title: fix #4041, warn overriding Vue's internal methods
comments:
@yyx990803 As discussed on Slack, this commit only solves half of the problem, as it doesn't cover the _properties_, which can be more tricky.
Doesn't a simple `key in vm` work just fine?

On Saturday, November 5, 2016, (¬¥„Éªœâ„ÉªÔΩÄ) notifications@github.com wrote:

> ## _@HerringtonDarkholme_ commented on this pull request.
> 
> In src/core/instance/state.js https://github.com/vuejs/vue/pull/4111:
> 
> > ```
> >        `method "${key}" has an undefined value in the component definition. ` +
> >        `Did you reference the function correctly?`,
> >        vm
> >      )
> > ```
> > -        hasOwn(BuiltinVue.prototype, key) && warn(
> 
> Hi, I also considered that approach when coding this. But if we use vm or
> vm.constructor.prototype, it will break constructor style instance
> because $emit or so isn't their own properties.
> 
> ‚Äî
> You are receiving this because you commented.
> Reply to this email directly, view it on GitHub
> https://github.com/vuejs/vue/pull/4111, or mute the thread
> https://github.com/notifications/unsubscribe-auth/AHrt0uN6VSZW78hdY5wLzpaeLaHGzX7tks5q6-4jgaJpZM4KpNci
> .
I'm sorry that this change introduced more problems than it resolved.
As @phanan pointed out, only `method` is warned against. Also https://github.com/vuejs/vue/issues/4142 is another problem caused by this.

I have reconsidered this. We want to only warn against overriding built-in method. And using `key in vm` to detect that effectively means:
- `vm` only has properties inherited from Vue.prototype. This is guaranteed by Vue's core code, where extending is done by option merging.
- Vue.prototype does not have user defined method. This is not controlled by core code, as #4142 showed.

@phanan Could you tell me the tricky part of properties? I'm not on slack.
@HerringtonDarkholme: @yyx990803 should have a better answer because he knows best about the framework's internal obviously, but from what I can tell, not all properties have been registered by the time methods are collected (examples are `$el` and `$slots`). This would make a check during `initMethods()` incomplete and was what kept me from sending a PR over.
Yes, I just tried to fix this again and found warning is particularly tricky thing. More importantly, a `_` and `$` prefix have been strong indicators to users. The marginal benefit for this pr doesn't worth... @yyx990803 I'm so sorry make this rushy pull request. Feel free if you want to revert this.
I'll just revert this for now - I think this is a very rare case anyway. Or, we can simply change it to warn against any method that starts with `$` or `_`, since this is conventionally reserved for internal and plugin methods/properties.
Agreed. This "improvement" has only been costing us time with no particular benefits to start with :)
comments_review:
Let rephrase this to "Avoid overriding Vue's internaml method ..." and can remove the second line.
Can't we just use `vm` instead of importing Vue here?
Hi, I also considered that approach when coding this. But if we use `vm` or `vm.constructor.prototype`, it will break constructor style instance because `$emit` or so isn't their own properties.

author: defcc
title: v-model binding with array.  (fix #3958,#3979)
body:
fix #3958 #3979 
As for array type case, v-model="model[idx]" binding uses **model[idx]=** internally, so the value change could not be reactive.

the binding model expression maybe be as follows:
- test
- test[idx]
- test[test1[idx]]
- xxx.test[a[a].test1[idx]]
- test.xxx.a["asa"][test1[idx]]
- test["a"][idx]

So I use a modelParser to parse the model expression to two parts **exp** and **idx**, and if the exp is an Array type, then use $$exp.splice($$idx, 1, value)
comments:

@defcc @yyx990803   

What about `test[index].key`? 
`test: [{ key: 'value' }]`

author: guidobouman
title: Fix using one delay to control all transitions.
comments:
Also, where'd I put a test for this? I assume after `custom-transition-classes` in `test/unit/features/transition/transition.spec.js`?

And should this actually be tested? As this seems like a niche thing to test.
Yeah, looks quite a niche to test. Could you please provide a fiddle so that I can confirm it though?
@yyx990803 https://jsfiddle.net/o8u35ywu/
By the way: `delays` is never an empty array, so `concat()` can't end up in an infinite loop.

To be sure we could add a fallback like `delays = delays.concat(delays || '0s')` But that would mean we need to know the syntax of a delay inside the function, which could cause issues when a browser decides to change the syntax.
@yyx990803 This should be mergeable, right?
Thanks!

author: chrisvfritz
title: fix root v-else not rendering in prod and switched examples to minified vue for better prod coverage
body:
Fixes #3940. This was a bit of a brainless error on my part - I apologize. Something I noticed however, is that none of our tests are currently covering the production build of Vue, thus allowing this error to slip through. To prevent this in the future, I was wondering if we should split the unit tests into two groups:
- Development-specific behavior (e.g. warnings)
- Features that should behave the same in both dev and prod, which will perform a second run with `NODE_ENV` set to `production`

I think that work would be well outside the scope of this PR, but as a stop-gap measure to cover production at least a little, I switched all of the e2e examples to use the production build, then tweaked the grid example so that I could add a regression test. 

My thinking is that production is probably most important for e2e anyway, as devs will more quickly discover development-only errors (and they won't affect end users). The only downside I can foresee is that if someone clones the repo to start playing with examples, they won't get any nice warnings if they make a mistake. So, I added a comment above each Vue script with instructions to use the development version if they'd like. Still, I'm happy to change it back if this is undesirable. We'd just have to think of another way to add a regression test.

One last unrelated note: while updating the examples, I noticed that the todomvc's HTML file was full of tabs rather than spaces, so I converted them for consistency.

author: phanan
title: Make forAlias regex lazy (fixes #3846)
body:
The current forAliasRE has the first rule greedy (`(.*)`), which will attempt to match whatever it can. This exposes a bug (#3846), where the regex fails if the template happens to have " in " or " of " in its last group. For instance, with the template `for key in [{body: 'Hey in body'}]`, current regex will capture the last group as `body'}]` instead of `[{body: 'Hey in body'}]`. This commit aims to fix this issue by making the first rule lazy instead.

I don't think this really needs a test, but let me know if it does.

author: danreeves
title: warn user calling Vue() without new
body:
Hi,

Open to different wording on the error & I wasn't sure where to put these tests so I've put them in a new file for now. 

An alternative to this PR would be something like:

``` diff
function Vue (options) {
+  if (!(this instanceof Vue)) {
+    return new Vue(options)
+  }
   this._init(options)
}
```

I'm not sure which would be better in the long run but the alternative would be more forgiving.

I could also wrap this in env check so this is left out of the production build, but it's also not a lot of code to leave in.

Let me know what you think.
comments:
It should actually be something like

``` js
if (process.env.NODE_ENV !== 'production' &&
    <failing-condition>) {
    warn('foo')
}
```

The test is something like `expect('foo').toHaveBeenWarned()`
Hi, thanks! I've updated the code and test to match that
comments_review:
Let's use `"Vue is a constructor and should be called with the`new`keyword"`
Sure thing; updated!

author: sergiirocks
title: Allow rendering forbidden tags on the server
body: Currently if you try to render `<script>` tag on the server side you'll get an error, which is not right, because server is not restricted by the rules of the browser. It is useful if server-side component is rendering the `<html>` tag with `<head>` `<body>` and everything else
comments:
Thanks for the PR - however, you should not be using Vue for rendering the entire page - because in the browser Vue will need to "pick up" the server-rendered DOM, so they must be consistent on both ends. Allowing `<script>` on the server will cause hydration errors on the client.

In most cases you'd wrap the markup rendered from your app with surrounding head/tail markup to make it a complete HTML page.
Yes, I know, but with the appropriate setup it still works very well without any effort:

Please take a look on this [gist](https://gist.github.com/naumovs/6fe32db51d4ee81c7cc6a66270233241).

There are two entry points for server and for the client. The server renderer just sets the server-rendered attribute to the main component from the client-index.js and client picks up rendered content. I feel like it is amazing to drop off other thirdparty templating systems if everything can be done with Vue
@naumovs ah, yeah that's a pretty neat idea!

author: chrisvfritz
title: prevent nested thunk children from failing
body:
This prevents avoidable failures in some cases, for example in a functional component using JSX that produces a double thunk:

``` js
render: (h, { children }) => <MyComponent>{ children }</MyComponent>
```
comments:
As this may get executed often, is it worth changing the recursion with a while loop? even thought it is less readable?
@posva Good idea! I don't think it's really less readable - just less functional, which is fine. üòÉ

author: chrisvfritz
title: Allow 2 root nodes with v-if and v-else
body: Since 2 root nodes with `v-if` and `v-else` are guaranteed to return one vnode, they should be considered safe in the root of a template.
comments:
You also have to check for the absence of `v-for` on the element that has `v-if`, as the combination of both would potentially also result in more than one root element. Or is that done somewhere else generally? @LinusBorg There's a [separate warning](https://github.com/chrisvfritz/vue/blob/f1a16e5703c60131387e0b163a2b0dc40ae228f8/src/compiler/parser/index.js#L138-L143) for `v-for` on root, which is triggered whether or not a `v-if` exists. I saw that but was unsure weither it only applies if there _is_ one root item. @LinusBorg Just confirmed with another test locally that this: ```
``` does indeed warn about `v-for`, but root constraints were _not_ being applied to the 2nd element with `v-else`. Added a test for it and fixed the issue. üëç It perhaps should be noted that the following will currently NOT trigger a warning: ``` vue

``` But I consider this a separate issue, since this doesn't warn in [_any_ context](https://jsfiddle.net/chrisvfritz/72eqv40t/), even though it should probably be considered invalid. Also, the above code does still guarantee the return of a single vnode (either the first or last element - the 2nd element is seemingly ignored by the parser). Great job!

author: kazupon
title: [2.0][suggestion] pass v-on event handlers on functional component
body:
Sometimes, there are times when we pass v-on event handlers to `render` function arguments on functional component.

The below URL is implemented example with v-bind on functional component.
http://jsfiddle.net/kazupon/bjp40byw/6/

In example, we need to define handler in `props`. 
I think that come in useful by v-on event handers passing through.
comments:
``` javascript
var on = { valid: props.onValid, invalid: props.onInvalid }
 var vnode = h('validate-input-control', { props: props, on: on })
```

why gather the properties from props since there is props passed already? Seems duplicated.
In virtual-dom system of vue 2.0, when we are necessary in order to communicate the parent-child components, need to use the `on`.
I think it's more straightforward to have only `props` as the second argument. We can pass the raw `data` as the 4th argument, since it's going to be rarely used, only for advanced users.
That's sounds good.
I'll try to fix now.

`attr` is hyphenated, but the user may use camelCase prop names in `propsData`. We need to check  both `propsData[attr]` and `propsData[name]`.
Maybe user can **only** use camelCase propsData[path]?
True, that makes more sense. then we should just replace `attr` with `name` here.

author: furybean
title: Fix bug: directive sort is not stable on Chrome
body:
I'm building a tabs component. It is used like this:

```
<tabs>
  <tab title="1">Tab1</tab>
  <tab title="2">Tab2</tab>
  <tab title="3">Tab3</tab>
  <tab title="4">Tab4</tab>
  <tab title="5">Tab5</tab>
  <tab title="6">Tab6</tab>
  <tab title="7">Tab7</tab>
  <tab title="8">Tab8</tab>
  <tab title="9">Tab9</tab>
  <tab title="10">Tab10</tab>
</tabs>
```

[Live demo(Works fine)](https://jsfiddle.net/sgd2sLqf/4/)

It works fine when there are less than 10 `<tab>s`. But tabs will disorder when I have more than 10 `<tab>s`.

[Live demo(Bug)](https://jsfiddle.net/sgd2sLqf/5/)

The main reason is that the directive sorting by priority is not stable on Chrome.

I fixed this bug using a sort method(time: O(n), space: O(n)),  It also can be fixed using a stable sort method such as merge sort.

author: nervgh
title: Fixed: the "pluralize" filter with multi arguments, when selected arg‚Ä¶
body:
In Vue.js `1.0.25` the "pluralize" filter returns "three"

``` js
Vue.filter('pluralize')(1, "", "two", "three") // three
```

instead of the empty string. After this fix, the "pluralize" filter returns the empty string:

``` js
Vue.filter('pluralize')(1, "", "two", "three") // ""
```
comments: Thanks!

author: a0viedo
title: fix: glob in npm lint script
body:
Instead of using globs to be expanded in the shell, ESLint has support for recursively linting `.js` files inside a directory. Another reason for the change would be that `**` was expanding to all files, including files without `js` extension (like git's `.orig`).

If you still want to use a glob, the correct one would be `/**/*.js` but it's a fairly new feature in Bash so I wouldn't recommend that as an alternative.

ÊâßË°å‰ª•‰∏ãÂä®‰ΩúÔºö
- 1.Âú®ÁÅ∞Ëâ≤Âå∫ÂüüÂÜÖÈöèÊÑèÈ´òÈ¢ëÂ§ßÂπÖÂ∫¶ÊªëÂä®ÔºàËÆ©ÊªöÂä®Êù°ÊúâÊªöÂä®ÔºâÔºõ

### What is Expected? What is actually happening?

ÁÇπÂáªÊåâÈíÆÂêéÔºåÂºπÂá∫‚ÄúRight‚ÄùÁöÑÊòØVueÊ≠£Â∏∏Â∑•‰ΩúÔºåÂºπÂá∫‚ÄúError‚ÄùÊòØVueÂá∫Áé∞‰∫ÜÂºÇÂ∏∏„ÄÇ

ÊàëÁî®v-textÊñπÊ≥ïÂú®ÊåâÈíÆ‰∏äËæìÂá∫arr.length„ÄÇÂêåÊó∂ÊàëÂú®ËøôÈáåÁöÑclick‰∫ã‰ª∂‰∏≠Áî®ÂéüÁîüÊñπÊ≥ïÂÅö‰∫Ü‰∏Ä‰∏™Âº∫Âà∂Âà§Êñ≠Ôºö

``` javascript
this.arr.length == document.getElementById("button").textContent
```

ËÄåÂú®IOS 9.3.xÁöÑËøô‰∫õÂá∫Áé∞ÂºÇÂ∏∏ÁöÑÊµèËßàÂô®‰∏≠ËøôÊó∂ÂÄôarr.lengthÁöÑÁúüÂÆûÊï∞ÂÄºÂíåÊåâÈíÆ‰∏äÊòæÁ§∫ÁöÑ‰∏ç‰∏ÄÊ†∑ÔºåÊâÄ‰ª•‰ºöÂºπ‚ÄúError‚Äù„ÄÇ

ÁõÆÂâçÂ∑≤Áü•Âú®IOS 9.3.x‰ª•‰∏ãÊµèËßàÂô®‰∏≠ËøêË°åÊòØÊ≠£Â∏∏ÁöÑÔºö
- 360ÊµèËßàÂô®
- firefox
- safari
- chrome
- ÂæÆ‰ø°webview

Âú®IOS9.2Âèä‰ª•‰∏ãÁöÑÁ≥ªÁªüÁâàÊú¨‰∏≠ÊâÄÊúâÊµèËßàÂô®ÈÉΩÊòØÊ≠£Â∏∏ÁöÑ„ÄÇ

ÈÄöËøáÂÆ°Êü•VueÁöÑÊ∫êÁ†ÅÔºåÂèëÁé∞ÈóÆÈ¢òÂá∫Âú®util/env.js‰∏≠ÂÖ®Â±ÄMutationObserverÁöÑÁõëÂê¨„ÄÇ

``` javascript
  /* istanbul ignore if */
  if (typeof MutationObserver !== 'undefined' && !(isWechat && isIos)) {
    var counter = 1
    var observer = new MutationObserver(nextTickHandler)
    var textNode = document.createTextNode(counter)
    observer.observe(textNode, {
      characterData: true
    })
    timerFunc = function () {
      counter = (counter + 1) % 2
      textNode.data = counter
    }
  } else {
    // webpack attempts to inject a shim for setImmediate
    // if it is used as a global, so we have to work around that to
    // avoid bundling unnecessary code.
    const context = inBrowser
      ? window
      : typeof global !== 'undefined' ? global : {}
    timerFunc = context.setImmediate || setTimeout
  }
```

v1.0.24ÈáåËøôÊÆµ‰∏çËÆ°ÂÖ•‰ª£Á†ÅË¶ÜÁõñÁéáÊµãËØïÁöÑ‰ª£Á†Å‰∏≠ÔºåËøòÁâπÊÑèÂØπIOSÁöÑÂæÆ‰ø°webviewÂÅö‰∫ÜÂº∫Âà∂ÈôçÁ∫ßÂ§ÑÁêÜÔºàÂáΩÊï∞ÁöÑÂºÇÊ≠•ÊâßË°å‰∏ç‰ΩøÁî®MutationObserverËÄåÈááÁî®setTimeout(0)ÔºâÔºåÊâÄ‰ª•Âú®ÂæÆ‰ø°webview‰∏ãÊ≤°ÊúâËøô‰∏™ÂºÇÂ∏∏„ÄÇÂ∞ùËØïÂèñÊ∂àÂØπIOSÁöÑÂæÆ‰ø°ÁöÑÁâπÊÆäÂ§ÑÁêÜÂêéÔºåÂæÆ‰ø°webview‰πüÂá∫Áé∞‰∫ÜËøô‰∏™ÈóÆÈ¢ò„ÄÇ

ÁªèËøáÂÆûÈ™åÊµãËØïÂü∫Êú¨ÂèØ‰ª•ËÆ§‰∏∫ÊòØÊµèËßàÂô®Â∫ïÂ±ÇÂØπMutationObserverÁöÑÂºÇÊ≠•ÊâßË°åÂá∫Áé∞‰∫ÜÈóÆÈ¢òÔºåÂú®ÊµèËßàÂô®Â±èÂπïÊªöÂä®ÊàñÂõûÂºπÁöÑËøáÁ®ã‰∏≠Â¶ÇÊûúÂêåÊó∂ËÆ©touchÁöÑ‰∏Ä‰∫õÈªòËÆ§‰∫ã‰ª∂Ëß¶ÂèëÔºå‰ºö‰∫ßÁîüÂØπMutationObserverÁöÑÈòªÂ°ûÔºå‰ª•Ëá≥‰∫éMutationObserverÁöÑÂõûË∞ÉÂáΩÊï∞‰∏çÂéªÊâßË°å„ÄÇÈÄ†ÊàêÂêéÂêéÈù¢‰∏ÄÁ≥ªÂàóÁöÑÂºÇÂ∏∏„ÄÇ

IOS 9.3ÂØπÁ≥ªÁªüÂ∫ïÂ±ÇÁöÑtouch„ÄÅclickÁ≠âÂæàÂ§ö‰∫ã‰ª∂ËøõË°å‰∫ÜÈáçÂÜôÔºåÂèñÊ∂à‰∫Ü300msÂª∂ËøüÂèØËÉΩ‰ºöËøûÂ∏¶ÁùÄÂú®‰∏Ä‰∫õËé´ÂêçÂÖ∂Â¶ôÁöÑÂú∞ÊñπÂ∏¶Êù•ÈòªÂ°ûÔºåÁâπÂà´ÂÆπÊòìÂØπ‰∏Ä‰∫õÊ∂âÂèäÂºÇÊ≠•ÁöÑÂéüÁîüÊñπÊ≥ï‰∫ßÁîüÂΩ±Âìç„ÄÇ

ÊúâÂºÇÂ∏∏ÁöÑÂõΩ‰∫ßÊµèËßàÂô®ÁöÑÂÖ±ÂêåÁÇπÊòØ‰ªñ‰ª¨ÈÉΩÊòØUIWebViewÔºåË°®Áé∞Ê≠£Â∏∏ÁöÑÊµèËßàÂô®ÔºàsafariÈô§Â§ñÔºâÂùáÈááÁî®‰∫ÜWKWebView„ÄÇ

ÔºàË°•ÂÖÖÔºöÂú®IOS‰∏≠ÔºåWKWebViewÊòØIOS8‰ª•ÂêéÊâçÊúâÁöÑÔºåÊØîUIWebViewÊõ¥Êñ∞ÔºåÊÄßËÉΩ‰πüÊõ¥Â•ΩÔºåÁé∞Âú®ËøòÊ≤°Êé®ÂπøÂºÄÊù•ÔºåÂõΩÂÜÖÂéÇÂïÜÂ§ßÈÉΩËøòÂú®Áî®UIWebView„ÄÇÔºâ

ÊàëÊúÄÂêéÊèê‰∫§‰∫Ü‰∏Ä‰∏™PRÔºåÊîπÊàêÂØπIOS 9.3ÁöÑÊâÄÊúâUIWebViewÂú®MutationObserverËøô‰∏™ÊñπÊ≥ï‰∏äÂÅöÈôçÁ∫ßÂ§ÑÁêÜ„ÄÇÔºàUIWebView‰∏çÊîØÊåÅIndexedDBÔºâ

ÊääÊ∫êÁ†Å‰∏≠ÂØπiosÂæÆ‰ø°ÁöÑhackÂà†Êéâ‰∫ÜÔºåÊØïÁ´üÂÆûÂú®Â§™dirty‚Ä¶‚Ä¶‰∏çËøáPRÈáåÈù¢ÊàëÂØπIOS9.3ÁöÑÂà§Êñ≠ËøôÈáåÊàëÂ§ÑÁêÜÂæó‰πüÂæàdirtyÔºåËøô‰∏™‰∏éÁ≥ªÁªüÁöÑUIwebviewÁõ∏ÂÖ≥ÁöÑbug‰º∞ËÆ°‰ª•Âêé‰∏ç‰∏ÄÂÆö‰ºö‰øÆÂ§çÔºåÁî®Á≥ªÁªüÁâàÊú¨Êù•ÂÅöÂà§Êñ≠ÊØïÁ´ü‰∏çÊòØÈïø‰πÖ‰πãËÆ°„ÄÇËøô‰∏™issueÁöÑÂºÇÂ∏∏Â∞±ÈúÄË¶ÅÂ∞§Â§ßÂ§ßËøõ‰∏ÄÊ≠•ËÄÉËôë‰∫Ü„ÄÇ

Â¶ÇÊûú‰∏çÊîπVueÁöÑÊ∫êÁ†ÅÔºåÂú®ËøôÈáåÂØπtouch‰∫ã‰ª∂ÂÖ®ÈÉ®preventDefaultÊéâÔºåÊâÄÊúâÈªòËÆ§ÁöÑËß¶Â±è‰∫ã‰ª∂ÈÉΩÁî®ÂÖ∂‰ªñÂ∫ìÊù•ÂÆûÁé∞‰πüÊòØËß£ÂÜ≥ÊñπÊ≥ï‰πã‰∏Ä„ÄÇ‰ΩÜÊòØÊàë‰ª¨ÁöÑ‰∏öÂä°‰∏çÂÖÅËÆ∏Êàë‰ª¨preventDefaultÊéâÊâÄÊúâtouchmoveÔºåÊâÄ‰ª•Âè™ÊúâÂú®VueÊ∫êÁ†Å‰∏≠ÊâæÂéüÂõ†‰∫Ü„ÄÇ
comments_review:
This line needs to check `inBrowser` first otherwise it would throw Error in Node.js.

Also I'd rename it to `hasIndexDB`
Only checking iOS 9.3 may not be future-proof if the same bug remains in 9.4 or future versions of iOS. We may need to do a regex match to check if the version number is greater than 9_3.
In addition: since this check is only used for the specific case of iOS (detecting WKWebView), there is no need to check `webkitIndexedDB` and `mozIndexedDB`.

author: leemotive
title: do not call shift if the key already exists
body: if the cache size is equal to cache limit and now we put a new entry with an existed key (not the head key), the result is we removed the head entry and updated an existed entry. the cache size will be limit-1. so we need to move the if-statement inside
comments_review:
I the outer `if`-statement could be avoided if we moved the inner `if`-statement until after the entry was added/updated.

then:
- if entry did already exist, size will still be the same
- if entry is a new one, size will be over the limit, and we can remove the head.

author: bartlomieju
title: Delimiters tests
body:
ref #2872

I think it should be somehow emphasized that if we want delimiters to be changed globally we should define Vue.options.delimiters. Doing so in a constructor of our root instance will not have effect (check out 'delimiters should only affect vm' spec). I guess this is desirable, for most of users rely on default delimiters, and we want to be able to use 3rd party plugins.

title: extract style/class/transition as web platform compiler modules
body:
Currently they are written and treated as special attributes. This pr made them possible decoupled from web platform implementations.

And each platform will custom more attributes as platform compiler modules in the future.

Updates:
- added `modules?: Array<ModuleOptions>` in `CompilerOptions` type
- added `src/platforms/web/compiler/modules/*`

Changes:
- `parser`
  - `processClassBinding(element)`
  - `processStyleBinding(element)`
  - `processTransition(element)`
- `optimizer`
  - `isStaticKey`
- `codegen`
  - `genData(el)`
comments_review:
can make `staticKeys` optional here.
I think it's better to do `data += module.genData(el)` here. `genData` for each module doesn't need existing `data` as an argument.
fixed
We are generating a new map every time `optimize` is called. Wondering if there's a way to cache this since most of the time it's going to be the same map.
OK, done.
How about generate a string option `staticKeys` directly in `CompilerOptions` in `web-compiler.js`?
~~actually this option can be a function called `isStaticKey` directly... no need to cache it!~~

~~The problem though is the `genStaticKey` function should not be in an entry file, since other platform's entry file will probably also need it~~

nevermind, saw updated changes
If we do this the basic static keys `'type,tag,attrsList,attrsMap,plain,parent,children,staticAttrs'` also put into the entry file. That's not good from my opinion.

author: Jinjiang
title: new render mechanism
body:
1. Modified `__h__(tag, data, children, namespace)` into `__r__(__s__(tag, data, namespace), children)` to separate node-self process and children process.
2. Supported getters for text node (`__t__`) and static root (`__m__`) to make general detail control possible.

   - `renderSelf` -> `renderElement`
   - `renderElement` -> `renderElementWithChildren`
2. removed the need for the `ComponentDef` - `renderElement` always return `VNode | void`, instead we do different set children ops depending on whether the vnode is a component or not.

author: blake-newman
title: improved SSR rendering
body:
- Reduced duplicated code
- Added more test coverage
- Added component option resolving (async to sync conversion)
- Allows resolvable components
- Fixed component lifecycle
- Added raw render method, to allow custom streaming possibilities
comments:
@yyx990803 As discussed I have ammended the PR to work with resolving components, this is now done internally to prevent blocking the UI. 

As mentioned we still need to ignore reactivity, and manually call hooks.
comments_review:
Isn't `return` here redundant?
Most likely both `return` statements here are not needed.  :)
Unfortunately we don't actually need this. I didn't explain it clear enough, but the proper usage would be bundling the root component via Webpack with `target: 'node'`, which already automatically shims `require.ensure` and `require(['...'], cb)` into synchronous requires. So as long as you stick to Webpack's supported code splitting syntax, you don't need to do anything.
While this fixes the hook invocation order, this is mounting the entire component tree synchronously. I'm wondering if it's possible to delay the mounting to play nicer with streaming mode...
Agreed, would need to be able to initialise the component's without mounting. The question is how?
Resolved: Ensured that synchronous components are able to be resolved.
Directly call `_update` with `_render` result. In some scenarios `_watcher` was not yet defined. This is also faster anyway.
Above could probably be provided by an internal function to reduce duplicated code.

author: tejitak
title: [Vue 2.0] Fix BooleanAttr & EnumeratedAttr serialization
body:
Values of BooleanAttr & EnumeratedAttr are added even when their values are `false`. (The attrs are not added when the value is 'null') For example, the following ':selected' values currently result in `selected="selected"` for both options. ``` js { data: { value: 'bar' }, template: `
` } ``` Only second option should have selected attribute. F.Y.I. As a current work around, we can set the prop like `:selected="value === 'foo' ? true : null`.
comments:
@tejitak Don't forget about the test üòÑ 
üëç if you can add add a test case that'd be great
Okay! I'll try to add a test case for that soon.
@posva @yyx990803 
While preparing the test cases, I found some attribute serialization are different than v1.0 output like the following.

| Attr | current v2.0 output | v1.0 output |
| :-- | :-- | :-- |
| :test="null" | attr value: null | attr removed |
| :test="false" | attr value: 'false' | attr removed |
| :test="true" | attr value: 'true' | attr value: '' |
| :xlink:special="null" | attr value: null | attr removed |
| :draggable="false" | attr value: 'true' | attr value: 'false' |
| :disabled="false" | attr value: 'disabled' | attr removed |

I modified the 2.0 serialization code to be matched with v1.0 output.

Note that current code of `el.data.attrs['server-rendered'] = true` will have blank attribute by applying the spec. I changed this into String `el.data.attrs['server-rendered'] = 'true'`

More detail, please refer the test cases.
@tejitak nice job!
FYI I made some changes in 5fb1a54 to make the behavior more consistent (and different from 1.x):
- Only `null`, `undefined` and `false` are considered to be falsy values in all cases, including for enumerated attributes. This means `:draggable="''"` will result in `draggable="true"`.
- For enumerated attributes, in addition to the falsy values above, the string value of `"false"` will also render as `attr="false"`.

author: phanan
title: Add support for decimal places in currency filter
body:
I know @yyx990803 has little intention to extend these core functionality, but IMHO you either support something fully or you don't at all. So‚Ä¶

Currently the "currency" filter only accepts one argument: the currency symbol. The number of decimal places is fixed as 2. This can cause troubles with several currencies out there whose number of decimal places can be 0 (e.g. Japanese Yen or Vietnamese Dong) or 3 (e.g. Jordanian Dinar).

This commit modifies the filter to accept an extra optional argument: decimal places, which defaults to 2. With this, one can write `{{ 1234 | currency '¬•' 0 }}` to properly display a Yen value. Backward compatibility is maintained.

(Just realized there's a [StackOverflow question](http://stackoverflow.com/questions/35725935/need-a-flexible-currency-filter-in-vuejs) about this very issue, where the OP was recommended to create a new filter, which is anti-DRY IMO).
comments:
I still think this should be a separate filter,  called `precision`.  It has way more use cases,  and can be chained with this. 
I personally don't think `precision` needs to be a filter ‚Äì it's a mere `toFixed()` call after all ‚Äì or if the users want to, they can create it easily. This commit on the other hand extends what Vue currently has.
Also, decimal places is certainly a currency property and should be implemented as such.
I agree to some extent with your argument,  I suppose this is down to how @yyx990803 sees it best implemented.

author: GuillaumeLeclerc
title: remove :is attribute even when component is cached (fixes #2666)
body:
Hello,

**This bug fixes #2666, a html file reproducing the bug within it's context can be found [here](https://github.com/GuillaumeLeclerc/vue-seo/blob/master/examples/hreflang.html)** 

Since it's only one line I don't think a test is required but I'll explain why the bug occurs and why the PR fixes this.

As stated [here](https://github.com/vuejs/vue/blob/be7339b38ad5083fd0d0baaa2eb9f508b5f9ce23/src/directives/internal/component.js#L55), the compilation is cached so for all components except the first one the attributes are not removed. Users might want to use the ':is' version. In this case it's not removed from the DOM and visible.

This PR fixes the bug in my codebase.

Thank you !

author: sirlancelot
title: [fix] Don't remove newlines during parseText
body:
Since `text` is being used as the key in `cache.get(text)` and the
cache is checked _before_ newlines were removed, the cache would always
miss if the input `text` had _any_ newlines.

I updated `tagRe` to match tags which contain newlines, and added an
extra test case to ensure newlines outside of tags are preserved

Thanks!

author: phanan
title: Support for mutiple class names as key
body: This is to replace #2581.
comments_review:
Unconditional split + forEach can be slow, and class bindings can be a hot spot so performance is important.

Let's do an `key.indexOf(' ') > 1` check first, then use a normal for loop. (And abstract this into a function)
That's what concerned me too, though I don't have an exact idea about the speed comparison between the check and a blind `split`.
instead of passing a boolean, we can just pass in `addClass` or `removeClass` and call it directly. This makes it more explicit at the callsite.
Great idea. Will do.

author: posva
title: orderBy can take a Function as its first argument
body:
Hello,

This feature was asked in #2518. The point of this generic filter is to support any kind of sorting by using a custom comparator. Tell me your thoughts on the feature and the code :smile: 

PS: I did the PR instead of the issue because it took little to no time to do it and I didn't have internet when I coded it :stuck_out_tongue:
comments:
Forgot to comment in the feature request issue, but I think this should just be part of `orderBy`. The first argument can either be a string or a function, this is how `filterBy` works currently.
Ok, ~~so instead of giving a String or an Array of string you can also give your own Function.~~
So the sortKeys becomes `{String|Array<String>|Function}` instead of just `{String|Arrary<String>}`. Makes sense to me. I didn't see that filterBy already worked that way
Let me review this a last time tomorrow in the morning (I want to be fresh :smile: )
I'll ping you when the PR is ready for review
I'll also update the doc

Let's keep it here for now since it's not yet used in any other context. We can move it when we do need to use it elsewhere.
Can this be simplified to: `types.map(formatType).join(', ')`?

Also, it may make more sense to join with `" or "`, so the warning becomes: "Expected Boolean or String" instead of "Expected Boolean, String"
condition could be replaced with `valid === false`
Yeah the code is more readable the way you say. @yyx990803 already did that in this [commit](https://github.com/vuejs/vue/commit/daab3c5f58c97bcb7c528ae199f0419456703e8f). You are right, perhaps using `" or "` instead of `", "` is a better approach.
I've just noticed that this was also changed with this [merge](https://github.com/vuejs/vue/commit/e831412f2a4fbf89f66c13aab0988976adc8ff72)
They say, `let` should be used instead of `var` in ES6.
By the way, checking the `constructor` or `constructor.name` is not reliable enough?

``` js
let ok = 'test'
ok.constructor === String // true
```

author: kazupon
title: Improve terminalable directive
body:
There are times when we want to use the `arg` and `modifires` in custom terminal directive, and control the priority.

e.g.

``` html
<input type="text" v-validate:feild1.input-off="['required']">
```

Recently, in the following related issues or PR, we became able to define the terminal directive.
- allow empty expression in terminal directives
  https://github.com/vuejs/vue/pull/2137
- transfer DOM
  https://github.com/vuejs/vue/issues/2130

However, we can not yet.

I fixed this issues.
I hope that this PR are merged with you.

Please check the codes.
comments:
Thanks for the PR! This one takes some time to review, but I'll do it as soon as I can :+1: 
Thanks!! :smiley_cat: 
ping @yyx990803 
Here's what I think what should be the ideal API: the custom directive should just declare `terminal: true` instead of monkey patching the internal `terminalDirectives` array. We should also change `v-if` and `v-for` to use the same `terminal: true` contract.

With this, the `checkTerminalDirectives` function would largely be the same with `compileDirectives` - pseudo code:

```
let A = "current terminal directive found with highest priority"
- for each attribute on current element:
  - if it's a directive, and has `terminal: true`:
    - if A doesn't exist, or it has higher priority than A:
      - assign it to A
- If A exists, return a terminalLinkFn for it.
```

Does this make sense? I may have overlooked something but I think this could make it more efficient and more consistent.
> custom directive should just declare `terminal: true`

Do want. This will allow to make things like [vue-transfer-dom](https://github.com/rhyzx/vue-transfer-dom) truly reusable (i.e. without `Vue.use(...)`).
I totally agree with the approach not to monkey patch parts of the core API.  This clearly has a use case that makes sense to easily implement, with future extentions this will become ever more requested. 
@yyx990803 
Thank you for your code review , new API proposal for terminal directive, and pseudo code.

When I'm implementing the patch of this PR, I felt that `terminalDirectives` array is monkey patch. I think that your API proposal make sense.

I'll try to challenge based on your feedback. :smile_cat: 
@yyx990803 updated
@yyx990803 
Updated Done.

This PR is breaking change of custom terminal directives.
We need to write the document terminal directive feature.
@kazupon yes. Custom terminal directives were not publicly documented though, so technically this is a new feature. One case I can think of is https://github.com/rhyzx/vue-transfer-dom may need to be updated to use the new API. /cc @rhyzx 
Merged! :tada: 
I think this is the first PR that makes non-trivial updates to the compiler mechanism, great job @kazupon !
@yyx990803 
Thanks !! 

As next step, I'll try to write the documentation.
comments_review:
Perhaps assign the args[0] to a variable.
These change seems pretty expensive since it's now map + sort + nested for loop for every single element compiled. Ideally we want to move as much work out of this function as possible.
we can already extract arg as `matched[2]` here, and can just use that and pass it to `makeTerminalNodeLinkFn` instead of using `argRE`.

author: thecrypticace
title: Support backspace with "delete" keycode alias
body:
Currently when using the `delete` alias in a on directive with keyup `delete" does not support using backspace. This seems quite counterintuitive. Additionally, on Mac keyboards the key normally identified as "backspace" on PC keyboards is called "delete." I was fairly surprised when using the delete modifier didn't detect the key.

I came upon this when developing a search / tag field that turned a search query into tokens when hitting enter or space. I wanted a way to delete tokens without using the mouse. The solution I came up with was detecting the delete key and removing the last token if the search field was empty. I spent 10 minutes debugging code until I realized that I had to press fn+delete (equivalent of DEL / forward delete on a Mac laptop-sized keyboard) for it to actually remove the token.

You can see a reduced test case / demo of this here: http://codepen.io/thecrypticace/pen/YwGKmJ

This PR makes a change to allow aliases to map to multiple key codes. And, using that, it adds support for delete to react to both backspace and DEL / forward delete.
comments:
Thanks for the detailed explanation and test coverage :+1: 
Glad to help.

author: Jinjiang
title: improve nextTick by setImmediate
comments:
We should still prioritize the MutationObserver approach, because it uses **microtask** semantics, and `setImmediate` uses **macrotask** semantics. In environments where both are present (e.g. IE11), we should prioritize the one that is consistent with other browsers where only MutationObserver is present.

For microtask vs macrotask, see https://jakearchibald.com/2015/tasks-microtasks-queues-and-schedules/
Sorry to bump in a bit offtopic Evan ( @yyx990803 ), but what is a macrotask? The article only mentions tasks and microtasks (and it is a great article btw). 

Scott
@yyx990803 gotcha. So mutation observer, promise belongs to microtask and setImmediate, setTimeout, process.nextTick belongs to (macro)task?

And Q1: mutation observer / promise >> (process.nextTick in Node.js > ) setImmediate > setTimeout(0) / process.nextTick polyfill in Browser. Is that correct?
Q2: why a DOM related solution (mutation observer) not promise? 
Ahh...ok. A regular task is a macrotask. Right?

Scott
Q1: yes except that process.nextTick is also microtask in Node > 0.9

Q2: because MutationObserver is more widely supported than native Promise,
and the user may be using a Promise polyfill that doesn't adhere to the
microtask semantics.
On Thu, Jan 21, 2016 at 2:55 AM Scott notifications@github.com wrote:

> Ahh...ok. A regular task is a macrotask. Right?
> 
> Scott
> 
> ‚Äî
> Reply to this email directly or view it on GitHub
> https://github.com/vuejs/vue/pull/2200#issuecomment-173487505.
Well, so this PR will be merged, closed, later or what else? (I have updated the order: MutationObserver, setImmediate, setTimeout)
