author: tgeorgiev
title: stringToFragment not using cache when templateString != templateStrin‚Ä¶
body:
‚Ä¶g.trim()

The issue was that initially we check the cache by an un-trimmed key, while later on, before putting a value in the cache, we trim the key. This would lead to the fragment of a templateString that has spaces at the beginning or the end, not to be retrieved from the cache.
comments:
Thanks, one issue here is that we want to use the `raw` behavior for text-only templates. So we should probably assign the trimmed string to a separate variable so that we can use the original string when a text-only string is detected.
Oh, I see what you mean. I will fix this and update the request shortly. Thanks!

author: rhyzx
title: Fix inline statement propagation
body:
When handle events by inline statement, propagation continuing is not working.

By the way: https://github.com/rhyzx/vue/blob/fix-inline-statement-propagation/test/unit/specs/api/events_spec.js#L186-L187 ,  binding handler using `v-on` directive to component will be treat as its inner handler, this is **non-intuitive** in my opinion, eg:

``` js
// parent.vue
<foo @test="stopPropagation"></foo>
```

`test` event dispatched by `foo` will still propagate even if `stopPropagation` returned `false`, what do you think about this? @yyx990803
comments:
After some investigation I'm starting to think that:
1. inline `v-on` should not interfere with event flow;
2. inline `v-on` should only be triggered by events emitted from that component only (i.e. not by dispatched or broadcasted events).
... but these will be breaking changes. So I'll probably just make inline handlers behave as expected.
:+1: rapid!

> Âú® 2016Âπ¥1Êúà3Êó•Ôºå‰∏äÂçà6:47ÔºåEvan You notifications@github.com ÂÜôÈÅìÔºö
> 
> ... but these will be breaking changes. So I'll probably just make inline handlers behave as expected.
> 
> ‚Äî
> Reply to this email directly or view it on GitHub https://github.com/vuejs/vue/pull/2102#issuecomment-168436007.
Agreed, those can be introduced in next major release.

> Âú® 2016Âπ¥1Êúà3Êó•Ôºå‰∏äÂçà6:22ÔºåEvan You <notifications@github.com <mailto:notifications@github.com>> ÂÜôÈÅìÔºö

>

> inline v-on should only be triggered by events emitted from that component only (i.e. not by dispatched or broadcasted events).

Does it ok to use ES6 syntax here? i searched whole src codes and found there is no ES6 syntax used except modules.
One disadvantage of doing wrapper here instead of [here](https://github.com/vuejs/vue/blob/dev/src/instance/api/data.js#L26) is, **if this statement `isSimplePath`, it is no necessary to wrap it**, so we will waste one function call here.

Good point. Let's wrap it in `$get`. Also, use `util.toArray` to convert `arguments` to an array, the `...args` syntax adds a long for loop in the compiled code.

Unfortunately, had to revert this because this actually neglects a use case where the user attempts to use `v-model` on a `v-for` alias with a read-only filter, e.g. `orderBy`. This is in fact pretty common and is what the original warning is trying to prevent.

With this PR, such use case no longer receives a warning and actually writes the value back to the original array at the wrong index.
Ok. Any ideas for enhancements?

author: jdavidberger
title: Added support for properties which were created with defineProperty o‚Ä¶
body:
‚Ä¶utside of vue.

Previously objects with properties with get/set defined outside of vue wouldn't propagate value changes after being made reactive in vue. This uses getOwnPropertyDescriptor to detect that case and account for it. 

Since it seems like every browser with supports defineProperty also supports getOwnPropertyDescriptor, I didn't add any logic to detect/work without it. 

Also added are two test cases testing the concept. 

If this addition gets pulled, it'd also probably be worthwhile checking the 'configurable' property. If configurable is set to false, defineReactive currently just throws an error. I imagine the correct behavior would be just to return out without changing anything; but this patch doesn't address it.
comments:
Thanks for the PR!

I've considered implementing this before, but decided not to because of 2 reasons:
1. As stated, Vue expects your "data" to be plain objects so that they can be serialized and re-hydrated. Also, being plain objects make them easy to reason about. Allowing the data to contain arbitrary external getter will make component state less predictable. This is why Vue provides computed properties but intentionally limit them to the view layer. I don't really see any particularly convincing use case for data objects with pre-defined getter/setters. Most of them can be achieved using alternative patterns. 
2. Having to check `getOwnPropertyDescriptor` for every single property actually introduces a roughly 10% performance hit even if the user doesn't use this feature at all. This is the primary reason I did not implement this in Vue in the first place.

So unfortunately, I'll have to decline this - but let me know if you think there's a convincing use case that justifies the performance cost. In general, it's a good idea to discuss new features before submitting a PR. But I really appreciate your effort and please keep contributing in the future!
I'm not sure if the use case I'm targeting it for is going to be particularly compelling, but here is what I was using for it. I'm interfacing it with a C library ported into emscripten; the object properties on the JS side invoke getters and setters exposed from emscripten to set attributes in C; which are eventually used to calculate stuff in the C library.

At a 10% performance hit I completely understand not including it. If that wasn't the case, would you consider inclusion? I was curious about the number because I hadn't tested timing benchmarks at all under the assumption that getOwnPropertyDescriptor should be more or less free if you are only doing it once per defineProperty. Did you see the 10% hit on object creation or on object access? I wrote up some quick benchmarks and didn't see a hit in chrome, node, or firefox, but I only tested the latest versions. 
The 10% number was a brief test using one of the re-render benchmarks: https://github.com/vuejs/js-repaint-perfs The cost mostly comes at when replacing large nested objects and we need to convert these new objects to become reactive. This is probably not the most common use case though, so the overall perf hit would be less obvious.

In fact, it maybe a good idea to include this feature under a flag: it's off by default, but can be turned on when you need it and are ok with the perf tradeoff. For example, `Vue.config.convertAllProperties = true`.
Apologies if the above comments aren't formatted correctly; I've never actually used the in-diff commenting in github. 

This should address the key points; namely putting the functionality behind an option which defaults to off and minimizing impact to normal attributes when the option is turned on. I switched out the getter/setter function approach for one that, for the common case of normal attributes, doesn't have to call any functions which should perform better on some engines. 
Thanks!
No problem! Thanks for reconsidering on the feature inclusion!

I did find a problem with the merged commit. 'property' is undefined when defineReactive is actually adding a field that wasn't there before to obj. I'm sure this happens in other places, but I first saw it in the for directive. I have a commit which tests and addresses this in my fork. It didn't flag in the unit tests since that config option is false by default. 

I reran the unit tests with the flag switched on by default and everything passed, so I think it should be good now. I'll be playing with it more in my project to see how it goes; would you rather I make pull requests if/when each thing comes up or group them up over a few days? 
Thanks for the follow up - note that I've made some modifications to the merged parts (mostly trying to further simplify it): https://github.com/vuejs/vue/commit/a71aa59364a0218165e582df5877a8a931d3400f

Ideally rebase your fork against the latest dev before submitting the new PR :)
comments_review:
Two things here:
1. The getter and setter should be invoked using `obj` as the `this` context, so `getter.call(obj)`.
2. The getter only needs to be called once inside the reactive getter. Calling it every time seems unnecessary.
Since people may use Vue in PhantomJS, I've intentionally avoided using the native `bind`. You can use the `bind` provided by Vue's own util: `_.bind(get, obj)` and remove the bind shim in tests.
Since `val` is now a getter, if the original is also a getter, we are still effectively invoking the original getter multiple times here. We should just cache the value as `var value = target.val` at the top of the metaGetter.
Just noticed it's possible for a property to only have getters, or only have setters. We should handle all three possible situations here. Probably need to procedurally build up the descriptor based on the presence of the getter and the setter.
Should be fine to just return `val` here as well.
Please bear with me, thanks for the effort so far :)
No worries it's all good feedback. 

I think the getter/setter stuff makes sense, but might as well also make it safely handle 'configurable' being false. For now I'll make it so it just leaves everything alone; let me know if you think some other behavior makes more sense. 
Not sure how I missed replacing this one out; I'll add a test condition which enforces only calling the underlying getter once.

author: kazupon
title: Occurred TypeError in Observer.create
body:
I create the object with `Object.create(null)` for plugin, and when it would try to define as reactivity object with `Vue.util.defineReactive`, occured the `TypeError` in `Observer.create`.

Please see the following jsfiddle:
https://jsfiddle.net/kazupon/yo2cmsLp/1/

In Vue.js, Can I define the reactity object was created with `Object.create(null)` ?

If this is bug, I hope that you will check PR.
comments:
I fixed. :smile_cat: 
Thanks!
comments_review:
Thanks, but using `in` operator this would return `true` if the `__ob__` is defined on the prototype as well. We can use `Object.prototype.hasOwnProperty.call(value, '__ob__')`.
Thanks!
You're right.

author: fergaldoyle
title: IE should prefer bound props over static props other than class
body:
A follow on from: https://github.com/vuejs/vue/pull/1639

There are more attributes other than `title` which IE has issues with. (`id`, `lang`, `language`,`dir`, etc)
e.g: http://codepen.io/anon/pen/yYxBPy

In this PR, we feature detect binding syntax issues, if the current browser does have this issue, we check every prop for a bound alternative, (`:`, `v-bind:`, `*.sync`, `*.once`) and if present, use the bound prop over a static prop.

`class` is ignored. Buy ignoring it the behavior matches other browsers (bound classes get passed down to component root element)
comments: `hasAttribute` now used and indeed there is no need to check for `.once` or `.sync`
comments_review:
Let's move this check in to `util/env.js` and expose it as `_.preferBinding`.
Looks like we can just use `el.hasAttribute` here and the returned value will be a boolean.
Is the check for `.once` and `.sync` necessary? Does IE also treat `:title.once` as `title`?

author: fergaldoyle
title: IE title binding issue
body:
With IE 10 & 11 (haven't tested on Edge yet), we cannot use title as a prop. Using `:title` or `v-bind:title`, IE seems to convert it to a static title attribute, which Vue will pick up instead of the bound attribute. Example:
http://codepen.io/anon/pen/epryMp

In this PR, a bound `title` attribute is preferred over a static title attribute. 

Perhaps all bound attributes should be preferred over static if both are specified on an element?
comments:
Thanks, can you add a test case in `test/unit/specs/misc_spec.js`?
Done
Thanks!

author: fergaldoyle
title: v-model radio and checkbox expressions
body:
**Radio input**
Added the ability to specify an expression, via attribute `exp`, which will be evaluated on the current scope and set as the v-model value when the radio is selected, similar to Angular `ng-value`. e.g.

``` html
<input type="radio" name="sample" v-model="model.radio" value="1" exp="true" />
<input type="radio" name="sample" v-model="model.radio" value="0" exp="false" />
```

If the first radio is selected, `model.radio === true` instead of `"1"`. When the model updates and `exp` is present, we match the evaluated expression rather than the `value` string when choosing which radio to set as `checked`.

**Checkbox input**
Added the ability to specify a `true-value` and `false-value` which will override the default `true`/`false` values. Similar to Angular `ng-true-value` and `ng-false-value`. e.g:

``` html
<input type="checkbox" v-model="model.checkbox1" true-value="'someTrueValue'" false-value="'someFalseValue'"/>
<input type="checkbox" v-model="model.checkbox2" true-value="expression1" false-value="expression2"/>
```

If present `true-value` and `false-value` will be evaluated on the current scope, and set as the v-model value when the checkbox changes. Similar to the radio, if the model changes a comparison is made against `true-value` and `false-value` values to determine the checkbox state.
comments:
Yes makes sense to use `true-exp` and `false-exp`. Also simplified `matchValue`, either true/trueExp matches the incoming value or it does not, which implies a false match.

https://github.com/yyx990803/vue/commit/b8e364fd3b0a1231452f0e425a0e75e95d174f93
Cool! Mind rebasing against latest `dev` so the CI build can pass?
Hitting the limits of my git knowledge here, I've re-based `v-model-enhancments` onto `dev`, will I have to open a new pull request?

https://github.com/fergaldoyle/vue/commits/dev
Here's what you should **probably** do:

```
git checkout dev
git pull https://github.com/yyx990803/vue.git dev
git checkout v-model-enchancements
git rebase dev
git push -f
```
That seemed to work
Thanks!
comments_review:
Since `el.checked` can be only `true` or `false`, we just need to check if `value` equals `trueValue` here - in all other cases we just return false. This could make `matchValue` much simpler.
To be consistent with `exp` for radio input, maybe we should use `true-exp` and `false-exp`?

author: fergaldoyle
title: Cater for possibility of el not existing
body:
While writing a drag and drop vue sortable directive which uses jQuery UI sortable (both same list and connected list sortable), I found vue was throwing `el` undefined errors a lot with various actions, e.g. dragging the first item in a list then updating the underlying array model. The element had been removed by jQuery while vue was expecting it to exist.

By checking for the existance of `el`, and returning and empty object if it does not exist, allow these two dom manipulation libraries play nicely together.
comments:
This will likely cause the list to go out of sync. I need to see a demo of jQuery UI sortable working properly with this change.
Here is the sortable directive with stock vue.js (throws errors)
http://jsfiddle.net/fergal_doyle/5Lrtte9v/7/

And here is the same directive but with a built of vue.js including the change I made in this PR:
http://jsfiddle.net/fergal_doyle/5Lrtte9v/6/

You can drag and drop items, use methods to reverse and add items to the model in any combination and the list stays in sync.
I've made the changes, no empty object now being returned.
Thanks!
comments_review: I finally got time to investigate this and it seems to indeed work! One thing here is that we can just `if (!el) return`, no need for the empty object.

author: KuroGuo
title: fix getContainedComponents in IE 11
comments:
Is it possible to provide a repro of the error before the fix?
In IE, nextSibling returns a text node, but text node has no method 'contains'.
Merging so you can get credit, I'll fix with tests. :) thanks
FYI, we had the same issue, and came to the same workaround in testing (+cur.contains(el) on the if directive), but kept digging, and it was triggered by IE9 when doing v-if inside a < template > tag.
yep, the whole IE family doesn't implement `contains` for text nodes. In the [spec](http://www.w3.org/TR/domcore/#node) `contains` is part of the `Node` interface, which should be available for text nodes as well, but oh well, it's IE...

author: nkovacs
title: <content> select should only match children.
body: Fixes #786
comments: Thanks!
comments_review:
One possible issue here: if all nodes in `selected` are nested ones (thus should be filtered out), we end up outputting empty content, but in that case we should actually use the fallback content (`outlet.childNodes`).

According to http://w3c.github.io/webcomponents/spec/shadow/#dfn-pool-distribution-algorithm, the algorithm here should be:
- For each direct child node of `raw`, check if it matches `select`.
- If yes, push it into `selected`.
- If `selected` ends up empty, use `outlet.childNodes` instead.

This also means we need a `matches()` helper in `util/dom.js`:

``` js
var p = Element.prototype
var matches = p.matches || p.webkitMatchesSelector || p.mozMatchesSelector || p.msMatchesSelector
exports.matches = function (el, selector) {
  return matches.call(el, selector)
}
```
I wanted to avoid element.matches because its browser support is slightly worse than querySelectorAll (http://caniuse.com/#feat=matchesselector vs http://caniuse.com/#search=queryselectorall). In practice it probably doesn't matter (opera mini 8 is the only browser that's still used of those, and I don't know if vue even supports it), but I decided to play it safe.

author: 44px
title: Return empty string for Infinity and properly format values such as 0.999
body:
This PR fixes two issues in currency filter (demo for both: http://jsfiddle.net/k5bv3r62/ ):

1) x.999 values are shown as $x.00
Say you have model with value 0.999. With currency filter applied it will be shown as $0.00

2) Infinity value show as $In,finity.ty
I think, it would be good to return empty string as for falsy values

Also I added new test cases for described issues.
comments:
Thanks for the PR. Would it be weird to have `Infinity` output as empty string though? Maybe it should just print `"Infinity"`?
Thanks for response.

That's interesting question. Here is my thoughts:
It seems that printing an empty string is a default way to say that value is wrong. Currency filter does it for `undefined` and for `NaN`. And it would be less weird to see 'Amount: ' than 'Amount: NaN' or 'Amount: Infinity' somewhere in interface.

Also I made this test with AngularJS, it prints empty string: http://jsfiddle.net/41Lga6bg/
Sounds good, it's probably a good idea to keep the filter consistent with Angular's implementation.
Thanks!
comments_review:
fix indent here?
Fixed.

author: bpierre
title: Fixed transitions on some Android 4.1 devices
body:
On some devices (tested on a Samsung Galaxy S2), the Android 4.1 browser erroneously reports to support unprefixed transitions events, while it‚Äôs in fact not implemented.

The solution is to test for the prefixed version first. The WebKit-prefixed event has been moved on top of the tested events, and while the Object properties order is not guaranteed in JavaScript (ES3, section 4.3.3), it is the case in the targeted browser.

More information:
https://github.com/Modernizr/Modernizr/issues/897
https://bugs.dojotoolkit.org/ticket/17164

author: bpierre
title: Implements plugin parameters
body:
Small change: every additional parameters is passed to the function instead of a single `options` param. As a consequence, `this` is set to the current ViewModel if the plugin is a function.

Tell me if that‚Äôs OK, otherwise I¬†will change it to respect what you said in #88. I will also make a pull request on https://github.com/vuejs/vuejs.org.
comments: Landed! Thanks a lot :)
comments_review:
Why slice then unshift here? It seems simply `plugin.install.apply(plugin, arguments)` will do.
Because I want to replace `arguments[0]` with `ViewModel` (otherwise, `arguments[0]` is the plugin function / string / object), and `arguments[0]` cannot be reassigned.
Oh you're right, I was reading the code out of context...
Can you use `[].slice` here? This function is not perf sensitive and it could save a few bytes :)
I think it's better to keep `this` context consistent here. In the case of a raw function could you use `plugin.apply(null, args)`?
Sure! I was using Array.prototype.slice for performance reasons, but you are right :)
One more note - let's check `if (plugin.install)` first. This way plugins can also expose functions that has a `install` method.
Agree, I will do that. Do you prefer a separate commit, or should I try to force an amended version?
Force push with one commit please. I'd love to keep the commit log as clean as possible. Thanks a lot!
I don‚Äôt do any check here, I think it‚Äôs fine to crash if a plugin author tries to `.use()` a plugin with a wrong interface.
Can you remove the `vue` argument here and in the function below? Just for jshint to pass (complaining unused vue...). I've run through the build and everything else looks good to merge once this is fixed.
Done!

author: th0r
title: Support boolean attributes
body:
Current `v-attr` implementation doesn't support boolean attributes (e.g. `disabled`).
Here is the common use-case:

```
<button type="submit" v-attr="disabled: !submittionAllowed">
```

It doesn't work because `v-attr` uses `this.el.setAttribute` method. So, when `submittionAllowed` equals to `true`, then submit button will look like this:

```
<button type="submit" disabled="false">
```

...which is treated by browser as disabled button.
My proposal is to remove current attribute if it's value is falsy (except zero).
comments:
Hi Yuriy, I have tested locally and it's looking good. Just one final thing: please do not include the `/dist` files in the commits. If you can reset and make a single clean commit without the `/dist` files it will be good to merge. (You can just push -f to your current branch)
@yyx990803 Fixed! =)
Merged! Thanks for the great work! :+1:
:beers: I just ran into this. Thanks!

author: rhengles
title: Lazy load for components, filters and directives (fix #8106)
body:
<!--
Please make sure to read the Pull Request Guidelines:
https://github.com/vuejs/vue/blob/dev/.github/CONTRIBUTING.md#pull-request-guidelines
-->

<!-- PULL REQUEST TEMPLATE -->
<!-- (Update "[ ]" to "[x]" to check a box) -->

**What kind of change does this PR introduce?** (check at least one)

- [ ] Bugfix
- [x] Feature
- [ ] Code style update
- [ ] Refactor
- [ ] Build-related changes
- [ ] Other, please describe:

**Does this PR introduce a breaking change?** (check one)

- [ ] Yes
- [x] No

If yes, please describe the impact and migration path for existing applications:

**The PR fulfills these requirements:**

- [x] It's submitted to the `dev` branch for v2.x (or to a previous version branch), _not_ the `master` branch
- [x] When resolving a specific issue, it's referenced in the PR's title (e.g. `fix #xxx[,#xxx]`, where "xxx" is the issue number)
- [x] All tests are passing: https://github.com/vuejs/vue/blob/dev/.github/CONTRIBUTING.md#development-setup
- [ ] New/updated tests are included

If adding a **new feature**, the PR's description includes:
- [x] A convincing reason for adding this feature (to avoid wasting your time, it's best to open a suggestion issue first and wait for approval before working on it)

**Other information:**

The convincing reason was explained at length over at #8106. I know this will not be merged, in fact I'm gonna close it myself. But I'm publishing this PR for reference for anyone else interested.

The initial need was for components, but when reviewing the code I thought the most elegant way to do this was by changing the `resolveAsset()` function to call a user function defined on the `$options` object:

```
getComponent(id: string, identifierSpellings: Object): void | Component | AsyncComponent
getDirective(id: string, identifierSpellings: Object): void | Directive
getFilter(id: string, identifiesSpellings: Object): void | Filter
```

The `identifierSpellings` object has normalized spellings in case the user needs it:

- raw: the way it was called
- hyphenated
- camelized
- PascalCase
- and a toString() method, which returns the raw version

The nice thing about this is that it gives all the power to the user, and enables him to do many things which aren't possible with the current api, and the biggest use case is to **lazily load async components only when they are needed.**

I know that to submit a decent PR, I'd still need to write tests and documentation... that is the next step.

A running example can be seen here:

https://unpkg.com/@arijs/vue-generator@0.1.4/outra/pagina/

My version is released at:
https://unpkg.com/@arijs/vue@2.5.17-beta1.0/
https://www.npmjs.com/package/@arijs/vue

author: Hoishin
title: Fix #8798: $refs TypeScript type definition
body:
<!--
Please make sure to read the Pull Request Guidelines:
https://github.com/vuejs/vue/blob/dev/.github/CONTRIBUTING.md#pull-request-guidelines
-->

<!-- PULL REQUEST TEMPLATE -->
<!-- (Update "[ ]" to "[x]" to check a box) -->

Fixes #8798 

When you refer to `$refs`, the type if always something truthy, while it is possible that the value is `undefined`.
Without this change, one can refer to a `ref` that is `undefined`, but TypeScript thinks it is `Element` or `Vue`.

This PR added `undefined` type to the type of `$refs`. This way it is more type-safe when using `$refs`.

**What kind of change does this PR introduce?** (check at least one)

- [x] Bugfix
- [ ] Feature
- [ ] Code style update
- [ ] Refactor
- [ ] Build-related changes
- [ ] Other, please describe:

**Does this PR introduce a breaking change?** (check one)

- [x] Yes
- [ ] No

If yes, please describe the impact and migration path for existing applications:

This change will break code written in TypeScript which does not null-check the value of `this.$refs.foo`.

**The PR fulfills these requirements:**

- [x] It's submitted to the `dev` branch for v2.x (or to a previous version branch), _not_ the `master` branch
- [x] When resolving a specific issue, it's referenced in the PR's title (e.g. `fix #xxx[,#xxx]`, where "xxx" is the issue number)
- [ ] All tests are passing: https://github.com/vuejs/vue/blob/dev/.github/CONTRIBUTING.md#development-setup
- [ ] New/updated tests are included

~~If adding a **new feature**, the PR's description includes:~~
~~- [ ] A convincing reason for adding this feature (to avoid wasting your time, it's best to open a suggestion issue first and wait for approval before working on it)~~

**Other information:**
comments:
The test is failing, but the failed test seems to be unrelated to my change.Hi @Hoishin, I don't think this is a safe change. It won't make any change when users don't turn on `strictNullChecks`. And if users do turn on it, this pull request doesn't prevent them from casting refs to non-null.  To sum, the benefit of adding `undefined` doesn't pay for its cost.

If you do want to ensure type safety when using refs, you probably should use class style component and refine `$refs` typing there. Example: https://github.com/vuejs/vue-class-component/blob/master/example/App.vue#L58-L60

author: Justineo
title: fix (#8731): drop enumerated attrs
body:
<!--
Please make sure to read the Pull Request Guidelines:
https://github.com/vuejs/vue/blob/dev/.github/CONTRIBUTING.md#pull-request-guidelines
-->

<!-- PULL REQUEST TEMPLATE -->
<!-- (Update "[ ]" to "[x]" to check a box) -->

**What kind of change does this PR introduce?** (check at least one)

- [x] Bugfix
- [ ] Feature
- [ ] Code style update
- [ ] Refactor
- [ ] Build-related changes
- [ ] Other, please describe:

**Does this PR introduce a breaking change?** (check one)

- [ ] Yes
- [ ] No
- [x] Not sure

If yes, please describe the impact and migration path for existing applications:

As explained in #8731.

**The PR fulfills these requirements:**

- [x] It's submitted to the `dev` branch for v2.x (or to a previous version branch), _not_ the `master` branch
- [x] When resolving a specific issue, it's referenced in the PR's title (e.g. `fix #xxx[,#xxx]`, where "xxx" is the issue number)
- [x] All tests are passing: https://github.com/vuejs/vue/blob/dev/.github/CONTRIBUTING.md#development-setup
- [x] New/updated tests are included

If adding a **new feature**, the PR's description includes:
- [ ] A convincing reason for adding this feature (to avoid wasting your time, it's best to open a suggestion issue first and wait for approval before working on it)

**Other information:**
comments:
See https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/HTML/Global_attributes/draggable

The logic is still needed to coerce `true` and `false` to `"true"` and `"false"` - we just need to allow additional values.Then maybe we should coerce all boolean bindings for non-boolean attributes to string. There are other attributes like `aria-hidden` which accept `'true'`/`'false'` values. Now it seems that we already require users to coerce themselves. Is it better to apply this default coercing to all non-boolean attributes? There seems no need to have special logic for enumerated attributes - we only have normal attributes and boolean ones. @yyx990803Hmm that's true... however, dropping the logic altogether would technically be a breaking change, as code that previous produced valid usage would now require manual coercing from the user.

So I think for 2.x it's better to just loosen the coercing to skip non-boolean values so that other values for `contenteditable` can be used.Current behavior for normal attributes and ‚Äúenumerated attributes‚Äù in Vue:

| Binding | `foo` | `draggable` |
| - | - | - |
| `:attr="null"` | / | `draggable="false"` |
| `:attr="undefined"` | / | / |
| `:attr="true"` | `foo="true"` | `draggable="true"` |
| `:attr="false"` | / | `draggable="false"` |
| `:attr="0"` | `foo="0"` | `draggable="true"` |
| `attr=""` | `foo=""` | `draggable="true"` |
| `attr="foo"` | `foo="foo"` | `draggable="true"` |
| `attr` | `foo=""` | `draggable="true"` |

I can think of two solutions:

1. We can coerce boolean values into string and drop `enumeratedAttrs` entirely, we'll have:

    | Binding | new `draggable` | old `draggable` |
    | - | - | - |
    | `:draggable="null"` | / | `draggable="false"` |
    | `:draggable="undefined"` | / | / |
    | `:draggable="true"` | `draggable="true"` | `draggable="true"` |
    | `:draggable="false"` | `draggable="false"` | `draggable="false"` |
    | `:draggable="0"` | `draggable="0"` | `draggable="true"` |
    | `draggable=""` | `draggable=""` | `draggable="true"` |
    | `draggable="foo"` | `draggable="foo"` | `draggable="true"` |
    | `draggable` | `draggable=""` | `draggable="true"` |

    It brings a lot of consistency across all enumerated properties and the only cases which will break legacy usage would be we are not coercing `null` to `'false'` and invalid stuff (numbers, empty strings, attributes without values) to `'true'` anymore. Or we can still coerce attributes without binding value to `'true'` to make some usage still work (`foo` → `foo="true"` doesn't hurt).

2. Or we can keep the `enumertedAttrs` logic, and directly output the original value as long as we got string, we'll have:

    | Binding | new `draggable` | old `draggable` |
    | - | - | - |
    | `:draggable="null"` | `draggable="false"` | `draggable="false"` |
    | `:draggable="undefined"` | / | / |
    | `:draggable="true"` | `draggable="true"` | `draggable="true"` |
    | `:draggable="false"` | `draggable="false"` | `draggable="false"` |
    | `:draggable="0"` | `draggable="true"` | `draggable="true"` |
    | `draggable=""` | `draggable=""` | `draggable="true"` |
    | `draggable="foo"` | `draggable="foo"` | `draggable="true"` |
    | `draggable` | `draggable="true"` | `draggable="true"` |

    The second might be safer but my concern is that the original `enumeratedAttrs` is actually flawed. Otherthan `spellcheck`/`draggable`/`contenteditable`, there are quite a few enumerated (and boolean-like) attributes in WAI-ARIA like `aria-hidden`/`aria-selected`/... so there's already inconsistency here. The first plan would solve this inconsistency.

author: HcySunYang
title: fix(#8728): only execute the dependArray function once
body:
<!--
Please make sure to read the Pull Request Guidelines:
https://github.com/vuejs/vue/blob/dev/.github/CONTRIBUTING.md#pull-request-guidelines
-->

<!-- PULL REQUEST TEMPLATE -->
<!-- (Update "[ ]" to "[x]" to check a box) -->

**What kind of change does this PR introduce?** (check at least one)

- [ ] Bugfix
- [ ] Feature
- [ ] Code style update
- [ ] Refactor
- [ ] Build-related changes
- [x] Other, please describe: This PR is not a bug fix, but a performance improvement for issue #8728.

**Does this PR introduce a breaking change?** (check one)

- [ ] Yes
- [x] No

If yes, please describe the impact and migration path for existing applications:

**The PR fulfills these requirements:**

- [x] It's submitted to the `dev` branch for v2.x (or to a previous version branch), _not_ the `master` branch
- [x] When resolving a specific issue, it's referenced in the PR's title (e.g. `fix #xxx[,#xxx]`, where "xxx" is the issue number)
- [x] All tests are passing: https://github.com/vuejs/vue/blob/dev/.github/CONTRIBUTING.md#development-setup
- [x] New/updated tests are included

If adding a **new feature**, the PR's description includes:
- [ ] A convincing reason for adding this feature (to avoid wasting your time, it's best to open a suggestion issue first and wait for approval before working on it)

**Other information:**
The `newDepIds` property of each Watcher instance object holds all the dependencies collected by this evaluation. We can prevent the `dependArray` function from being called multiple times by checking if the dependency has been collected.
comments: em.. I think the changes in this PR cause a regression bug. It looks like the `dependArray` method was designed to solve the dependency problem in a nested array. ```vue ``` Have not try this example with your branch yet, but I think the `checkRelated` will cause the nest array not reactive.The `dependArray` function will still execute, except that it will only execute `once`. `Watcher` collects dependencies by executing getters, and each time the getter is executed, the `watcher.cleanupDeps` function is executed to reset `newDepIds`. That is, everything is a new start every time the watcher's getter is re-executed, but in the process, there is no need to execute the `dependArray` function multiple times. It does not cause nested arrays to be not reactive.my bad, the check was executed before depend so it is ok:)@wangyi7099 When value is a plain-object, your code will cause it to fail to collect dependencies. And performance issues only occur in the case of large arrays, usually we don't need to care about objects@HcySunYang I'm sorry. My sample code has some errors. I have updated it. > And performance issues only occur in the case of large arrays, usually we don't need to care about objects I think you are right. But I also think care about plain-object will also save some performance cost.

author: ypresto
title: fix(sfc): do not deindent space-padded output
body:
**What kind of change does this PR introduce?** (check at least one)

- [x] Bugfix
- [ ] Feature
- [ ] Code style update
- [ ] Refactor
- [ ] Build-related changes
- [ ] Other, please describe:

**Does this PR introduce a breaking change?** (check one)

- [x] Yes
- [ ] No

If yes, please describe the impact and migration path for existing applications:

`parseComponent('...', { pad: 'space' }).script.content` will contain code with base indent if SFC content has base indent. Also applies to styles or etc.

As #5058 and #5059, `pad: 'space'` is for character-oriented tools that calculate positions by distance from the beginning of the file instead of by line. This should be applied to source code itself, so I think it was buggy and breaking change is unavoidable. 

**The PR fulfills these requirements:**

- [x] It's submitted to the `dev` branch for v2.x (or to a previous version branch), _not_ the `master` branch
- [x] When resolving a specific issue, it's referenced in the PR's title (e.g. `fix #xxx[,#xxx]`, where "xxx" is the issue number)
- [x] All tests are passing: https://github.com/vuejs/vue/blob/dev/.github/CONTRIBUTING.md#development-setup
- [x] New/updated tests are included

**Other information:**

I'm personally creating tool to convert `export default { ... }` to `vue-property-decorators` style, so I'm using `vue-template-compiler` with `@vue/component-compiler-utils` and code with original indent is needed.

author: bowen31337
title: fix(parser): add data-v- prefix to make directive comply with WCAG2 A
body:
Add data-v- prefix for the directive to make the site comply with WCAG2 level A standard

Attribute with v- prefix is regarded as invalid attribute in https://validator.w3.org/, that results
in the accessibility error for not complying with WCAG2 A. In the western countries, the public
sites built with Vuejs in such way have the risks of being sued for not making the sites accessible.

<!--
Please make sure to read the Pull Request Guidelines:
https://github.com/vuejs/vue/blob/dev/.github/CONTRIBUTING.md#pull-request-guidelines
-->

**Other information:**
Reference: https://www.w3.org/TR/UNDERSTANDING-WCAG20/ensure-compat-parses.html
comments:
Thanks for your PR üôÇ 
Your resulting HTML is wc3 compliant, and that's what matters. See #273@posva It does not hurt to add ‚Äúdata-‚Äú prefix, it gives devs the option to choose the directive. If the framework does not provide this option, then it is the framework to blame.

It is undeniable that the directive will be removed when the rendered tree is complete, BUT BUT BUT It is really unaccessible when the JavaScript of the page is disabled.

author: Justineo
title: feat: support v-html for SVG elements
body:
<!--
Please make sure to read the Pull Request Guidelines:
https://github.com/vuejs/vue/blob/dev/.github/CONTRIBUTING.md#pull-request-guidelines
-->

<!-- PULL REQUEST TEMPLATE -->
<!-- (Update "[ ]" to "[x]" to check a box) -->

**What kind of change does this PR introduce?** (check at least one)

- [ ] Bugfix
- [x] Feature
- [ ] Code style update
- [ ] Refactor
- [ ] Build-related changes
- [ ] Other, please describe:

**Does this PR introduce a breaking change?** (check one)

- [ ] Yes
- [x] No

If yes, please describe the impact and migration path for existing applications:

**The PR fulfills these requirements:**

- [x] It's submitted to the `dev` branch for v2.x (or to a previous version branch), _not_ the `master` branch
- [ ] When resolving a specific issue, it's referenced in the PR's title (e.g. `fix #xxx[,#xxx]`, where "xxx" is the issue number)
- [x] All tests are passing: https://github.com/vuejs/vue/blob/dev/.github/CONTRIBUTING.md#development-setup
- [x] New/updated tests are included

If adding a **new feature**, the PR's description includes:
- [x] A convincing reason for adding this feature (to avoid wasting your time, it's best to open a suggestion issue first and wait for approval before working on it)

Currently for older browsers (IE9~IE11) we cannot use `v-html` on SVG elements because they don't support `innerHTML` for SVG elements. While actually we can fix this without much effort and make it ‚Äújust works‚Äù. As `innerHTML` is defined for `Element` interface (which `SVGElement` is derived from) [in the latest spec](https://w3c.github.io/DOM-Parsing/#dfn-innerhtml), I think it's reasonable to add this for `v-html`.

**Other information:**

Related issues: #5310 #5756

Since it's a browser-specific fix and we don't run tests for IE locally, I created a repo to demonstrate the fix: https://github.com/Justineo/v-html-svg

* With latest `vue` on `unpkg.com`, see: https://justineo.github.io/v-html-svg/test-original.html
* After the fix, see: https://justineo.github.io/v-html-svg/test-fixed.html

I've tested and it should now work in IE 9~IE 11.

author: wildan2711
title: fix(v-model): prevent double v-model update on functional components(#8436)
body:
<!--
Please make sure to read the Pull Request Guidelines:
https://github.com/vuejs/vue/blob/dev/.github/CONTRIBUTING.md#pull-request-guidelines
-->

<!-- PULL REQUEST TEMPLATE -->
<!-- (Update "[ ]" to "[x]" to check a box) -->

**What kind of change does this PR introduce?** (check at least one)

- [x] Bugfix
- [ ] Feature
- [ ] Code style update
- [ ] Refactor
- [ ] Build-related changes
- [ ] Other, please describe:

**Does this PR introduce a breaking change?** (check one)

- [ ] Yes
- [x] No

If yes, please describe the impact and migration path for existing applications:

**The PR fulfills these requirements:**

- [x] It's submitted to the `dev` branch for v2.x (or to a previous version branch), _not_ the `master` branch
- [x] When resolving a specific issue, it's referenced in the PR's title (e.g. `fix #xxx[,#xxx]`, where "xxx" is the issue number)
- [x] All tests are passing: https://github.com/vuejs/vue/blob/dev/.github/CONTRIBUTING.md#development-setup
- [ ] New/updated tests are included

If adding a **new feature**, the PR's description includes:
- [ ] A convincing reason for adding this feature (to avoid wasting your time, it's best to open a suggestion issue first and wait for approval before working on it)

**Other information:**
Currently, when transforming `data.model` in `createElement` function, it does not check if the component is a functional component, causing a double update on `v-model`. This prevents double update on v-model in functional components by not transforming model when `Ctor.options.functional` is `true`.

fix #8436 and eventually https://github.com/vuetifyjs/vuetify/issues/4460

author: sagirk
title: fix (shared-utils): Improve readability and consistency in code comments (fix #8528)
body:
Improvements that apply to all comments:
- Consistent use of periods
- Consistent use of commas
- Consistent capitalization
- Correct use of articles (a, an, the)

Improvements to specific comments:
- Correct pluralization in the description for helper functions
- Re-word for clarity and break into shorter sentences the description
for `polyfillBind` function
- Re-word for clarity the description for `genStaticKeys` function
- Add a previously missing description for `looseIndexOf` function

Fixes: https://github.com/vuejs/vue/issues/8528

author: phablulo
title: update toMs function. fix #4894
body:
Old versions of [Chromium](https://www.chromium.org/) (below 61.0.3163.100) [formats floating pointer numbers in a locale-dependent way, using a comma instead of a dot](https://bugs.chromium.org/p/chromium/issues/detail?id=720222).
This PR makes toMs function parse it correctly, preventing unexpected behaviors.

<!--
Please make sure to read the Pull Request Guidelines:
https://github.com/vuejs/vue/blob/dev/.github/CONTRIBUTING.md#pull-request-guidelines
-->

comments:
hmm, this bug was fixed in Chromium a while ago (https://bugs.chromium.org/p/chromium/issues/detail?id=720222). What is the current version used by Electron?
BTW, this needs a small comment saying a bug in old versions of chromium used by electron uses a comma version (locale dependent) instead of a dotElectron 2.0.5 (current latest) uses Chromium 61.0.3163.100, the bug seems to be fixed on version 68.0.3409.0

I'll add the commentoh lol, so it wasn't fixed as long ago as I thought it wascomment fixed (: I meant in the code üòÜ lol, sorry!
I fixed just commented the code

author: sodatea
title: fix(transition): check existence of `el.parentNode`, fix #8199
body:
Fix #8199 
If the new parentNode gets a `textContent` or `innerHTML` property during patching, the `transition` node would have been detached early, which means `el.parentNode` no longer exists.
So this existential check is necessary.

This is an imperfect fix because while errors are suppressed, transition animations still get lost.
It is due to the different mechanism of `v-html` and VDOM element patching. But fixing that would be much more complex and I don't think we'd bother fixing such an edge case.

author: wqzwh
title: The first parameter in plugin.install.apply can also be defined as: null or undefined

Whether the first parameter in plugin.install.apply can be null or undefined. In fact, at the same time when the plugin is installed, the plugin can get the context of the current plugin. It is not necessary to pass the context via install.apply.

title: feat(errors): sync/async error handling for lifecycle hooks and v-on handlers (#7653, #6953)
body:
<!--

https://github.com/vuejs/vue/blob/dev/.github/CONTRIBUTING.md#pull-request-guidelines
-->

<!-- PULL REQUEST TEMPLATE -->
<!-- (Update "[ ]" to "[x]" to check a box) -->

- Added async errors handling for lifecycle hooks and event handlers (issue link: #7653). 

Update:
- Added normal and async errors handling in v-on handlers from @coldino (issue link: #6953).

If adding a **new feature**, the PR's description includes:

comments:
Can we add error handling for v-on handlers to this? Both sync and async need to be caught for them.

I have working code and tests for this here: <https://github.com/coldino/vue/commits/event-handler-errors>. It would need very minor updates to work with the changes in this PR.

This will also address #6953.@coldino 
I think it will be great to address 2 issues in this PR. But what will be the proper way to merge changes? You can create pull request to this branch - "feature/async-errors-handling", and I will edit PR according to the changes from you ( for #6953 ).
P.S. or just create separate PR for #6953@enkot The changes will overlap significantly as I would switch to using your handlePromiseError function, so I will create a PR for your branch. Note that in addition to the ones you implemented, I also added async error handling for:
 * watcher callbacks
 * nextTick callbacks
 * invoked functions (v-on)
 * directive hooks

Currently there are only tests for the v-on invoked function async+sync errors. I don't have enough experience with the testing system to add tests for all of them. If you are able to assist with this we can have much greater coverage for async error catching.

I will keep the hooks without tests in a separate commit so you can include/exclude as you choose.I have only included the v-on checks in the PR as I didn't want to include changes with no tests and possibly delay this PR.

comments:
Could you provide a minimal repro of the bug please?@posva 
Sure: [codesandbox repro](https://codesandbox.io/s/9yq45q0wk4)

p.s.
Of course, in our app code we can subscribe on child's events and use `stopPropagation` as a workaround. But I think, `<transition-group>` should only affect direct descendants
Or at least this case can be documented somewhereThanks, now it is much clearer! This seems reasonable to me but could break some people work, so it would be interesting if there is any reasonable usage of nested elements transitions to trigger that transition-group. This is because, as you said, it's very easy to workaround the problem by adding ` @transitionend.stop` to the nested element that also has a transition

author: Globegitter
title: Provide amd id for umd build
body:
<!--
Please make sure to read the Pull Request Guidelines:
https://github.com/vuejs/vue/blob/dev/.github/CONTRIBUTING.md#pull-request-guidelines
-->

<!-- PULL REQUEST TEMPLATE -->
<!-- (Update "[ ]" to "[x]" to check a box) -->

**What kind of change does this PR introduce?** (check at least one)

- [ ] Bugfix
- [ ] Feature
- [ ] Code style update
- [ ] Refactor
- [x] Build-related changes
- [ ] Other, please describe:

**Does this PR introduce a breaking change?** (check one)

- [x] Yes
- [ ] No

If yes, please describe the impact and migration path for existing applications:

**The PR fulfills these requirements:**

- [x] It's submitted to the `dev` branch for v2.x (or to a previous version branch), _not_ the `master` branch
- [ ] When resolving a specific issue, it's referenced in the PR's title (e.g. `fix #xxx[,#xxx]`, where "xxx" is the issue number)
- [x] All tests are passing: https://github.com/vuejs/vue/blob/dev/.github/CONTRIBUTING.md#development-setup
- [ ] New/updated tests are included

If adding a **new feature**, the PR's description includes:
- [ ] A convincing reason for adding this feature (to avoid wasting your time, it's best to open a suggestion issue first and wait for approval before working on it)

**Other information:**
We are running a dev-setup where all our code is converted to amd module and then concatenated to one file. This is the approach that [Bazel](https://bazel.build/) takes for js dev. For more details see: https://github.com/alexeagle/angular-bazel-example/wiki/Running-a-devserver-under-Bazel When depending on the vue build the problem is it does not have an id so when the umd file is being loaded requirejs complains about an anonymous module. Just by providing the id this is fixed and we can depend on vue from our application.
comments:
I don't think it's a good idea to add an AMD id for the UMD bundle. AMD's named modules is used to handle situations where there are multiple modules inside one single file as an escape hatch. Usually it's for final bundled AMD modules and will make the module less portable. Moreover, adding a module id will be a breaking change which we won't accept ATM.

In your case I suggest you ‚Äúalias‚Äù `vue` to Vue's CommonJS version (`dist/vue.common.js`) and wrap it into a named AMD module during your loading process yourself.Angular for example provides amd ids and it seems to work fine there. I see that in theory it makes it less portable, but how else would one want to call vue? I would be surprised if anyone would not have `import Vue from 'vue'` or the equivalent depending on their module format. But if there is sentiment against it that is also fair enough and this can be closed.

author: yywc
title: refactor(state.js): Warning of defining a data that starts with _ or $
body:
When we defining a data that starts with _ or $ in data() and use this._xxx in created() or
mounted(), it returns 'undefined' instead of the value we have defined.But there is no any tips for
this phenomenon.

BREAKING CHANGE: When this occur,console will show vue warning.

author: hirokiosame
title: Methods in functional components
body:
<!--
Please make sure to read the Pull Request Guidelines:
https://github.com/vuejs/vue/blob/dev/.github/CONTRIBUTING.md#pull-request-guidelines
-->

<!-- PULL REQUEST TEMPLATE -->
<!-- (Update "[ ]" to "[x]" to check a box) -->

**What kind of change does this PR introduce?** (check at least one)

- [ ] Bugfix
- [x] Feature
- [ ] Code style update
- [ ] Refactor
- [ ] Build-related changes
- [ ] Other, please describe:

**Does this PR introduce a breaking change?** (check one)

- [ ] Yes
- [x] No

If yes, please describe the impact and migration path for existing applications:

**The PR fulfills these requirements:**

- [x] It's submitted to the `dev` branch for v2.x (or to a previous version branch), _not_ the `master` branch
- [x] When resolving a specific issue, it's referenced in the PR's title (e.g. `fix #xxx[,#xxx]`, where "xxx" is the issue number)
- [x] All tests are passing: https://github.com/vuejs/vue/blob/dev/.github/CONTRIBUTING.md#development-setup
- [x] New/updated tests are included

If adding a **new feature**, the PR's description includes:
- [ ] A convincing reason for adding this feature (to avoid wasting your time, it's best to open a suggestion issue first and wait for approval before working on it)

**Other information:**
Currently it's difficult to use the functional template since you lose access to closures where as the render method can reference closed-over functions.
comments:
why `functional` component need method?@Kingwl I already explained in the PR body but, when using a render method instead of using a functional template, I can write functions outside of the component and reference them via closure. However, when using a template, I no longer have access to the closure.

I can reference them via `$options.methods` but seems hacky and would prefer official support in offering a similar API to stateful components.I respect your work, but I think there will be a better solution(maybe)
/ cc: @posva I think that rather than having just methods, it will be useful to be able to inject stuff in the context so it can also be accessed in templates What are you thinking @Kingwl ?

@posva If I've understood your suggestion correctly, that is what this PR is doing; it allows methods to be injected into the context so it can be accessed in the template. I'd like to see more support of functional components so that they can be easier to use and hence more useful; this will be a step towards that.

Here's an issue in vue-loader (it was originally in vue but closed) that might explain the use-case more clearly: https://github.com/vuejs/vue-loader/issues/1291

author: industral
title: Need judge styles[transitionProp 'Duration'] is undefined (fix #7444)
body:
**What kind of change does this PR introduce?** (check at least one) - [x] Bugfix - [ ] Feature - [ ] Code style update - [ ] Refactor - [ ] Build-related changes - [ ] Other, please describe: **Does this PR introduce a breaking change?** (check one) - [ ] Yes - [x] No **The PR fulfills these requirements:** - [x] It's submitted to the `dev` branch for v2.x (or to a previous version branch), _not_ the `master` branch - [x] When resolving a specific issue, it's referenced in the PR's title (e.g. `fix #xxx[,#xxx]`, where "xxx" is the issue number) - [x] All tests are passing: https://github.com/vuejs/vue/blob/dev/.github/CONTRIBUTING.md#development-setup - [ ] New/updated tests are included **Other information:** `jsdom` returns `undefined` from `style` instead of empty string. ``` $ node > const jsdom = require("jsdom"); undefined > const { JSDOM } = jsdom; undefined > const dom = new JSDOM(`

Hello world

`); undefined > dom.window.document.querySelector("p").style CSSStyleDeclaration { '0': 'color', _values: { color: 'red' }, _importants: { color: '' }, _length: 1, _onChange: [Function] } > dom.window.document.querySelector("p").style.color 'red' > dom.window.document.querySelector("p").style.unexisted undefined > ``` So a solution is to do like that: ``` (styles[transitionProp + 'Delay'] || '').split(', ') ```
comments: +1Any news on it?still nothing?

author: mpbarlow
title: fix(#7913): Prevent erroneous warning when using <slot> inside slot-scope
body:
Because slotNodes inside a slot-scope context are already set to \_rendered = true after initial
render, the warning for duplicate slot presence always fires when a slot-scope prop change triggers
a re-render. With this change, the compiler tracks whether any slot-scoped elements have been
encountered yet at the point the slot is compiled. If so, the direct ancestors of the slot are checked
for slot-scope presence, and if one is found, the warning is supressed.

This is admittedly not a perfect solution, as within a slot-scope context the warning now does not fire even when there _are_ duplicate slots, but I couldn't find a good way to get around that.

fix #7913

author: mathieutu
title: fix #8093: Use custom toString method when interpolating objects if implemented
body:
<!--
Please make sure to read the Pull Request Guidelines:
https://github.com/vuejs/vue/blob/dev/.github/CONTRIBUTING.md#pull-request-guidelines
-->

<!-- PULL REQUEST TEMPLATE -->
<!-- (Update "[ ]" to "[x]" to check a box) -->

**What kind of change does this PR introduce?** (check at least one)

- [ ] Bugfix
- [x] Feature
- [ ] Code style update
- [ ] Refactor
- [ ] Build-related changes
- [ ] Other, please describe:

**Does this PR introduce a breaking change?** (check one)

- [ ] Yes
- [x] No


**The PR fulfills these requirements:**

- [x] It's submitted to the `dev` branch for v2.x (or to a previous version branch), _not_ the `master` branch
- [x] When resolving a specific issue, it's referenced in the PR's title (e.g. `fix #xxx[,#xxx]`, where "xxx" is the issue number)
- [x] All tests are passing: https://github.com/vuejs/vue/blob/dev/.github/CONTRIBUTING.md#development-setup
- [x] New/updated tests are included

**Description:**

Hi, 
When interpolating an object, it uses the JSON.stringify method instead of toString, which is normally the proper method to set a way to convert an object to a string. 
This PR allow you to use your custom `toString` method to render your object if it exists. It's tested (I've also added a test for toJson), and it should not be a breaking change.

Thanks you for your amazing work folks, and see you in Paris next month!
comments:
I'm adding some example of the problem to make me understood better:

[![Edit Vue Template](https://codesandbox.io/static/img/play-codesandbox.svg)](https://codesandbox.io/s/0plonqx6jp)

@posva:

I can confirm that your (so used!) `Object.create(null)` example works exactly the same than before (like arrays), as it's not a "plain object" (`_toString(Object.create(null))` gives `[object Undefined]`).

And to write here what I told you yesterday, it _could_ be a BC for those who had a object with a `toString` method implemented and still want to use the `toJson`  in templates. I think we can easily consider that this is not a standard case. üòÖ

See you! üëã
comments_review: I think this function can really use early returns now.As you want, I kept the original style to make as few changes as possible and let the diff easier to read, but it'll be easy to refactor.

comments_review:
Should we do the same thing when we come across properties prefixed with `_`?that's true, I thought there is an eslint warning for it. Let me check againI added that as well but I wonder if it is correct. I'm not sure what _babel helpers_ are we talking about in 8e1478e3Why not proxying both? I changed all mixins in a big project to respect this rule on Style Guide (https://vuejs.org/v2/style-guide/#Private-property-names-essential) and now when I am trying to pass it to a component prop it gets there undefined because it is not being proxiedto prevent conflicts. We cannot check all existing properties (which would be ideal), for conflicts, so we test that instead.
Nowadays, if you want to create plugins that inject custom properties, using Symbols is probably the safest wayYet the style guide recommends it, I think this issue should be given some thought, either change the rule for private property names or proxy everything, (maybe giving a warning in development process). Not proxying this is removing functionality and forcing developers that follow the recommended style guide find workarounds because of limited functionality to prevent others who may not read the documentation and override vue properties.Does it have to be some property starting with preserved prefixes here? It feels a little weird to me that after these checks we concluded that the property starts with `_` or `$`.Something like `warnPreservedPrefix`?if the key is in `$data` it is not proxified, then it can only be starting with those 2 characters. That's what I was thinkingProxying properties starting with $_ would be an optionThese two expects are identical, is that accidental?

fixes #8191 Silly me.  I assumed that since vue was preliminary a Javascript project, it wouldn't have the typescript toolchain installed, and therefore wouldn't be able to test the types.  I'll add a test for this to `yarn test:types`.@ktsn  @LinusBorg Is this a public API ? I checked the doc here https://vuejs.org/v2/api/#render and here https://vuejs.org/v2/api/#render. But it seems nowhere mentions multiple root.The most official source I've seen on the topic has been a core team member here suggesting it as an option at https://github.com/vuejs/vue/issues/7088#issuecomment-345855657

Given that articles like https://zendev.com/2018/05/07/multi-root-vue-components.html are starting to pop up, it probably ought to be added to https://vuejs.org/v2/guide/render-function.html#Functional-Components.  I'm surprised it wasn't already.@HerringtonDarkholme It's definitely official API. It's one of the reasons functional components were created in the first place.

But looking at the current documentation, it's not mentioned (anymore?) 

/cc @chrisvfritz Oh, I thought I did mention it. I'll add it. üëçis there anything holding  this up?poking this again, is there anything else I need to do to get this merged?Please be patient, we are currently wrapping up work on other core projects and will return attention back to the core repository shortly. No worries.  Thanks for the update :-)

body:

- [ ] Yes

If yes, please describe the impact and migration path for existing applications:

**The PR fulfills these requirements:**

- [x] It's submitted to the `dev` branch for v2.x (or to a previous version branch), _not_ the `master` branch
- [ ] When resolving a specific issue, it's referenced in the PR's title (e.g. `fix #xxx[,#xxx]`, where "xxx" is the issue number)
- [x] All tests are passing: https://github.com/vuejs/vue/blob/dev/.github/CONTRIBUTING.md#development-setup
- [x] New/updated tests are included

If adding a **new feature**, the PR's description includes:
- [x] A convincing reason for adding this feature (to avoid wasting your time, it's best to open a suggestion issue first and wait for approval before working on it)

**Other information:**

Adds support for iterable object implementing [Symbol.iterator]()
It shouldn't have an impact for existing code because non iterable objects are not impacted.
Vue will have the same behaviour than a for...of expression for iterables. (actual interest for using iterables)
Allows us to pass an iterable directly to a template without giving internal properties or converting it to an array


I wrote 4 new tests. No existing tests needed changes.
All tests passed. I ran tests with PhantomJS (lack of Symbol support), Firefox and Chrome.
comments:
note: git conflict with #7171Related: #5893So I have been using the following for a while now: https://github.com/vuejs/vue/blob/cb062c50cdd21628dcf758fe54c84d17d75cb2ca/src/core/instance/render-helpers/render-list.js

But I thought that in #5893 it is said that this will not go into core for now?> But I thought that in #5893 it is said that this will not go into core for now?

I'm aware of this but I think if you choose to implement [Symbol.iterator] you choose to break old browsers compatibility. This way your iterable object has the same behaviour in Vue than in other parts of your code.
What do you think ?
I personally like it, I was all for #5893.

title: perf(Dep.js): Dep now uses an object to handle subscriptions
body:
<!--
Please make sure to read the Pull Request Guidelines:
https://github.com/vuejs/vue/blob/dev/.github/CONTRIBUTING.md#pull-request-guidelines
-->

<!-- PULL REQUEST TEMPLATE -->
<!-- (Update "[ ]" to "[x]" to check a box) -->

**What kind of change does this PR introduce?** (check at least one)

- [ ] Bugfix
- [ ] Feature
- [ ] Code style update
- [ ] Refactor
- [ ] Build-related changes
- [x] Other, please describe: Performance increase

**Does this PR introduce a breaking change?** (check one)

- [ ] Yes
- [x] No

If yes, please describe the impact and migration path for existing applications:

**The PR fulfills these requirements:**

- [x] It's submitted to the `dev` branch for v2.x (or to a previous version branch), _not_ the `master` branch
- [x] When resolving a specific issue, it's referenced in the PR's title (e.g. `fix #xxx[,#xxx]`, where "xxx" is the issue number)
- [x] All tests are passing: https://github.com/vuejs/vue/blob/dev/.github/CONTRIBUTING.md#development-setup
- [x] New/updated tests are included

If adding a **new feature**, the PR's description includes:
- [x] A convincing reason for adding this feature (to avoid wasting your time, it's best to open a suggestion issue first and wait for approval before working on it)

**Other information:**
Tearing down a big set of Vue elements (table rows) with lot of reactive dependencies, was very slow due to array [traversing](https://forum.vuejs.org/t/destroying-a-component-with-many-children/23533). Using an object sped up the whole process. Page 170 rows from 8s to 1sec and 800rows with less reactive data from 6sec to 2.5~sec. This could be observed best while navigating between routes.
comments_review:
this line will be costly on an object with many keys. Probably better to just use a `for...in`.Since I've gone down the rabbit hole of performance testing, here are some iteration tests.
http://jsben.ch/3s22e - and the winner is `Object.keys()` with a negative while loop, faster by 7% to a `keys -> map -> loop` solution.Funny thing though, using object literal instead of `Object.create(null)` makes the values -> forEach version faster almost by 200ms ü§î @yyx990803 Any more thoughts on this? So I could go ahead and refactor the iteration and finish it up.

author: kball
title: fix #8041: templates inside v-pre should be rendered to HTML
body:
close #8041

<!--
Please make sure to read the Pull Request Guidelines:
https://github.com/vuejs/vue/blob/dev/.github/CONTRIBUTING.md#pull-request-guidelines
-->

<!-- PULL REQUEST TEMPLATE -->
<!-- (Update "[ ]" to "[x]" to check a box) -->

**What kind of change does this PR introduce?** (check at least one)

- [x] Bugfix
- [ ] Feature
- [ ] Code style update
- [ ] Refactor
- [ ] Build-related changes
- [ ] Other, please describe:

**Does this PR introduce a breaking change?** (check one)

- [ ] Yes
- [x] No

If yes, please describe the impact and migration path for existing applications:

I don't believe this is breaking as content inside of `v-pre` is considered to be static. _However_ it does change the outputted static content in the case where a `<template>` tag is labeled with `v-pre` or inside of a `v-pre` element.

**The PR fulfills these requirements:**

- [x] It's submitted to the `dev` branch for v2.x (or to a previous version branch), _not_ the `master` branch
- [x] When resolving a specific issue, it's referenced in the PR's title (e.g. `fix #xxx[,#xxx]`, where "xxx" is the issue number)
- [x] All tests are passing: https://github.com/vuejs/vue/blob/dev/.github/CONTRIBUTING.md#development-setup
- [x] New/updated tests are included

If adding a **new feature**, the PR's description includes:
- [ ] A convincing reason for adding this feature (to avoid wasting your time, it's best to open a suggestion issue first and wait for approval before working on it)

**Other information:**

I pushed a 'compiled' version of this to a different branch to show the working behavior on jsFiddle. The original fiddle from issue #8041: https://jsfiddle.net/zct418xa/1/
A fiddle with the updated behavior using vue.js compiled from this change: https://jsfiddle.net/f7nv9218/
comments:
Any feedback on this PR? No pressure as I know how hard it is as a maintainer - I'm just excited to learn more about the Vue codebase and tackling issues is the best way I know to do that.

Will happily take feedback on approach, style, or anything else.

title: fix: In development mode, warns if user tries to Vue.set a property t‚Ä¶
body:
‚Ä¶hat already exists.

In development mode, warns if user tries to Vue.set a property that already exists. Issue reported
in #8129. Codepen demonstrating the issue available at
https://codepen.io/chrisvfritz/pen/rvzgBR?editors=1010

fix #8129

comments:
@posva I'm trying to add a test for this, but struggling a bit.  Here is a codepen of a test that I expect should pass for this.  https://codepen.io/bigtunacan/pen/rvGgoB?editors=0010#
> I'm trying to add a test for this, but struggling a bit.

Could you provide more information on where you struggled? For example, are you not sure where the test should go, or did running the tests not work, etc?@chrisvfritz I placed the test in `test/unit/modules/observer/observer.spec.js`.

The test fails with the generic message `FAILED Observer Cannot enable reactivity on a property that is already defined`

So then I ran the tests against Chrome with inspector to see what is happening; the warning is getting hit in test the same as in dev, but yet it fails in my test (which I also linked in the codepen above).

I could also push my changes onto this pull request, but I didn't necessarily want to do that when I know the test isn't working yet.@bigtunacan You may have to wrap your expectation with `waitForUpdate` (like in [this test](https://github.com/vuejs/vue/blob/dev/test/unit/modules/observer/observer.spec.js#L307-L311)).@chrisvfritz I tried that as well, with the same results.

https://codepen.io/bigtunacan/pen/RyxbLa?editors=0010#Can you upload the exact code you're trying? It's OK if the test is failing - we'll squash when we merge anyway.@chrisvfritz Ok; I've updated the PR@posva I believe this should be ready to merge now.@posva Just curious since it's been sitting for awhile and shows as "Changes requested".  Are you still waiting on anything from me to merge this in?  I thought everything was good now?
comments_review: I think this should be `then` rather than `end`.I've tried that as well, but the result is the same.A Vue instance must have a template prop or render fn, your test is throwing an error before getting to the checks@dhensche Thanks; that was it.

author: brophdawg11
title: fix(SSR): Properly handle newlines and whitespace in SSR classnames (fix #7859)
body:
When encountering newlines in SSR classnames, do not render "\n" and
instead replace the new line with a space.

Once newlines are removed, indentation from subsequent lines can leave
classnames abnormally spaced out, so replace multiple spaces with a
single space

fix #7859

body:

If adding a **new feature**, the PR's description includes:

**Other information:**
When we run our test suite with relatively new ( >beta13 ) on vue-test-utils we end up with this issue failing a portion of our test suite as it appears somehow that `componentInstance` is undefined by the time this hook gets called.

I spent about an hour trying to find where to put a test where the destroy hook gets called, but couldn't figure out how to test it properly.  I even attempted to find a good spot by having that function `throw`, but even that wasn't very helpful, so I'd love some help with that.

I'm also happy to help with code there, or whatever, but I could use some guidance since there is a lot of complexity going on around this area of the code, the stack trace we got was:

      at VueComponent.Vue.$forceUpdate (node_modules/vue/dist/vue.runtime.common.js:2689:19)
      at updateChildComponent (node_modules/vue/dist/vue.runtime.common.js:2863:8)
      at prepatch (node_modules/vue/dist/vue.runtime.common.js:4142:5)
      at patchVnode (node_modules/vue/dist/vue.runtime.common.js:5923:7)
      at updateChildren (node_modules/vue/dist/vue.runtime.common.js:5820:9)

It is better to replace the whole expression with a single template literal, IMHO.Multi-line template string will introduce unnecessary whitespaces, unless we adopt a weird code style that has no leading space in template string literals...Hmmm‚Ä¶ My bad. Thought that was acceptable coding style (compared to mix usage of `'` & `` ` ``). Didn't check with existing codebase‚Ä¶

Not sure about the flow type error. 
ExtendedVue should contain the methods too. I added it in the second commit, but still not showing up@posva 
https://github.com/vuejs/vue/pull/8096 shows what is wrong with current state of repo
I have added that into this PR as per you said`this` type annotation is intentionally omitted because it will be inferred by `ThisType`. `beforeCreate` has it because it does not have user defined date / methods at that moment. @ktsn why does #8096 fail then ? It should fail because you cannot use methods in `beforeCreate`.
https://jsfiddle.net/uxbcb0q7/Okay I understand now. Thanks @ktsn

author: utatti
title: feat(warn): Warn component names hyphenated into reserved names, fix #8025
body:
Currently, component names like 'Map' is silently ignored, because they translated into reserved names but the component names are not exactly the same as the reserved names. The component names, thus, should be hyphenated before checking if reserved.

Resolve #8025.

<!--
Please make sure to read the Pull Request Guidelines:
https://github.com/vuejs/vue/blob/dev/.github/CONTRIBUTING.md#pull-request-guidelines
-->

<!-- PULL REQUEST TEMPLATE -->
<!-- (Update "[ ]" to "[x]" to check a box) -->

**What kind of change does this PR introduce?** (check at least one)

- [ ] Bugfix
- [x] Feature
- [ ] Code style update
- [ ] Refactor
- [ ] Build-related changes
- [ ] Other, please describe:

**Does this PR introduce a breaking change?** (check one)

- [ ] Yes
- [x] No

If yes, please describe the impact and migration path for existing applications:

**The PR fulfills these requirements:**

- [x] It's submitted to the `dev` branch for v2.x (or to a previous version branch), _not_ the `master` branch
- [x] When resolving a specific issue, it's referenced in the PR's title (e.g. `fix #xxx[,#xxx]`, where "xxx" is the issue number)
- [x] All tests are passing: https://github.com/vuejs/vue/blob/dev/.github/CONTRIBUTING.md#development-setup
- [x] New/updated tests are included

If adding a **new feature**, the PR's description includes:
- [x] A convincing reason for adding this feature (to avoid wasting your time, it's best to open a suggestion issue first and wait for approval before working on it)

**Other information:**

The reason of using `hyphenate()` instead of `.toLowerCase()` is that we should allow a name like `MaP`, as it is shown as `ma-p` in template and thus a valid component name.
comments:
Vue community has at least one popular library that uses `Input` or `Select` as component name. Say https://github.com/vuejs/vetur/issues/303 and https://github.com/vuejs/eslint-plugin-vue/issues/181 . 

I don't know if it will be an annoying warning.  cc @icarusionDidn‚Äôt know that these child components actually work when we use the capitalized name as it is. But I think it‚Äôs really ambiguous, because, as described in #8025, we are sometimes not sure if a name is reserved and should be used in case-sensitive way. I think it‚Äôs generally good to warn users when they‚Äôre using CamelCased reserved names.

body:

- [x] All tests are passing: https://github.com/vuejs/vue/blob/dev/.github/CONTRIBUTING.md#development-setup
- [x] New/updated tests are included
comments:
Is this really needed or something just more like over-engineering?For me it's good approach to create `isString` like methods. It increases readability of code.

There are methods like `isTrue`, `isFalse`, `isObject` in `shared/util`, so why don't create similar for `isString` ?

Please also take a look here:
https://github.com/vuejs/vue/blob/f7b5c86ef2620c1d7ec275f86ae0f380ccaea4ef/src/platforms/web/util/class.js#L37-L39
Mixing different levels of abstraction (`isObject` near `typeof value === 'string'`) is not a good practice.

As said lusarz, there is methods like isTrue|isFalse|isObject|isPrimitive, so i dont see over-engineering here
comments_review: What do you think about `return isString(value) ? transformSpecialNewlines(value) : JSON.stringify(value)` notation ?

author: fenduru
title: fix(slots): preserve reactivity inside of $slots, fix #7856
body:
Previously $slots was not reactive which caused use cases such as
portal-vue to not update when the contents of the slots updated. This
was because there were no reactive properties accessed when using $slots
and renders were only being triggered by calls to $forceUpdate when slot
contents changed.

This change makes $slots reactive, so updates are detected appropriately
regardless of where the slot is used.

fixes #7856

<!--
Please make sure to read the Pull Request Guidelines:
https://github.com/vuejs/vue/blob/dev/.github/CONTRIBUTING.md#pull-request-guidelines

comments: @yyx990803 can this be merged?For me create reactive $slots property, it is not solution issue(in that case of course it is one of the solution), but slots it is not like reactive variable, with watches and observer, it is another type.This seems to be unrelated to the original issue discussed in #7856. Also, the added test case is not really a use case I think we should be encouraging. I'd rather implement proper portal support in core instead of relying on such usage.
