I guess the `decode` is done by intention. Note compiler is shared across ssr, client side template and vue-loader, I wonder if decode is necessary under different situation. However, I'm not familiar enough to give confident answer.

Would you mind digging deeper for this? Thanks!Thanks for the PR, but the decode in the parser is necessary for correct client-side behavior. The bug was actually introduced by the SSR optimizing compiler in 2.4 and a proper fix is provided in 172dbf9f

author: sunyatasattva
title: Uses reactive set to change a synced property
body:
**What kind of change does this PR introduce?** (check at least one)

- [ ] Bugfix
- [ ] Feature
- [ ] Code style update
- [ ] Refactor
- [ ] Build-related changes
- [x] Other, please describe:

Small improvement

**Does this PR introduce a breaking change?** (check one)

- [ ] Yes
- [x] No

If yes, please describe the impact and migration path for existing applications:

**The PR fulfills these requirements:**

- [x] It's submitted to the `dev` branch for v2.x (or to a previous version branch), _not_ the `master` branch
- [x] When resolving a specific issue, it's referenced in the PR's title (e.g. `fix #xxx[,#xxx]`, where "xxx" is the issue number)
- [ ] All tests are passing: https://github.com/vuejs/vue/blob/dev/.github/CONTRIBUTING.md#development-setup
- [ ] New/updated tests are included

**Other information:**

I'm using the reactive setter to set a property with the `sync` modifier. My case is that since the `sync` modifier is basically just syntactic sugar to avoid some boilerplate, it is useful for most case to set a property through `Vue.set`.

I might be wrong, but instead of opening an issue I thought doing a pull request would be faster, since the change is just a line of code.
comments:
Hello thanks for your PR but using `Vue.set` has an extra cost because it forces Vue to add watchers whereas doing a plain assignment don't. This is intentional, remember every reactive property should be declared in `data`Hey! Thanks for answering. I was just wondering if basically anything with `.sync` isn't practically expected to be reactive, and that would save some boilerplate.

But if you disagree, feel free to close of course :)Sync is for two way binding. You shouldn't do Vue. Set everyone to se something, it's for Vey specific cases. Look for caveat in the documentation. That would hopefully clarify many things This seems unnecessary to me, since the event listener would only be created if the key already exists in that object. This would only apply when the key exists and is not already reactive, which sounds like quite an unlikely case for `v-bind` object. Closing but feel free to provide a use case where this would prove necessary.

title: Support ES proposals in vue template expressions, fix #6307
body:
<!--

-->

<!-- PULL REQUEST TEMPLATE -->
<!-- (Update "[ ]" to "[x]" to check a box) -->

- [ ] Build-related changes
- [ ] Other, please describe:

**Does this PR introduce a breaking change?** (check one)

If yes, please describe the impact and migration path for existing applications:

**The PR fulfills these requirements:**

- [x] It's submitted to the `dev` branch for v2.x (or to a previous version branch), _not_ the `master` branch
- [x] When resolving a specific issue, it's referenced in the PR's title (e.g. `fix #xxx[,#xxx]`, where "xxx" is the issue number)

- [ ] New/updated tests are included

If adding a **new feature**, the PR's description includes:
- [x] A convincing reason for adding this feature (to avoid wasting your time, it's best to open a suggestion issue first and wait for approval before working on it)

**Other information:**
A lot of people ask specifically about object spread support in vue templates but it's limited to environment where compilation is happening. Since most of the time people are using babel which uses babylon as parser, we can use same parser for vue templates if available. Discussion: #6307.

Tests are not included because tests are runnnig in `PhantomJS` where `require()` is not available. Tested locally.
comments:
Note compiler is also used in browser. So requiring babylon doesn't run at all.

If this change only applies in nodejs environment, can we just apply change in vue-loader?@HerringtonDarkholme, I am not familiar with `vue-loader` codebase. Is there a way to override expression validation only in it? If yes I think that's a better solution.I think that is doable, compiler has a `module` option to modify ast. We can transpile expression there.@HerringtonDarkholme, I don't think we want to transpile expressions, that should be handled by webpack, the only thing that affects usage of things like spread in vue expressions is the expression validation, we should only make this validation pass. Adding another layer to transpile expressions from vue templates before passing the template to template compiler itself doesn't sound good IMHO.After further consideration, I still think porting expression checking logic to vue-loader is a better solution:

1, current PR maintains two parallel expression checking logic: one is babylon in vue compiler, the other is in [vue-template-compiler](https://github.com/vuejs/vue-template-es2015-compiler). Even passing vue compiler will still causing errors in vue-template-compiler because buble, the underlying transpiler for vue-loader, does not recognize features like optional chaining and numeric separator.

2. transpiling ESNext expression can be legitimate compiler plugin's work, if viewed as [strength reduction](https://www.wikiwand.com/en/Strength_reduction), that is, we reduce stronger ESNext expression to weaker ES5 expression. Indeed, compilers do have multiple transformation phase since long ago.


3. If purity does need to be kept, we can introduce a new flag like `needCheck` to skip checking in core compiler. All vue loader needs to do is checking expression before and set `needCheck` to false.

4. Core compiler is shared between node building and browsers. We cannot cram too much logic like resolving babelrc in core compiler.

5. Ideologically, a require statement in `try { } catch(e) {}` reminds me of conditional macro in C/CPP. It is targeted only for nodejs. Platform specific code in core code looks quite smelly to me. Especially we can check it via `module`.@HerringtonDarkholme, Yeah, agree, transpiling expressions in `vue-loader` sounds better, still need to figure out a wayt to do that.
comments_review:
I haven't used `babylon` before, so these may not be the most intelligent questions - I apologize in advance. üòÖ  

- Where do these plugins come from? Are we relying on them being installed by the user? What if one of them isn't?
- Would it be possible to read from a user's `.babelrc` file, if it exists, then simply skip this step if there is none? I worry about having two separate combinations of Babel features, one of which it may _seem_ the user is in control of, but really isn't.@chrisvfritz, plugins are a part of `babylon` and are bundled with it.

Looking for `.babelrc` synchronously in the directory tree would be very expensive and blocking. Specially if we consider that sometimes you need to go a lot of directories up to find the `.babelrc`, and we cannot do that asynchronously :(And reading from `.babelrc` and tracking down `babylon` plugins from it can be pretty hard too, I think that adds a lot of complexity, we can add optional `BABYLON_PLUGINS` env variable support, something like: 
```
> BABYLON_PLUGINS=objectRestSpread,numericSeparator npm run dev
```
What do you think?@nickmessing Hmm, I don't have any ideas either for easily mapping Babel configs to babylon plugins, making the feasability of reading from `.babelrc` kind of moot anyway. üòï  Having taken a closer look at babylon now, I agree with the subset of plugins you've chosen to include and I didn't realize before that it supported ES2017 out-of-the-box. üëç @nickmessing Regarding the environment variable, I think it'd just be good to include any plugins that could possibly be needed in a template expression - which I think you've already done. I think it's better to allow _too much_ than too little here. If they're using a syntax that _really_ isn't supported by the user's own Babel config, they'll still see an error, just a syntax error as they would (probably) expect, rather than an invalid template error.

author: chrisvfritz
title: Allow v-bind="$attrs" with v-on="$listeners" to work with v-model
body:
<!--
Please make sure to read the Pull Request Guidelines:
https://github.com/vuejs/vue/blob/dev/.github/CONTRIBUTING.md#pull-request-guidelines
-->

<!-- PULL REQUEST TEMPLATE -->
<!-- (Update "[ ]" to "[x]" to check a box) -->

**What kind of change does this PR introduce?** (check at least one)

- [x] Bugfix?
- [x] Feature

**Does this PR introduce a breaking change?** (check one)

- [x] No, unless someone was using `v-model` to purposefully bind an element's value directly to a DOM Event, which I think would be strange.

If adding a **new feature**, the PR's description includes:

- [x] A convincing reason for adding this feature (to avoid wasting your time, it's best to open a suggestion issue first and wait for approval before working on it)

I brought this up in #6216 a couple weeks ago and it didn't encounter any opposition, so here we go! 

__TLDR__: Since `v-bind="$attrs"` and `v-on="$listeners"` were added, a lot of people have been assuming that combining these should be sufficient to allow `v-model` on the component. This PR makes `v-model` work as users expect.
comments:
I just noticed some Weex tests are failing. I could easily make them pass, but due to the nature of the tests and my own lack of experience with Weex, I'm not confident this would actually guarantee working behavior. 

@Jinjiang Would you mind taking a look? Is it safe to update the tests, or is it possible my changes would break Weex?Seems `$event.target.value` will break weex, browser-based code shouldn't exist in cross-platform part.@javoski Are you sure this would break Weex? I only try to access `$event.target.value` if the `$event` is an object and `$event.type === 'input'`. In cases where a DOM Event (or something resembling a DOM Event) isn't attached to the component event (which I think should always be the case in native environments), Weex would not see changed behavior.@chrisvfritz sorry it's still loading status in "$ bash build/ci.sh" part of the ci report (maybe my network problem). I will have a look in the deep. Just a moment please :-)@chrisvfritz This commit is fine. Currently you can just skip these failed test cases in weex. And @Hanks10100 and I will fix them later.
Thanks.@chrisvfritz After I confirmed that this feature will not destroy weex, I will modify those failed test cases and add the corresponding case in Weex.@chrisvfritz  I fixed the test case in Weex and send a PR (https://github.com/chrisvfritz/vue/pull/1) to your branch. The CI is passed.

Your modification didn't break Weex, but not consider the difference of it.

As I write in that PR:

> In Weex, the structure of the `<input>` element has a slight difference with Web, it doesn't have the `value` property but has `attr.value`.Can this be merged? It would be a great help for wrapping inputs!See https://github.com/vuejs/vue/issues/6216#issuecomment-333648093Yeah, I agree it felt a little hacky and certainly didn't cover every use case. Part of me was hoping you'd think of some small refactor that would simplify things, but we weren't lucky this time. üôÇ

comments_review:
Should we do `^update:([\w.$]+[^.])\.([\w$]+)$` to prevent things like `update:foo..bar`hmm, nvm, it doesn't seem to be necessary@javoski  `update:.foo.bar` would still pass through the regex and produce the same matching length

isn't it undesirable, since you're getting the first split chunk? removing the first dot from your expression would deal with this

`^update:([\w$]+)\.([\w$]+)$`@jpsouzasilva Thanks for pointing this out, actually the event `'update:.foo.bar'` will not get into the Regex validation process unless there is an event named `'update:'` exists in the instance. However, we can modify the regex to `/^update:([\w$][\w.$]+)\.([\w$]+)$/` to make it more robust.

author: gebilaoxiong
title: chore(runtime): correctly render the embed attribute allowfullscreen
body:
#6202

<!--
Please make sure to read the Pull Request Guidelines:
https://github.com/vuejs/vue/blob/dev/.github/CONTRIBUTING.md#pull-request-guidelines
-->

<!-- PULL REQUEST TEMPLATE -->

- [ ] Refactor

correctly render the embed attribute allowfullscreen

**Does this PR introduce a breaking change?** (check one)

- [ ] Yes
- [x] No

If yes, please describe the impact and migration path for existing applications:

**The PR fulfills these requirements:**

- [x] It's submitted to the `dev` branch for v2.x (or to a previous version branch), _not_ the `master` branch
- [ ] When resolving a specific issue, it's referenced in the PR's title (e.g. `fix #xxx[,#xxx]`, where "xxx" is the issue number)
- [x] All tests are passing: https://github.com/vuejs/vue/blob/dev/.github/CONTRIBUTING.md#development-setup
- [ ] New/updated tests are included

If adding a **new feature**, the PR's description includes:
- [ ] A convincing reason for adding this feature (to avoid wasting your time, it's best to open a suggestion issue first and wait for approval before working on it)

**Other information:**
comments:
FYI, `allowfullscreen` is indeed a [Boolean attribute](https://html.spec.whatwg.org/multipage/iframe-embed-object.html#attr-iframe-allowfullscreen) and in the spec it can only be used on `<iframe>`. Changing it to enumerable would break its usage on `<iframe>`.

Flash's usage of `allowfullscreen` on `<embed>` is technically not spec compliant. However, this usage seems to be widely adopted so I added a special case in https://github.com/vuejs/vue/commit/d77b95317cedae299605fb692e2c7c67796b17cb .

title: fix #4223, add interpolation config.
body:
**What kind of change does this PR introduce?** (check at least one)

If adding a **new feature**, the PR's description includes:

**Other information:**

Sorry for create pr before approval...

This PR perfectly fix #4223.

Usage
```javascript
Vue.config.interpolation = false // default is true.
```

Best regards,
comments:
Hi @alfa-jpn, thanks for your contribution.

However, there is no silver bullet for server side vue template, especially when users want to mix user generated content with programmer's template. IMHO, Vue's users can and should think over how to separate UGC and template.

On the other hand, Vue's API is already large enough. `Vue.config.interpolation` can be easily replaced by `v-pre` that already exists. Users can even provide non-matching regex to mock this pull request. 

While we thank your contribution, we might still keep our API surface not too large. (Vue's API is already not as small as it used to be). For more reasoning, please see https://github.com/vuejs/vue/issues/6004#issuecomment-312404196.@HerringtonDarkholme 
Tanks for reply.

I see.
I also agree with a policy of minimum API.

But, the non-matching regex is weak to version up, because it's implemented by a mocking replace method of string.
(please see https://github.com/vuejs/vue/issues/4223#issuecomment-272113467 about `v-pre` )

So, I created plugin.
https://github.com/alfa-jpn/vue-disable-interpolation

author: jkzing
title: fix #6093, inject should not be merged with Object.create
body:
<!--
Please make sure to read the Pull Request Guidelines:
https://github.com/vuejs/vue/blob/dev/.github/CONTRIBUTING.md#pull-request-guidelines
-->

<!-- PULL REQUEST TEMPLATE -->
<!-- (Update "[ ]" to "[x]" to check a box) -->

**What kind of change does this PR introduce?** (check at least one)

- [x] Bugfix
- [ ] Feature
- [ ] Code style update
- [ ] Refactor
- [ ] Build-related changes
- [ ] Other, please describe:

**Does this PR introduce a breaking change?** (check one)

- [ ] Yes
- [x] No

If yes, please describe the impact and migration path for existing applications:

**The PR fulfills these requirements:**

- [x] It's submitted to the `dev` branch for v2.x (or to a previous version branch), _not_ the `master` branch
- [ x When resolving a specific issue, it's referenced in the PR's title (e.g. `fix #xxx[,#xxx]`, where "xxx" is the issue number)
- [x] All tests are passing: https://github.com/vuejs/vue/blob/dev/.github/CONTRIBUTING.md#development-setup
- [x] New/updated tests are included

If adding a **new feature**, the PR's description includes:
- [ ] A convincing reason for adding this feature (to avoid wasting your time, it's best to open a suggestion issue first and wait for approval before working on it)

**Other information:**
fix [https://github.com/vuejs/vue/issues/6093](https://github.com/vuejs/vue/issues/6093)

`Object.create` is not adding 'own property' to the object, which caused injections not injected properly.üò≠
comments:
Thanks for the PR.
Actually there's no need to add another merge strategy function, it's an issue about using `Object.keys()` to iterate inject object while using `for...in` on other options. (`Object.keys()` will not enumerates properties in the prototype chain, but `for...in` does). 
See [https://github.com/vuejs/vue/blob/dev/src/core/instance/inject.js#L21](https://github.com/vuejs/vue/blob/dev/src/core/instance/inject.js#L21)

So my suggestion is:
```js
strats.props =
strats.methods =
strats.inject =
strats.computed = function (parentVal: ?Object, childVal: ?Object): ?Object {
  if (!parentVal) return childVal
  const ret = Object.create(null)
  extend(ret, parentVal)
  if (childVal) extend(ret, childVal)
  return ret
}
```

```js
// Just delete this line will fix that issue :
if (!childVal) return Object.create(parentVal || null)
```@javoski You are right, I did think about that too. But I just didn't have the confident to remove that line directly. (I was afraid it's using `Object.create` for a reason)

Anyway, If it works totally OK without `Object.create`, it's better to merge your PR, and feel free to close this one when merging it.Thanks, #6093 seems to be a simpler fix.

author: heug
title: ci(CircleCI Config): Migrate to CircleCI 2.0 with workflows
body:
<!--
Please make sure to read the Pull Request Guidelines:
https://github.com/vuejs/vue/blob/dev/.github/CONTRIBUTING.md#pull-request-guidelines
-->

<!-- PULL REQUEST TEMPLATE -->
<!-- (Update "[ ]" to "[x]" to check a box) -->

**What kind of change does this PR introduce?** (check at least one)

- [ ] Bugfix
- [ ] Feature
- [ ] Code style update
- [ ] Refactor
- [ ] Build-related changes
- [x] Other, please describe: CI Improvement

**Does this PR introduce a breaking change?** (check one)

- [ ] Yes
- [x] No

If yes, please describe the impact and migration path for existing applications:

**The PR fulfills these requirements:**

- [x] It's submitted to the `dev` branch for v2.x (or to a previous version branch), _not_ the `master` branch
- [x] When resolving a specific issue, it's referenced in the PR's title (e.g. `fix #xxx[,#xxx]`, where "xxx" is the issue number)
- [x] All tests are passing: https://github.com/vuejs/vue/blob/dev/.github/CONTRIBUTING.md#development-setup
- [] New/updated tests are included

If adding a **new feature**, the PR's description includes:
- [ ] A convincing reason for adding this feature (to avoid wasting your time, it's best to open a suggestion issue first and wait for approval before working on it)

**Other information:**
CircleCI 2.0 allows for faster performance and reduced overall time to build and test by utilizing parallel testing via workflows. The codebase and dependencies are downloaded, cached, and are then used as part of a common workspace for the different components in `npm run test`, which have been split into four parallel containers.

Tests should complete in around 1m45s once the initial testing and caching has been done with CircleCI 2.0, compared to around 4m currently.
comments:
Thanks for PR, but why is the v2 config file so much more complex? What's the advantage of this over the current shell script?Hi, thanks for reviewing!

Circle's v2 provides much more customization over v1, and as such requires a lengthier configuration file. The v2 config file in the PR pulls the code, restores and updates the dependency cache, and provides this environment as a common workspace in separate containers for the different types of testing that were present in `npm run test`. The different tests run in parallel now instead of sequentially, cutting the time to build and test by almost half compared to the v1 config.Isn't there a simpler syntax for that. 130 lines of yml config looks like an overkill üò≠ 
edit: don't get me wrong, cutting the time of build by 50% is amazing, but people actually need to learn too much before being able to edit that fileUnfortunately no, I did the best I could by using references at the top of the yml to avoid repeating many of the lines. I'd be happy to go back in and comment all the things so people can follow along and contribute more easily in the future if that sounds good!Personally, I think this can save quite some time. Having comments do help.
As a CircleCI user, v2 looked super interesting but when I wanted to use it, I was overwhelmed by how complicated it was compared to v1 (can work with zero config). It's clear how powerful it is in complex projects. Having you writing a config for vue makes it much easier understand how it works üôÇ I played with this in the CI branch and indeed it greatly speeds up the build, but the base Node image in CircleCI 2 doesn't have java so the Selenium-based e2e tests cannot be run. If anyone wants to take this over and find a suitable docker image to use, contributions are welcome.@heug thanks again for the PR! We have enabled CircleCI 2 in https://github.com/vuejs/vue/pull/6627 :)

author: ai
title: test: test bundle size
body:
**What kind of change does this PR introduce?** (check at least one)

- [ ] Bugfix
- [ ] Feature
- [ ] Code style update
- [ ] Refactor
- [x] Build-related changes
- [ ] Other, please describe:

**Does this PR introduce a breaking change?** (check one)

- [ ] Yes
- [x] No

If yes, please describe the impact and migration path for existing applications:

**The PR fulfills these requirements:**

- [x] It's submitted to the `dev` branch for v2.x (or to a previous version branch), _not_ the `master` branch
- [ ] When resolving a specific issue, it's referenced in the PR's title (e.g. `fix #xxx[,#xxx]`, where "xxx" is the issue number)
- [x] All tests are passing: https://github.com/vuejs/vue/blob/dev/.github/CONTRIBUTING.md#development-setup
- [x] New/updated tests are included

If adding a **new feature**, the PR's description includes:
- [ ] A convincing reason for adding this feature (to avoid wasting your time, it's best to open a suggestion issue first and wait for approval before working on it)

**Other information:**

[size-limit](https://github.com/ai/size-limit) is a tool to show how many kilobytes your JS library increases the user bundle. You can set size budget and size-limit will prevent JavaScript libraries bloat on Travis CI.

It already used in Autoprefixer, PostCSS and JSS. For instance, I reduce Logux Client size 2x because I found some unexpected huge dependencies.

For Vue this tool can be useful to always know project size and prevent unexpected size regression.
comments:
Thanks for the pr Andrey üôÇ 
I'm not sure this is useful for Vue because it doesn't have any dependency and also because we use rollup for bundling. The tools looks interesting, really like the fact that you added a way to run the bundle analyzer

edit: The question I ask myself if it is going to break at least one. Otherwise it may not be worth the extra CI time (which I haven't checked)@posva yeap, tool is much effective in project with dependencies :D.

But even without dependencies some wrong `process` usage could increase bundle size for few KB.

Anyway, Vue is already small, so it is up to you, to lint bundle size or not :)@posva BTW, React is planning to add this kind of tool too https://github.com/facebook/react/pull/10090

But since you have no dependencies and already build-in file, maybe `bundlesize` by @siddharthkp will be better for you. It doesn‚Äôt run webpack, so results is not so accurate, but in other hand tool works faster.@ai I see, yeah, bundlesize may be useful since it checks a generated file but lets you generate it as you wantHey thanks for the PR @ai - in fact, Vue's build script already logs the size for every dist file when they are built, and we don't have any dependencies, so I believe an extra tool is unnecessary.

body:

- [x] When resolving a specific issue, it's referenced in the PR's title (e.g. `fix #xxx[,#xxx]`, where "xxx" is the issue number)
- [x] All tests are passing: https://github.com/vuejs/vue/blob/dev/.github/CONTRIBUTING.md#development-setup
- [x] New/updated tests are included
comments:
While the extra `<template scope="...">` is more verbose, it's also more obvious/explicit that it is a scoped slot. I intentionally only allowed it on `<template>` for this reason.

Also, just the presence of `scope` is ambiguous - e.g. you may want to bind a prop named `scope` on a component.I agree that we should make it more explicit.
Or maybe scoped slot on html element or component should be implemented through a more specific way, like ```v-scope``` or something else. 

BTW, the condition checking in [codegen - genScopedSlot()](https://github.com/vuejs/vue/blob/dev/src/compiler/codegen/index.js#L342) looks unnecessary if scoped slot is only allowed on ```<template>```

author: drewsmith
title: added Object key sort prior to JSON.stringify comparison (fix #5908)
body:
#5908

<!--
Please make sure to read the Pull Request Guidelines:
https://github.com/vuejs/vue/blob/dev/.github/CONTRIBUTING.md#pull-request-guidelines
-->

<!-- PULL REQUEST TEMPLATE -->
<!-- (Update "[ ]" to "[x]" to check a box) -->

**What kind of change does this PR introduce?** (check at least one)

- [ ] Bugfix
- [X] Feature
- [ ] Code style update
- [ ] Refactor
- [ ] Build-related changes
- [ ] Other, please describe: Improvement

**Does this PR introduce a breaking change?** (check one)

- [ ] Yes
- [X] No

If yes, please describe the impact and migration path for existing applications:

**The PR fulfills these requirements:**

- [X] It's submitted to the `dev` branch for v2.x (or to a previous version branch), _not_ the `master` branch
- [X] When resolving a specific issue, it's referenced in the PR's title (e.g. `fix #xxx[,#xxx]`, where "xxx" is the issue number)
- [X] All tests are passing: https://github.com/vuejs/vue/blob/dev/.github/CONTRIBUTING.md#development-setup
- [X] New/updated tests are included

If adding a **new feature**, the PR's description includes:
- [ ] A convincing reason for adding this feature (to avoid wasting your time, it's best to open a suggestion issue first and wait for approval before working on it)

**Other information:**
comments:
This maybe not working because AFAIK it's `JSON.stringify` that has no guarantee on the order of properties serialized by it. Will it be useful by sorting the keys before serializing? ü§îDefinitely a somewhat trivial edge case. There are two ways to ensure this AFAIK. This approach has some reusability or you can pass sorted keys to stringify ```JSON.stringify(obj, Object.keys(obj).sort())```@drewsmith Is this right approach?

If I compare key by key in two objects, it would take `O(N)` comparisons.
If I sort then compare stringified JSON, it would take `O(N logN)` comparisons + overhead of `stringify`.@znck Thanks for the comment. Are you referring to passing sorted keys to ```stringify``` or sorting altogether?

The _right_ approach is deep object equality IMO, which ```stringify``` is a low tech mechanism for doing so since it serializes the entire object including values. The fact the order is not deterministic requires some sort of explicit ordering or perhaps ```stringify``` should be replaced with something else altogether?I want to say, sorting the keys beats the purpose of `looseEqual`.

Also, `looseEqual` is used only in [model.js](https://github.com/vuejs/vue/blob/master/src/platforms/web/runtime/directives/model.js) for select options, I guess `stringify` serves the purpose there. @yyx990803 would know this better.I agree with you depending on semantics. Does loose mean implicit deep copy, or is it a synonym for shallow? ```stringify``` gets you a poor man's deep copy, but either way values need to be compared.Maybe check how [this package does it](https://www.npmjs.com/package/json-stable-stringify).Thanks for the PR - however, cloning with sorted keys results in extra memory allocation and it's better to just compare in place. See a8ac129
comments_review:
Either one should be `unsortedTestObj` here.If `obj` isn't `object`, this function always return an empty object which makes such call like `looseEqual(1, 2)` returning `true`.This only sorts the first level of an object. For nested object like `{nested: {a: 1, b: 2}}` and `{nested: {b:2, a:1}}`, it fails.

A recursive call should pay more attention to cyclic references.This function is only used in this file, consider not exporting it. Also, obj is annotated as `any` which in this case, `Object` is a better choice, if you perform no recursive call.This changes `looseEqual`'s original behavior.

comments:
There is a config variable, which you can set to turn it off.

https://vuejs.org/v2/api/#productionTip

ScottIt's fine to have the message, I just think it should be shorter :-)

BTW: I can't get the global config change to work. Where would I have to put that `Vue.config.productionTip = false;`? Just above my first `var app = new Vue({ ...`?Should work right after the import of Vue in `main.js` or above your `app` assignment.

ScottThis new message just tells you to visit a website while the other was explicit about the intention of the warning. I really prefer the old one@smolinari: I think something is wrong with this setting. When I load a page *for the first time*, I don't  get the tip in the console. But when I reload, I keep getting it. Does it work for you as expected?

@posva: I did keep the first sentence ("You are running Vue.js in development mode."), which tells you (more or less) everything that's really important. I deleted the second sentence ("Make sure to turn on production mode when deploying for production") which, well, is no new information after the first one...  
However, I don't really care about the exact wording. I'd just like to have it **in only one line** :-)
@ThomasLandauer yours does make sense.> Does it work for you as expected?

It sure does. 

ScottThanks for the PR, but I also think the old one is more explicit.

author: ghost
title: Allow white space when v-binding to an array or object (fix #4881)
body:
**What kind of change does this PR introduce?** (check at least one) - [ ] Bugfix - [ ] Feature - [ ] Code style update - [ ] Refactor - [ ] Build-related changes - [x] Other, please describe: Not really a _bug_ but prevents a compilation error when you have white space in array or object bindings which is a common way to write them. **Does this PR introduce a breaking change?** (check one) - [ ] Yes - [x] No If yes, please describe the impact and migration path for existing applications: **The PR fulfills these requirements:** - [x] It's submitted to the `dev` branch for v2.x (or to a previous version branch), _not_ the `master` branch - [x] When resolving a specific issue, it's referenced in the PR's title (e.g. `fix #xxx[,#xxx]`, where "xxx" is the issue number) - [x] All tests are passing: https://github.com/vuejs/vue/blob/dev/.github/CONTRIBUTING.md#development-setup - [x] New/updated tests are included If adding a **new feature**, the PR's description includes: - [ ] A convincing reason for adding this feature (to avoid wasting your time, it's best to open a suggestion issue first and wait for approval before working on it) **Other information:** When binding a value using array or object syntax, it is much more human readable and human writable to allow white space within it. This PR makes a change to the 5th capture group of the HTML parser regex to not break the match when a white space appears, thus allowing you to have spaces in your array/object syntax. For example, if you have a template like one of these: ```js template: `

{{message}}

`, //or template: `

{{message}}

` ``` The current parser will throw a template compilation error `- invalid expression: :class="[color,"`. [Here is a simple jsfiddle showing the issue](https://jsfiddle.net/jimrottinger/50wL7mdz/40869/). The changes in this PR correctly grabs the entire array or object, white spaces included.
comments: Hmm, I don't think this is a good idea - this makes the template invalid HTML, thus breaking compat with other HTML-based tooling. Thanks for the PR though!
comments_review: these lines were throwing `Expected indentation of 6 spaces but found 8 indent` when I tried to commit my changes.

author: DanielRosenwasser
title: Improve Vue type declarations for more canonical usage
body:
This PR improves the Vue `.d.ts` files so that users can get some improved inference when using the `noImplicitThis` compiler option. It takes advantage of many of the features the TypeScript team has been working on over the last few versions. Thus, it requires a minimum TypeScript version of 2.4. You can get this working with the current `typescript@next` (which is `2.5.0-dev.20170614`, but don't let that version number fool you - this will work with the final release of 2.4).

The best part about this change is that it makes using Vue easier when users choose not to use classes and inheritance. In other words, users and can more easily `new` up an instance using the Vue constructor, and can create components using the `Vue.extend` and `Vue.component` APIs a little more naturally. Extending Vue as a class will still work, so if you prefer to use vue-class-component and the rest, that should still work! However, those dependencies may need to be updated for this change.

There's definitely some amount of complexity that's been introduced but I'm willing to iterate on this with the help of others. Given the feedback that we've heard on [TypeScript-Vue-Starter](https://github.com/Microsoft/TypeScript-Vue-Starter), it's been a positive experience for users.

Fixes many of the issues users have asked about in #478.

Tests are probably failing at this point because I need to update the project's dependency on TypeScript.

author: lzxb
title: Feat:computed option support function type
comments:
Can you explain why (specific use case) would you need a function for the computed property?
The `computed` property of a component is kind of like the definition of the component. Making it a function allows it to be dynamic at runtimeI think I've seen this request before but I don't think we should support this.

Allowing computed properties to be dynamic makes the component's behavior more unpredictable and harder to properly type-check / be statically analyzed. This is not something we'd like to encourage.

On the other hand - this can already be achieved in userland inside the `beforeCreate` lifecycle hook. If you really need that, just do it in `beforeCreate`.Sure enough, it is possible

author: lzxb

comments:
I'm a bit concerned about the size increase vs. the use case. The use case seems to be very rare -
 and there isn't too much that can be done inside because the actual move is controlled completely by CSS.

The core lib (runtime only) is reaching 20kb and I think we really need to start carefully weigh every new feature against the amount of code it requires.

author: javoski
title: fix #5804: support object value for key attribute
body:
#5804

- [x] No
comments:
First, thanks for the PR and see https://github.com/vuejs/vue/issues/5804#issuecomment-305950427

Regarding the implementation - not sure if it's a good idea to pollute the observed objects like this. Ideally we should `Object.defineProperty` to make it non-enumerable. But this operation is quite expensive.

One way to work around this might be using native `Map` when it is available, and fallback to the "secret non-enumerable key" strategy used in this PR. However, I'd like to do some more performance benchmarking before actually adding the changes.Adding a warning should be a better idea before native map object can be take into consideration.
comments_review: Looks like a risk of memory leak hereüòÇ

It 's too late today and going to work tomorrow

I will fill the unit test in tomorrow ... 

sorry@Kingwl  

Now, I use a transition placeholder... 

can you help me to review it, thx : )Thanks @gebilaoxiong for the hard work. I found out a simpler fix in https://github.com/vuejs/vue/commit/c3cdfcfa68126783307d74fca22b136cd41c474a but your PR helped a lot in identifying the problem.@yyx990803

Thanks, your code is pretty@yyx990803 there is a small problem


https://github.com/vuejs/vue/commit/c3cdfcfa68126783307d74fca22b136cd41c474a#diff-6964744ffd2d3536df0f526fb0e2c286R142
``` javascript
child.key = child.key == null
  ? id + child.tag
  : isPrimitive(child.key)
    ? (String(child.key).indexOf(id) === 0 ? child.key : id + child.key)
    : child.key
```


if child is `async placeholder`(comment) and it did not have the `key`

then the child `key` is `__transition-1-undefined`

![84ffabb0-7036-4891-aec9-9034eb85580f](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/11804936/26789933/7cef9450-4a44-11e7-83f2-f0e59d07c492.png)

author: jkzing
title: Warn when keep-alive's child is not component
body:
<!--
Please make sure to read the Pull Request Guidelines:
https://github.com/vuejs/vue/blob/dev/.github/CONTRIBUTING.md#pull-request-guidelines
-->

<!-- PULL REQUEST TEMPLATE -->
<!-- (Update "[ ]" to "[x]" to check a box) -->

**What kind of change does this PR introduce?** (check at least one)

- [ ] Bugfix
- [x] Feature

- [ ] Refactor

If yes, please describe the impact and migration path for existing applications:

**The PR fulfills these requirements:**

- [x] It's submitted to the `dev` branch for v2.x (or to a previous version branch), _not_ the `master` branch
- [x] When resolving a specific issue, it's referenced in the PR's title (e.g. `fix #xxx[,#xxx]`, where "xxx" is the issue number)

If adding a **new feature**, the PR's description includes:
- [ ] A convincing reason for adding this feature (to avoid wasting your time, it's best to open a suggestion issue first and wait for approval before working on it)

**Other information:**
comments:
This is actually more tricky than it seems. The else branch could also be reached when `<keep-alive>` has no children (`v-if` with false conditions, `<component :is="null"/>`, etc.). So the check will fire in valid use cases as well.

I think the [docs](https://vuejs.org/v2/api/#keep-alive) is already explicit enough about the "component only case" and I think it's fine to not have this warning.

Thanks for the PR though.üòÖ

author: maggiehe
title: [bugfix] ignore comment type in array children.
body:
Here is a part of the template which will be rendered both in client-side and server-side: ```
``` In Vue 2.3.0, it was rendered to two VNodes: `[component, text]`, while the server-side only rendered the first node. The case will lead to this error: `The client-side rendered virtual DOM tree is not matching server-rendered content.` The problem is, by method `normalizeArrayChildren`, `[component, comment, comment]` will be processed into ` [component] -> [component, comment] -> [component, text]`. **What kind of change does this PR introduce?** (check at least one) - [x] Bugfix - [ ] Feature - [ ] Code style update - [ ] Refactor - [ ] Build-related changes - [ ] Other, please describe: **Does this PR introduce a breaking change?** (check one) - [ ] Yes - [x] No If yes, please describe the impact and migration path for existing applications: **The PR fulfills these requirements:** - [ ] It's submitted to the `dev` branch for v2.x (or to a previous version branch), _not_ the `master` branch - [ ] When resolving a specific issue, it's referenced in the PR's title (e.g. `fix #xxx[,#xxx]`, where "xxx" is the issue number) - [ ] All tests are passing: https://github.com/vuejs/vue/blob/dev/.github/CONTRIBUTING.md#development-setup - [ ] New/updated tests are included If adding a **new feature**, the PR's description includes: - [ ] A convincing reason for adding this feature (to avoid wasting your time, it's best to open a suggestion issue first and wait for approval before working on it) **Other information:**
comments: Sorry, this commit does not solve the problem, will launch a new one.

comments:
~Hey, the issue link is broken, can you get a working link please?~
https://github.com/vuejs/babel-plugin-transform-vue-jsx/issues/74The implementation looks good. 

It feels strange for me to inject `_context` to a `this`-less functional component, though.
https://vuejs.org/v2/guide/render-function.html#Functional-Components

@HerringtonDarkholme, I am not sure why but we do have a unique context for each functional component anyway, and this change won't break anything. I actually think that if we have to have a context why not have a common context shared between all functional components since it's going to be "empty". @yyx990803, can you please share your opinion on that?Hmm, indeed having `this` in a functional render fn feels weird. I think injecting this could be a bit surprising if users accidentally use it.

Since users have to use the `context` in most cases when using functional components, they have to provide `h` as the first argument anyway :/

Maybe instead - if the function name is `render` and have no arguments, we inject the `h` argument automatically?@yyx990803, I think that should be discussed in an issue in the babel-plugin-transform-jsx itself.I get the same issue
`Cannot read property '$createElement' of undefined`

for some reason, `render` is injected to the component@Gcaufy, can you please create an issue in vuejs/babel-plugin-transform-vue-jsx with all the information?This occurred to me today and seems like having a method called `render()` inside the `methods` property will cause this error.

title: warn when overwrite built-in directives (#4876)
body:

comments:
IMO it's not necessary to detect this. Kinda like to detect if someone overwrite the Vue instance.
And if really really needs, should be only in development mode.@dsonet  thanks for you reply.

What I do is avoid overwriting the built-in directives

doc: https://vuejs.org/v2/guide/custom-directive.html#Intro

> In addition to the default set of directives shipped in core (v-model and v-show), Vue also allows you to register your own custom directives

Like `checkComponent()`, I was checking in development mode

``` javascript
if (process.env.NODE_ENV !== 'production') {
  checkComponents(child)
  checkDirectives(parent.directives, child.directives)
}
```

üòÉ Hmm thanks for the PR - bt this doesn't seem to detect cases where user attempts to register other built-ins e.g. `v-if` (which would just fail silently).

After thinking about it, it seems the only way would be to have a constant list of built-ins for each platform. Feels too much of an edge case for this extra maintenance burden.

Still, thank you for the effort put into this PR!Yes, it is also bothering me, in addition also need to distinguish between compile-time and runtime

ping @yyx990803 https://github.com/vuejs/vue/blob/f1c38674f28116e1e335873ecbc6716fb70448a3/src/core/vdom/create-element.js#L72

i have try resolveAsset parentComponent.$options here if context is transition-group
but this is not a good idea
If this only works for global components it's not really a complete fix. Currently the user can actually do

``` html
<transition-group :tag="$options.components.foo">
```

It renders correctly, but there will be patch errors on updates. I think there are thing that needs to be further debugged inside transition-group itself before we can tackle this request properly, but it's not really high priority at the moment.
comments_review:
Use a local component here so that it doesn't accidentally pollute other test cases.That is a problem. `<component>` is resolved in `<transition-group>`, if I register it in `App` it won't be available in `<transition-group>`.

> Created a feature request #5252

author: finntl
title: Add node using nextSibling as reference
body:
<!--
Please make sure to read the Pull Request Guidelines:
https://github.com/vuejs/vue/blob/dev/.github/CONTRIBUTING.md#pull-request-guidelines
-->

<!-- PULL REQUEST TEMPLATE -->
<!-- (Update "[ ]" to "[x]" to check a box) -->

**What kind of change does this PR introduce?** (check at least one)

- [ x] Bugfix
- [ ] Feature
- [ ] Code style update
- [ ] Refactor
- [ ] Build-related changes
- [ ] Other, please describe:

**Does this PR introduce a breaking change?** (check one)

- [ ] Yes
- [ x] No

If yes, please describe the impact and migration path for existing applications:

**The PR fulfills these requirements:**

- [x ] It's submitted to the `dev` branch for v2.x (or to a previous version branch), _not_ the `master` branch
- [ ] When resolving a specific issue, it's referenced in the PR's title (e.g. `fix #xxx[,#xxx]`, where "xxx" is the issue number)
- [ x] All tests are passing: https://github.com/vuejs/vue/blob/dev/.github/CONTRIBUTING.md#development-setup
- [ ] New/updated tests are included

If adding a **new feature**, the PR's description includes:
- [ ] A convincing reason for adding this feature (to avoid wasting your time, it's best to open a suggestion issue first and wait for approval before working on it)

When an item is appended to the end of a list being rendered using v-for, it is appended as a new child to the parent element. If an element has been appended after the list in the meantime, it will appear in the middle of this list instead of after.

For an illustration see https://jsfiddle.net/39epgLj0/30/

This PR fixes this by using nextSibling of the previous node as a reference where available.
comments: Thanks for the PR, but in general, Vue's patching algorithm assumes that the DOM structure will not be arbitrarily mutated by 3rd party code. It's simply impossible to cater to every possible case - for example, your patch only works when there is a single element appended, what if there are multiple ones appended? The code would have to bloat significantly to cater to all these cases and imo simply not practical nor worth it.Thanks for the reply - the patch does work regardless of the number of elements externally appended as it uses the elm from the vdom as the reference, but makes sense that the patching algorithm shouldn't be expected to deal with external mutations - noted!

author: kazupon
title: Support flowtype definition for flow-typed (WIP)
body:
This is a flowtype definition for Vue.js
If this pull request does not need, feel free to close it.

Like a [TypeScript](https://github.com/vuejs/vue/tree/dev/types), I would like to unite the way of providing these definition files.
Already in the [`flow`](https://github.com/vuejs/vue/tree/dev/types) directory,  as @evan have said in [here](https://github.com/vuejs/vue/pull/4567),
but these definition files are defined that specialized in due to internal develop.
I feel these definition files don't give good development experimence to users, to say the least.
As well as typescript, I hope to provide the official flowtype definitions.

I'm considering the below specs:
- Adding `decls` directory for flowtype definition
- Put type definitions in the same [directory structure](https://github.com/flowtype/flow-typed/tree/master/definitions/npm) as flow-typed
- Testing type definitions with `flow-bin` (already installed with package.json)
- Support from flowtype version of `package.json`

author: yyx990803
title: refactor TypeScript typings to use ES style exports
body:
This PR will change Vue's TS typings to use ES-style exports so that it works better with the new ES module build + webpack 2 combo.

So instead of:

``` js
import Vue = require('vue')
```

TS users should now use:

``` js
import Vue from 'vue'
```

...which is consistent with recommended plain ES usage.

This is technically a breaking change, but since we've already unintentionally caused a breaking change for webpack 2 + TS users, we should probably just fully migrate to ES-based exports to avoid more breakage in the future.

Related:

- https://github.com/vuejs/vue-router/pull/1204
- https://github.com/vuejs/vuex/pull/658

@ktsn @HerringtonDarkholme  this will likely also affect `vue-class-component` and `av-ts`, so I'd like to get some feedback on whether this will cause potential issues.I need some local test here. Please kindly wait a moment. I guess this typing change will be fine for webpack users.
But I'm not sure about commonjs users. It seems to break some TypeScript libraries that directly depends on Vue. They need to be updated and also the updated library does not seem to be compatible with old (commonjs style) Vue. It's because TypeScript does not interop ESModule and CommonJS at all (as same as export).

```ts
// commonjs style import
import Vue = require('vue')

// will be compiled to ...
var Vue = require('vue')
```

```ts
// esmodule style import
import Vue from 'vue'

// will be compiled to ...
var Vue = require('vue').default
```@ktsn I think we will need to break something for consistent import style across TS/JS. 

But we should consider what part should we break. Or what should we support.What exactly is the runtime semantics? Vue is a CJS importable entity, but it's written as ES modules, so how are you transforming your code right now?

Also, what is the original source of breakage for TypeScript users?Hi @DanielRosenwasser . Vue now outputs a es module file for webpack/rollup users. So tree shaking will work. And Vue has supported commonjs output file as well. These two versions are compiled into two files by two different rollup configs.

For node/browserfiy users, they use vue.common.js, specified by `main` entry in package.json. The export is done via `module.exports = Vue` and imported by `require('vue')`.

For webpack/rollup users, they use vue.esm.js, specified by `module` entry in package.json. The export is `export default Vue` and is imported by `import Vue from 'vue'`. 

Library authors will also want to support both ESM and commonjs. Babel/webpack has compatbile require builtin. If an author writes library in Babel, Babel will take care of how Vue is imported. So library users can freely use ESM/commonjs and the author will need simply write one `import Vue from 'vue'`, regardless of it is executed in node like commonjs environment or webpack like es module environment.

However, TypeScript does not have builtin compatible library. An author must choose one style `import Vue from 'vue'` or `import Vue = require('vue')`. TypeScript compiles different code. And different style output is not mutually compatible. After some thoughts, maybe there is something that can be done in webpack 2. Right now the problem is that with the `module` field present in `package.json`, webpack will always use it regardless of the import syntax the user is using:

``` js
import Vue from 'vue' // <- gets the default export from the ESM build

const Vue = require('vue') // <- returns { __esModule: true, default: Vue }
```

IMO the `module` field should only be respected when the user is using ES modules import syntax. If a raw `require()` is used, it should use the `main` field instead.

/cc @TheLarkInnAnd for now, I think the best path forward is recommend Vue + TS users to start using `allowSyntheticDefaultImports: true` and use ES imports everywhere. This way when this PR lands they don't need to do anything.Let me summarize some findings. Sorted by effort required.

1. For webpack users: it needs minimal effort, just changing import style is enough.

2. For library authors: they need to use webpack to compile their libraries for commonjs / esm compatibility. [Example](https://github.com/HerringtonDarkholme/av-ts/commit/160cdd9dc0c871ab792c3efd729f157460467d3f).

3. For plain tsc users/ browserify users: they need use babel for a compatible `require`.

I'd rather argue the break in case 3 is sooner or later: e.g. by node-esm spec. (My speculation is not many users are using browserify + ts + vue, but if they do use this combo at least babel will come to rescue.) FYI, updated TypeScript usage docs: https://vuejs.org/v2/guide/typescript.html> And for now, I think the best path forward is recommend Vue + TS users to start using allowSyntheticDefaultImports: true and use ES imports everywhere. This way when this PR lands they don't need to do anything.

The problem is that TypeScript doesn't actually synthesize the default export for a CJS module - this will type-check just fine, but will not work at runtime. `allowSyntheticDefaultImports` only assumes that you have a loader that will do the right thing (e.g. SystemJS). Does Webpack provide this functionality? Otherwise users will need to run their output through Babel.@DanielRosenwasser for webpack 1 yes the user would have to use babel for interop. Webpack 2 uses the ES module build automatically so the semantics align. Webpack 1 is considered deprecated and upgrading to 2 doesn't require much effort, so we'd prefer sticking to es modules in all cases.Sure - it'd be AMD and Webpack 1 that would have problems though. I don't know how many people are using the former, but I'll take your word on the latter. I see you already added `allowSyntheticDefaultImports` to the documentation, so that should help people there.@DanielRosenwasser while we are on this topic - is it possible to allow packages to configure a different d.ts for different module formats? Similar to how the convention for webpack 2 is using "module" for ES modules build and "main" for CommonJS build, it would be helpful to have something like maybe "module-types" for d.ts with es style exports... or maybe something that allows the user to manually specify the d.ts for a specific module in tsconfig.json, like "resolve.alias" in webpack.> or maybe something that allows the user to manually specify the d.ts for a specific module in tsconfig.json, like "resolve.alias" in webpack.

This *sort of* works if you use path-mapping (using the `paths` option in your `tsconfig.json`), but it ends up feeling odd. If this ends up being part of the CommonJS interop spec (I'm on a cell phone so this is hard to look up right now) then we will need to do it (cc @mhegazy @vladima).Closing in favor of #5887.

author: fnlctrl
title: Add support for array as inline style value (client/ssr)
body:
When exploring [css-in-js solutions](https://github.com/MicheleBertoli/css-in-js) for vue, I came across the fact that some auto prefixed style objects (for example, by [postcss-js](https://github.com/postcss/postcss-js)) cannot be directly used as `style` option on elements, when they have an array as value, e.g.
```
{ display: ['-webkit-box', '-webkit-flex', '-ms-flexbox', 'flex'] }
```
...which happens when a rule value needs to be prefixed, other examples:
```
{ backgroundImage: ['radial-gradient(...)', '-webkit-radial-gradient(...)']
{ cursor: ['-webkit-grab','grab'] }
```
This PR adds support for directly consuming such objects as `style` option.        
         
     
      


This is really an edge case (inline style option + style object with value as an array), so I totally understand if this is not going into the core.
In fact I only need this for rendering email templates that require inline styles on html elements with vue SSR, though it seems nice to add support for such usage maybe to give people more freedom when choosing css-in-js solutions.
comments: Can we add test cases for these?I'll add it asap.Oops... messed up the log when rebasing onto dev, will open another PR with tests....

author: sffc
title: Adding the ability to suppress notifications in Vue.set and Vue.delete
comments:
I fixed the lint failures.For why it needs to trigger notification for anything that depends on the object itself, consider the following expression:

``` js
a.b + c
```

When `a` is still `{}`, `a.b` will not be able to detect a dependency on the key `.b`, because the getter doesn't exist yet. The only way to ensure this expression gets re-evaluated when `.b` is created, is by registering the entire object `a` as the expression's dependency. This is simply how Vue's reactivity system works given the current constraints.

That said, I don't really understand the use case for this PR. The only reason you'd use `Vue.set` is to explicitly trigger updates. If you don't trigger a notification on the object itself at the time of registering a new key, then expressions like the one mentioned above will never know a new key was added and will never update.Here's my use case.  I have an object that caches results from I/O operations, indexed by their filename.  For example, `data.cache["/path/to/filename.png"]`.  A watcher can subscribe to one or more of the keys in the cache, and they should update whenever their particular field changes.  At an instant in time, the cache contains around 20 keys.  However, each field in the cache can have multiple watchers, so there may be several hundred watchers.  Triggering a notify on every single watcher when a new key is added to the cache is very expensive.

My pattern for subscribing to a new key currently looks like:

```js
if (!cache.hasOwnProperty(key)) {
	Vue.set(cache, key, null, { notify: false });
}
// do stuff with cache[key]
```

In other words, I'm careful to make sure that the field exists prior to accessing it via the `[]` operator, in order to avoid the problem Evan mentioned.

Giving this a second thought, I think the better way forward might be to add the *Vue.get()* function instead of the `{ notify: false }` option parameter.  The implementation of *Vue.get()* would be something along the lines of:

```js
/**
 * Gets a property from an object, creating the property with the specified default value
 * if it does not exist.
 */
export function get (obj: Array<any> | Object, key: any, defaultVal: any) {
  if (hasOwn(obj, key)) {
    return obj[key]
  }
  const ob = obj.__ob__
  if (!ob) {
    return obj[key]
  }
  defineReactive(ob.value, key, defaultVal)
  return obj[key]
}
```

This way, when you are tempted to write `a.b + c`, you can instead write `Vue.get(a, "b", 0) + c` and ensure that you are subscribed to future changes to that field.

Although this approach would in effect prevent the "global notify" from *Vue.set()*, it would still trigger one from *Vue.del()*, which is not fully desirable.

Thoughts?> Triggering a notify on every single watcher when a new key is added to the cache is very expensive.

Watcher expressions (the first argument to `watch`) are not designed to be heavyweight. Complex logic should go to the watcher handler instead.

Your watcher handler gets executed exactly because you artificially return an object from the watch expression. If you weren't doing that, there's wouldn't be a problem in the first place.

Here is your modified demo with five thousand watchers (an order of magnitude more than several hundred), giving decent performance: https://jsfiddle.net/simplesmiler/exe3nxzg/3/. With this much watchers (assuming you have a few watchers per component) the performance of watcher expressions would not be a bottleneck.

Can you provide a reproduction where executing several hundred watch expressions (without artificially returning distinct values) actually causes performance issues?My watchers do image manipulations, which are synchronous activities that run on the order of milliseconds.  A hundred watchers and you're waiting close to a second for everyone to re-compute.  [Here is an example](https://github.com/sffc/vue-watcher-demo) for illustration.  Run the example using `npm start`, which will start up a local server.  On the server, click the "Load Next Image" button a few times.  Even after just 5 or 6 clicks, there is a noticeable lag.  This being said, I could probably figure out a way to hack the image manipulations into the handler function, but the code wouldn't be as clean.

Also, I noticed that [in core/instance/state.js](https://github.com/vuejs/vue/blob/dev/src/core/instance/state.js#L142), functions you set as a "computed" simply get delegated as watcher expressions.  It says [in the guide](https://vuejs.org/v2/guide/computed.html#Computed-Caching-vs-Methods) (emphasis mine):

> Why do we need caching? Imagine we have *an expensive computed property A, which requires looping through a huge Array and doing a lot of computations*. Then we may have other computed properties that in turn depend on A. Without caching, we would be executing A‚Äôs getter many more times than necessary! In cases where you do not want caching, use a method instead.

In other words, the guide seems to indicate that it's OK to have an expensive function as your computed, and in turn as your watcher expression.

*Even if* the watcher expressions are lightweight, I still don't like the idea of re-computing them when we know for sure that their dependencies haven't changed.  If I have a watcher listening on `cache.a`, creating `cache.b` logically shouldn't cause the other watcher to re-compute as it does now.

---

I've been hacking around in my copy of Vue, and I committed two new features to my branch.  I reverted the `{notify:false}` suggestion.

1. A modification to *Vue.delete()* that triggers notifications only on subscriptions to the property that was deleted, instead of globally to the object.  This is purely an internal optimization; the external behavior is the same, as all watchers that need to be notified get notified.
2. An implementation of *Vue.get()*, the function I had mentioned previously.  I actually like the *Vue.get()* API better than the `{notify:false}` API because if you use it correctly, your app will get faster, and if you don't use it, you simply get the old behavior.

Feature 1 doesn't seem to have any real downsides, and there are no changes to the API.

The gotcha with Feature 2 is that if you mix call sites (with some using *Vue.get()* and with others using the `[]` operator), the call sites using `[]` risk never getting their subscriptions added.  This only happens if you mix `[]` with *Vue.get()* on the same property, and there is a test case demonstrating it.  However, the guide already recommends that you use the sister functions *Vue.set()* and *Vue.delete()* globally, so as long as this restriction is well-documented, I think it should be okay.So - I appreciate the feedback and effort put into this PR, but I'm not convinced of the tradeoff of adding a new API for such a specific use case. In particular, the original perf problem can be circumvented by checking if the specific key has the same value (since you already know which key you depend on).

In the future Proxy-based reactivity system, this problem will go away without the need for an explicit API. Adding an API in the current version to solve a problem that doesn't exist in a future version means we will have to remove it when the new version lands, so ideally we want to avoid that.
comments_review: Tests failed because you didn't follow the lint rules. We only use single quotes.you should test the amount of calls before this line as wellsame hereAcknowledged. I changed the PR to not use the `{notify:false}` API anymore, but I still have it saved in a branch if we want to restore it.

author: andreiglingeanu
title: a bit more random _uids
body:
<!--
Please make sure to read the Pull Request Guidelines:
https://github.com/vuejs/vue/blob/dev/.github/CONTRIBUTING.md#pull-request-guidelines
-->

Continuing the work done in https://github.com/vuejs/vue-devtools/pull/260, I'm proposing a change for a bit more dynamic `_uid`s, by adding a small random offset to them.

This will allow components from multiple Vue dependencies to be inspectable in `vue-devtools` without any hassle. Also, one thing to note is the fact that [transitions](https://github.com/vuejs/vue/blob/f7062b9b75179a0a515205e47cfe6227f33b95f0/src/platforms/web/runtime/components/transition.js#L134) may break in some rare cases.

author: smolinari
title: Let userland remove the production tips info
body:
Hi,

From the discussions here:

https://forum.vuejs.org/t/hide-notify-you-are-running-vue-in-development-mode/5661

and here:

https://github.com/vuejs/vue/commit/aa6f7b4cdb889fba9575710c5a100234ccfb7975

and because it also annoys me, I decided to try and set up a flag, which will allow a dev to "consciously" remove the production tips info. 

It is also related to (requires) this PR for the webpack template.

https://github.com/vuejs-templates/webpack/pull/510

The flag is currently set to "false", so the client dev will have to go into the file and set it to true, to remove the production tips info. 

If you let me know how to best document the availability of the flag (if the two PRs get accepted), I'd be also glad to add into about the flag to the docs too. 

Also, this currently only works for the webpack setup. I haven't looked into the other build possibilities. 

Scott
comments:
Thanks for the PR, but using `process.env` is actually not ideal, because if the user neglected to provide this env var e.g. via Webpack's `DefinePlugin`, Webpack will attempt to emulate `process` by including a process shim module. The standalone build config also needs to change to make sure this reference to `process` is built-away.

I think it's better to just add a runtime config option. We will likely address this in the next release.Hi Evan. ( @yyx990803 )

Thanks for addressing the suggestion. 

I had a feeling I was skating on thin ice with this solution, but I didn't want to disrupt what seems to be a "no configuration" mantra of Vue too much and this was the only way I could figure it out. 

On that point, it seems to me, this mantra is what makes the warning necessary in the first place. There are certainly clear decisions that userland should make, one being setting up Vue for development or production and I think it is ok to allow that as a config setting. 

So, I request this not simply be a decision to remove the warning with an extra flag, but rather to have a clear setting for userland to setup Vue to run in "production" or "development" mode. This would negate the necessity of the warning altogether, because the situation "production" or "development" is then a userland responsibility and not a possible mistake of using Vue incorrectly. 

Scott   

P.S. don't forget to close the other PR in the Webpack Template. üòÑ 
 I loathe the fact Vue is the only package of 50+ I use that actually adds something like this to console.  It's frustrating.@jaketoolson This has already been released: `Vue.config.productionTip = false`Thank you Vue team for taking my suggestion to heart and making it happen! üëç 

ScottSomehow `Vue.config.productionTip = false` is ignored and the message appears anyway.Made it work. Had to put it right after vue.js:
```
...
<script src=".../vue.js">
<script>Vue.config.productionTip=false</script>
<script src=".../vuex.js">
<script src=".../vue-router.js">
...
```:8080/#/:6 Error parsing a meta element's content: ';' is not a valid key-value pair separator. Please use ',' instead.

author: Hanks10100
title: [weex] Fix the memory crosstalk between multiple instance
comments:
Is it possible for `createInstance` or `destroyInstance` to be called when the scheduler is pending? That may create some weird edge cases.

I think the cleaner way to handle this is probably expose Vue via a factory function and basically create a new instance of Vue for each Weex instance. (which would also solve the `Vue.config` usage problem)The `createInstance` and `destroyInstance` is called by native, which depends on the user's behavior. Even in the same *activity* would contain multi Weex instance.

I also think expose Vue through factory function is a more elegant way to fix this. But doing that may change too much (still worthy), and should also take care of those variables in closure. This is a much cheaper way to fix this without side effects.closed via 53d059222f568b14334f1aa9d161da0c79fef58e

author: phanan
title: Use ES2015 destructuring assignment to swap variables
