author: mitar
title: Necessary changes to observer for full Tracker compatibility
body:
(This is all open for debate and I understand that it is previously undiscussed pull request, but it is easier to debate it with concrete code changes available.)

I am working on integration of Vue with [Meteor](https://github.com/meteor/meteor) and I would like that Vue could be a drop-in replacement for Blaze. That is almost possible, because architecture is very similar. Vue is also using reactive dependency tracking, observer, while Meteor/Blaze is using [Tracker](https://github.com/meteor/meteor/tree/devel/packages/tracker). Now, there is a lot of code written for Meteor which is using Tracker and it would be great if it could just work with Vue. And in fact it is doable. I managed to create a [full 100% compatible Tracker implementation on top of Vue's observer](https://github.com/mitar/vue-test/blob/master/packages/tracker/tracker.js). But there are some changes necessary to observer's implementation and some internals have to be exposed.

This pull request is initial version of changes I had to do to get this first version of Tracker implemented, to get discussion rolling. I would really like to see if this or something like this could get merged into Vue. From my perspective changes do not really change how observer is working, and all existing tests are still passing.

A list of changes:

* added support for after flush callbacks
* adding a way to force flushing
* fixed exception recovery for pushTarget/popTarget
* correctly cleanup queue if there is an exception from getter
* exposing some internals (probably too much, API could be cleaner there)

Requesting comments, feedback, suggestions. This is work in progress. I will add tests in the future, after we finalize that this is OK to do and everything else.

[Example app](https://github.com/mitar/vue-test). Notice how I can use [Meteor ReactiveVar inside computed value directly](https://github.com/mitar/vue-test/blob/master/client/app.vue#L34).
comments:
Thanks @mitar , you need to follow the contribution guide when opening a PR.  Please refer: https://github.com/vuejs/vue/blob/dev/.github/CONTRIBUTING.md#pull-request-guidelines@defcc: I thought I did. Which part from the guide I am missing? I will add tests later for new features. I will fix failing tests now. Is there anything else?Hm, tests are now failing at "should get updated with model when in focus" which seems unrelated to my changes? Flaky tests?Thanks @mitar , I opened a PR to fix that error.Tests are passing.Hey, I think this is an interesting approach, but here's why I think it's unlikely to get merged: these changes increases the public API surface and will impact how we can make changes in Vue in the future.

By exposing the internals, it creates a liability for Vue to keep these APIs intact in order to stick to semver (otherwise it would break anything that relies on them, e.g. your Tracker wrapper). However, the scheduler and the reactivity system really is considered internal, and I intend to keep them internal so that we can iterate and make non-trivial changes to them without affecting the public API. There are a few experiments going on currently (e.g. using ES6 Proxy for change detection, slicing scheduler workload with `requestIdleCallback`) that all may cause changes to how the scheduler/Watcher/Dep system works, but if these internal implementation details become part of the public API, it places a serious constraint on how we can iterate on things in the future.

I do see the benefits here in that it allows the two reactivity systems to integrate more seamlessly, however I'm not sure whether it justifies adding the extra liability.

For now, a fork seems like the best short-term solution to me. In the long run, I will probably refactor Vue's reactivity system so that it can be exposed in a way that is less coupled to the internal details.@yyx990803, thank you for your answer.

I do understand your position, but I also think that there are some alternatives available here.

I am not sure what is your position of using `_` prefixed symbols. But this could be one way to expose those internals in a way to communicate that those symbols are internal and could break at any point and using them requires that consumer makes sure things work and things are integrated correctly. For example, from our side we could simply exactly require specific version of Vue and upgrade it in Meteor package only after a new version is tested. But at the same time, some other developer can try and force a new version much easier than forking our fork and changing things there to get this new version.

Another approach would be to provide a very simple API to register an "observer" module with which one can override default observer code (`Dep`, `Watcher`, and `queueWatcher`). Only the API of those would be fixed, but internal implementation would be left to the module to implement.Exposing internals with _ while considering them not part of the public API seems fine to me. And the Meteor integration could pin the version of Vue.@yyx990803, have you made a final decision on this? :)  

We in the Meteor/Blaze community need this change in order to move over to your framework!  There's a lot of developers over there waiting excitedly for this development!  

Can't we compromise on this by using the "_" to expose just the few internals we need?  We understand if you decided to make breaking changes to this portion of the API we're on our own.  Heck, shut down the said APIs if there is a breaking change and we'll be responsible for updating said APIs and brining them back online once everything passes.

I believe the effort will expose a entire community to your UI framework, possibly increasing the mindshare and popularity!I love to see the enthusiasm of Meteor community for this. :-) Thanks.

Just to be clear, exposing symbols with `_` is not enough, there are also some changes needed the code as shown in this pull request:
* added support for after flush callbacks
* adding a way to force flushing

(BTW, I will add tests for all those changes if we decide to merge this pull request.)

An alternative approach, of providing a way to register a custom implementation of `Dep`, `Watcher`, `queueWatcher` would allow us to simple completely swap the implementation, but of course the downside is that this common code would not be maintained (and especially coordinated!) together, which is a downside. But on the other hand it would not require from you to maintain this part of codebase.

I would also like to point out that some things should probably be merged in any case. I found out that current code is very bad at recovering from any exception, leaving the whole system in an undefined state. You can only reload to recover. This is why I added things like:
* fixed exception recovery for pushTarget/popTarget
* correctly cleanup queue if there is an exception from getter

Meteor Tracker tests are pretty hard on testing those edge cases and this is how I found them.If this will be possible, in whatever form, I dare say that Vue will become the default used framework with Meteor. At least for everyone still on Blaze. This would be the most sophisticated and incremental way to start using Vue. Good for both communities!

I started rendering some parts of our app with React. Although React is a great framework, it feels like a mismatch with Meteor. Or tracker, to be more precise.

I truly hope this interoperability will see the light of day!Resolved merge conflicts with current `dev` branch.@yyx990803, you added a 'pending' label to this PR.  Sorry, but what does this mean for us waiting on this change to integrate Vue into our existing Meteor projects?  Do you plan to merge this PR?

Just in case: Blaze has been broken out from Meteor and is now a stand alone project.  @mitar is the primary owner/maintainer for Blaze (no longer MDG).  He is trying to use Vue as the foundation of a Blaze 2 that will serve as the "default" UI for Meteor (the alternative is React).  But without this PR, it will be an impossible task.  

@yyx990803, please allow the Meteor community to further migrate towards Vue by accepting this PR and helping @mitar where needed.

Thank you for a super great framework!Great work.This is super awesome. I really Evan merges this in - thousands of Meteor apps that might switch to Vue as a result of this package.  I moved forked Tracker into its own repo: https://github.com/meteor-vue/tracker
And also made it easier to use forked Vue: https://github.com/meteor-vue/vue

Now it is easy to try all this in your app: https://github.com/meteor-vue/guideBTW, if anyone can help here. Do you know how I could configure something to notify me when this pull requests gets conflicting files. Now I see that it again has conflicting files, so branch should be updated.@mitar

> Do you know how I could configure something to notify me when this pull requests gets conflicting files.

maybe this can help with the alerts: https://gitnotifier.io/

Also, this software looks comprehensive and might have the feature you're looking for: https://www.realartists.com/blog/ship-20.html@yyx990803: What is your take on how to integrate Minimongo the best? Now that we have proper Tracker support, it means that if you do `collection.find().fetch()` inside Vue computed function, it will rerun on every change, as expected. But what should we do if you return `collection.find()`? Should we do anything smart, or just call `fetch()` on it and Object.freeze it? We should also make so that Vue uses `_id` as a default key for Minimongo results (arrays or cursors). Should we specially handle cursors so that Vue observes changes to underlying data without having to compare whole arrays?I have finished integrating Tracker with Vue. I think the result looks amazing. There are some internals we could continue improving, but I think that interface for developers works well.

To showcase it, I implemented [TodoMVC](https://github.com/meteor-vue/todomvc) in it. See [this file](https://github.com/meteor-vue/todomvc/blob/master/client/todos-display.vue) for an example of Vue component using familiar Meteor concepts, like reactivity, subscriptions and methods. (And also some custom packages, to show how they continue working as they worked in Blaze.)

Some [instructions how to use it can be found here](https://github.com/meteor-vue/guide). ~~After more people tested it and more feedback, we can work on putting this into a package and more reusable form.~~

Also, this is on purpose very non-MVVM and trying to be as close to what experience with Blaze is. (So subscribing to data, calling methods to modify data on events, without any fancy multi-way data binding.) Those things can be [future work](https://github.com/meteor-vue/vue-meteor/issues/77).

Comments and feedback welcome. Best place for that [is this issue](https://github.com/meteor-vue/vue-meteor-tracker/issues/3).

This is all possible because of the amazing work by @akryum! It is just combining things he made in a bit different way.

One potential step (which I am not planing to do personally, but would invite somebody to do) is to convert spacebars compiler to convert Blaze template syntax to Vue templates, in a similar way how [Vue allows to use Pug/Jade](https://vuejs.org/v2/guide/single-file-components.html).Also see #6079 with some more useful changes which would help make Minimongo integration smoother. (I am still unclear what would be the best way to do that integration.)Any updates to this issue?

> I'm using @mitar's [fork](https://github.com/meteor-vue/vue), but maybe it would be interesting to have an official integrationMy [previous comment](https://github.com/vuejs/vue/pull/4652#issuecomment-270746417) still stands true as we've planned to do a reactivity system overhaul (using Proxies internally) in early 2018. The chance for this PR to be compatible with the upgrade will be slim. If the need for Meteor integration is still in reasonable demand at that point, we can revisit what that entails after the upgrade.What would be the best way for me to be involved in that system overhaul to help make sure things can work together from the very beginning. So that it is not a later change which as you see now is much harder to get in?

I think that 38 upvotes on this pull request is clear that there is some demand for this.

Also, why not still merge this in as it is now, and then as upgrade happens, also the new system could contain things useful for Meteor?The main issue: the changes are too intrusive, so it is essentially asking the Vue team to take on liability, design constraints and potential technical debt for some need that is entirely induced by a 3rd party system.

In order to get involved in the process, it'd be helpful to have a proper write up of what is fundamentally preventing Vue's reactivity system to work with Tracker's; and instead of directly changing Vue's internals, providing a desired API surface that you'd like to see exposed (even better, test cases of these exposed APIs). That helps us gauge the constraints better and maybe can come up with something that decouples the two systems better.> In order to get involved in the process, it'd be helpful to have a **proper write up of what is fundamentally preventing Vue's reactivity system to work with Tracker's**; and instead of directly changing Vue's internals, **providing a desired API surface that you'd like to see exposed (even better, test cases of these exposed APIs)**.

@mitar do you have any plans on providing the stuff he's asking for above or have you moved on from this effort? @aadamsx, thanks for reminding me to reply here.

@yyx990803, I think there might be a slight misunderstanding here (of what this pull request is doing, or of what I am trying to achieve), so just to make sure I will summarize it. I ported Meteor's Tracker on top of Vue's reactivity system. Vue's is really a great reactivity system and Tracker was able to be ported to it with almost 1:1 API mapping only. The only small differences are that Tracker has some more hooks to be called (like after each invalidation, allowing to force flushing, small things like that). This PR might look intrusive, but it is mostly just adding such places for hooking in.

So I see two options, the first being this PR:
* Vue reactivity system exposes few more callbacks so that Tracker can be directly built as a API transformation on top of Vue reactivity system (personally, I do not see it as too intrusive, but this is your call, and maybe they could even be made cleaner than I made them)
* Vue makes its reactivity system pluggable, so that user can say, "hey, instead of this default implementation, swap it with this other JS module"; it would be on the second module to assure compatibility with default system

I think based on the feedback you gave here, I think the second approach would be better. Instead of us having to define API space and have to push back and forth on which callbacks Tracker would need and which one you would be OK to provide, you just freely design Vue reactivity system how it is, just allow that somebody can call something like `Vue.useReactivity(module)` and it would start using the new module instead. And if new module is buggy, it is on their maintainers to make it compatible. Based on PR here I see it that it would be easy to maintain such alternative implementation exposing few more callbacks. And it would be easier than providing the whole fork of Vue.

What do you think of this approach?

Just one reply from before:

> we've planned to do a reactivity system overhaul (using Proxies internally) in early 2018

So because I am building Tracker on top of Vue reactivity system, I do not think it is really important how internally you implement it. I am glad that Vue reactivity system has a concept of "user" watchers but beyond that it is just using the external API. See [here for details](https://github.com/meteor-vue/tracker/blob/master/tracker.js#L226).I heard the Vue logo is on Meteor.com - it sounds like this is going well :)@yyx990803, what do you think about ideas I made above how we could make this work for both communities?@yyx990803 ping. Is there a better channel to communicate about this?
comments_review:
Why are you not using default import syntax?

L22: `import Watcher from '../observer/watcher'`
L20: `import Dep,  { pushTarget, popTarget } from '../observer/dep'`No particular reason. I can change it, if you prefer.I find @znck syntax cleaner. :smile:Updated.

author: miherlosev
title: Propose an e2e testing framework
body:
Hello
I am a developer from the [TestCafe](https://github.com/DevExpress/testcafe) team.
In your [article on Medium](https://medium.com/the-vue-point/vue-in-2016-8df71d98bfb3#.bjcka9pet),
you mentioned that you have plans to improve the test story.

We want to propose TestCafe as an official testing tool for the Vue ecosistem.
Our e2e testing framework is a pure node.js solution, so it can easily integrate with Vue.

In this pull request, I rewrote all e2e tests using TestCafe to demonstrate key features, such as:

-  clean code (no 'waitForElementVisible', no waiting for page loads and xhr requests)
-  no need for additional dependencies, configs and browser plugins
-  easy setup
-  ES2016 syntax
-  flexible selectors

We would be happy to cooperate with you and we are ready to create vue-specific features (similar to Protractor selectors for Angular).

What do you think about it?
comments:
@miherlosev thanks a lot for the PR! I've been interested in testcafe since it was announced and was waiting for it to mature a bit. Before I can make a decision, I'll need to play with it a bit more in some other existing projects to get some first hand experience with it, but this PR is very helpful in that regard. Will get back to this after I test it more!I have updated to the latest version 0.12.1. 
This version contains a lot of new features and bug fixes.
For details, see https://devexpress.github.io/testcafe/blog/testcafe-v0-12-0-released.htmlWe found that people start using testcafe for vue-based applications.
We wanted to give them the capability to test vue markup and component properties together.
To this end, we've created the [vue selector extentions](https://github.com/DevExpress/testcafe-vue-selectors).
Please, take a look and let us know what you think about it.Since version 0.14.0 TestCafe supports the `file` schema and relative paths for the page directive. 
So, I removed the `http-server` module from `package.json` and changed all tests to relative paths.Hey - really thanks for starting this PR and sticking with us, and sorry for letting this stand for so long. The truth is, over the time our need for e2e testing in the core repo itself hasn't really changed much, and we haven't found much benefit in changing our setup to a different tool. I'm sure there are certain things that TestCafe does better than what we are using, but in our use case (the core repo), we just want to avoid the cost of having learn a different API without substantial benefits. IMO, the better to promote TestCafe to Vue users would be creating examples of testing actual projects instead of the core repo.

author: HerringtonDarkholme
title: Support async component hydration in SSR
body:
Fix #4387. Improve async component SSR performance by reducing bailing.

The basic idea here is, skip checking async component when hydration. To support this, I introduced a new flag on VNode `isAsyncPlaceholder`. A placeholder VNode is same as an emptyVNode, except the new flag set to true. Before this commit, an async component will be rendered to emptyVNode(in `createElement`). After this commit, an async component will be rendered to placeholderVNode. So the behavior in client-side rendering or bailed SSR rendering should be kept.

In SSR hydration, we skip checking a placeholder VNode against a real element. After component is resolved, the Vue instance in question will `$forceUpdate` in callback. So even if the real element dismatches with resolved VNode, rendered dom structure should be up to date. 

**Current implementation cannot reuse dom for async component because `isHydrating` is not available in `createComponent`.**

Another potential problem is that third party code can attach event handler / store data on SSR element. Those information will be lost in `$forceUpdate` callback. But I would suggest library users should care about it because I wonder if a library can provide a silver-bullet strategy.
comments_review:
Now resolveAsyncComponent will return null if component is rejected. This relies on JavaScript has two kinds of `zero value`. A more canonical solution is to wrap result in a container which has a property indicating resolution status. But it would incur more overhead.

Is current implementation good to you @yyx990803 ?We have a lot of boolean flags here. I think they can be packed into an integer and be retrieved by bitwise operation. Fewer properties should reduces memory consumption since typically we have a lot of VNode instances and probably can prevent multiple hidden class creation.

Maybe a good refactor for another pull request.Yep, that's something I've been thinking about too! Would love a PR for that!hmm maybe have some sort of enum integer consts like `const PENDING = 1` and check if `res === PENDING`resolveAsyncComponent now return an enum for resolution status: `RESOLVED`, `PENDING`, `REJECTED`. It is a function local to create-component so I think it should be fine. Having experimented with number flags, I only see memory consumption only drops 1%, yet manipulating flags is much more verbose than before. I didn't see much value here.

author: defcc
title: Add unbind to v-show (fix #4484)
body:
fix #4484 

If element exists in dom tree, will set its display property back.

Apply possible transition if value is false.
comments:
Thanks @defcc - there are a few issues with this fix: if we always reset the display in `unbind`, then elements hidden by `v-show` will be revealed if it is inside an element with a leaving transition. So we need to differentiate between a destroy `unbind` vs. a patch `unbind`, and only reset display for patch `unbind`. Transition check is not necessary for patch unbind because a patch unbind cannot happen to common child of the same `<transition>` component.

I added a 5th argument to `unbind` in https://github.com/vuejs/vue/commit/a977642fac385b2d16455a5eaebf70f2fc949377 (and used your test case)Thanks for your comment.

body:

comments:
yeah, why not. It makes things easier for contributors working with idea IDEsüòÇnot only `.idea`, but also `.iml`.@JounQin I've never used Idea's IDEs so having some user input on this is nice, thanks üëç Adding `.idea` should suffice though, since all `.iml` files are stored under the `.idea` directory@fnlctrl Not exactly. I'm using IDEA Modules in one project, what means the git root path is not same with `.idea` but is with `*.iml`.What's the deal with [creating a global `.gitignore`](http://stackoverflow.com/questions/7335420/global-git-ignore) and including the `.idea`-directory in there? You would never have to worry about accidentally committing the `.idea`-directory.

And what about other IDEs and editors? When you are developing in Visual Studio Code, the `.vscode`-directory is created. Same goes for NetBeans with the `nbproject`-directory. Should these directories be added to the `.gitignore` as well?

I don't think it's the responsibility for Vue to ignore these directories. To exclude all these directories, the `.gitignore`-file would get a bit too bloated.@petervmeijgaard thanks for sharing that, didn't know about it!
Makes sense not to merge this PR because we would have to add every ide, text editor specific folder to .gitignore and because there's a better solution, which is creating a global .gitignore üëç

author: kaorun343
title: Add some functions related to render
body:
Although these methods' prefix is `_`, using them are beneficial when writing `render`, I think.
So, I added them into the definitions.
comments:
Can you show any use cases by using these methods?
I'm not sure why we need to expose these private apis. `$createElement` does not suffice for you?I don't need all of these private methods. What I really need are these below. 

* `_m()`  to access to `staticRenderFns`
* `_l()`  We don't have to prepare the functions like `_.map()`
* `_f()` to access to the filters registered globally, some plugins are doing so
* `_k()` We don't have to know what the keyCode is

Also,  I tried to define these apis as `protected`. However, when specify `this`, I cannot access to these protected methods.Well, I meant that I want you to show some **practical use cases**.
I think we shouldn't expose private apis for use cases that can be achieved easily on the userland. Because it would complicate to maintain declaration files as they can be changed without updating major version. And if we really want to use them for some minor usage, we can declare them in our own project easily.

So, I'm still not sure when/why we need to use these apis rather than `$createElement` and other userland utilities.OK, I'll close this 'cause I couldn't show the merits of this PR.
Also I didn't think about the risks of putting them, private apis,  as public.

author: lgabster
title: fix kebab vs camel-case event names
body:
This PR fix the following problem
```javascript
v-on:click="$emit('myEvent')"
v-on:myEvent="doSomething()"
```

Now `$emit('myEvent')` trigger `v-on:myEvent`, `v-on:myevent`, `v-on:my-event`, and log error message to the console when event isn't hook: and cannot find in registered events.
comments:
FYI this already works if you are using string templates instead of in-dom templates. We've discussed this in the past but decided that ambiguous event name matching may end up causing subtle bugs.

The short answer is stick to kebab-case if you really have to use in-com templates.
OK, but now there is no any warning message, when event cannot find in vm._events
@lgabster that's a good point. I think what we can do is:
- In dev mode, if an event misses, check for a loose match. If there is a loose match, warn the user about the event casing problem.

author: salihsagdilek
title: data/store to normal object
body:
Hello i work on a project with vue.js.
But sometimes i need the raw data.
Actually same problem with this issue; [How to convert the object of Vue to normal object?
](https://github.com/vuejs/Discussion/issues/292)

```javascript
JSON.parse(JSON.stringify(vm.$data))
```
this solution is great but if you need it more than few times it's uncomfortable. so i wrote normalize; 
```javascript
/** vue */
vm.$data.normalize(); // return to normal object

/** vuex */
this.$store.state.normalize(); // return to normal object
```
<!--
Please make sure to read the Pull Request Guidelines:
https://github.com/vuejs/vue/blob/dev/.github/CONTRIBUTING.md#pull-request-guidelines
-->
comments: Sorry, but I think it's a bad idea to extend data objects like that. This could easily lead to naming conflicts. Just creat util functions of your own.

author: shreeve
title: Allow tag selectors in render functions
body:
This allows tags such as `section.active.admin@intro`, which would yield `<section class='active admin' id='intro'>`.

Allowing these types of selectors, when used in combination with another tiny enhancement (https://github.com/shreeve/coffeescript/pull/1) to `CoffeeScript` allows us to write native `CoffeeScript` that looks a lot like `JSX`, but is actually full fledged `CoffeeScript`. Here's an example of something we're working on (a work in progress, but coming along!):

![conversation coffee lite 2016-10-22 23-08-41](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/142875/19623874/7fd0582a-98ac-11e6-9f33-1ca8512df786.png)
comments:
If I get this right, I don't think this belongs to the core. Maybe a custom `render` function is what it should be.
A custom render function would work. Is there a way to have a hook inside of createElement that is able to invoke this code if specified? 
Yes you can. 

``` javascript
Vue.mixin({
  beforeMount() {
    this.$createElement = customCreateElement
  }
})

Vue.prototype._h = customCreateElement
```

This should works.  The first statement is for render function, the second statement is for compiled template .

POC https://jsfiddle.net/v368d4g3/3/

Caveats: implementation details are liable to change
Oh, man! That's great.

Is this a one-liner type of tweak that we could put in our top-level app and everything would inherit? That would make it super easy. Is there another library, module, or mixin (or whatever else) that could be used as an example for this type of feature?
> Is this a one-liner type of tweak that we could put in our top-level app and everything would inherit?

Yes, if I read the code correct. Place it in your entry file and most things will be fine. (~~with the probable exception of functional component~~, functional component behavior is not changed, you can just use your own createdElement function in render function as long as it returns VNode compatible object)

> Is there another library, module, or mixin (or whatever else) that could be used as an example for this type of feature?

I don't know. I think this is too hacky to be included in a project's README...
@phanan - Is there already a way to support such as custom render function as a Vue plugin?
As it has turned into a discussion, I'd suggest opening a thread on [the forum](http://forum.vuejs.org) instead.

author: HerringtonDarkholme
title: SSR: eliminate closure in render.js implementation
body:
I'm trying to remove closures in src/server/render.js.

Removing closures can improve runtime performance, enable easier reasoning about memory leakage, and prevent erroneous captured variable reused.  

The basic idea is to pack all captured variable into a `RenderContext` structure. In closure based implementation, all state changes are implicitly stored by wrapping `next` function. In context based implementation state transitions are explicitly recorded in `renderStates` property. 

I have ran a preliminary benchmark [here](https://docs.google.com/spreadsheets/d/1yxUXYqelR7VcyFHXXVBvZY9iBIr422I6uO8K2P8aU0M/edit#gid=0) by running `npn run bench:ssr`.
It seems closure elimination can achieve 20% performance boost.
#4002 has also been fixed in this, because contexts are separated between two render function.
comments:
Wow, very impressive! This is a pretty substantial PR, so I'll take a bit more time to evaluate it, but at a glance seems very well done.
Thanks for quick response! Leave comments if you have suggestions, I'm happy to fix.
Manually resolved and merged as 2ac581bb7f34b1ef0f35c3e6945acd630a92453e - thanks! Very nice work.

author: HerringtonDarkholme
title: upgrade flow type to 0.33
body:
Upgrading flow finds several typing issues (largely due to flow limitation) in compiler.

The first modification is to change `genData` to always return `string`, this requires extracting `plain` ASTElement out.

The second modification is to ensure `el.component` presents when called with `genComponent`. The checker does not flow type refinement information to function call. So we need a new parameter for the information.

Remaining modifications are solely at type level.
comments: Merged as part of #4007

author: blocka
title: Allow for function as child
comments:
I have implemented this, complete with tests that actually tests things this time (sometimes we need tests for the tests...) Not entirely happy about the implementation, but I'd like to here your thoughts. +1 for this feature. It will enable users to write powerful component for abstracting UI pattern and manipulating data rendering. My concern here is API consistency. - Double mustache is for interpolation in vue. Interpolating function is potentially confusing - Function as child only works well in render function. In template code, users cannot write code like `{{ (data) => Hello {{data}}}}` because vue does not translate expression. - Hard to specify to which slot the child function is passed. It is not ideal to pass multiple child functions and to distribute them by the order they are passed. To my best knowledge, I guess @blocka is inspired by JSX expression. But the problem here is that JSX isn't the default template method. UPDATE: my original can already be done in Vue2.0. See [POC](https://gist.github.com/HerringtonDarkholme/91bb004e6aa5b545f0893fdc2d8c4538) here. Working repo [here](https://github.com/HerringtonDarkholme/vue-loader-test/). My idea is introducing a new builtin component: `template`. A `template` component can declare new variable in its scope. It looks like Angular2's structural directive, sorry for that but I cannot come up with better API. It is compiled into a function that return vnodes. Allowing function for child is the common goal. ``` html ``` Compiled to render function ``` javascript _h('component-with-data', _tpl('mySlot', function(data) { return _h('span', data); })); ``` Because template is a tag, it works like other tags and would not introduce new behavior to interpolation. It works in vue's template code. And for render function, users can just pass a function as default child function, or passing `_tpl` for named slot. For JSX usage in render function, content in template will be compiled to normal vnode rather than functions so users cannot use it. This is confusing for JSX users, indeed. Adding a slot mark on template tag is easy. The `slot` name may need changed so it does not break `$slot`'s type consistency. Bike shedding is never enough for introducing an important feature like child function in vue. Looking forward to your feedback. --- I think I can already do this in vue 2.0. helper definition ``` javascript Vue.component('v-template', { created() { this.$options.render = h => h('') } }) ``` component definition: ``` javascript var printTwice = { render(h) { let template = this.$slots['default'][0].data.inlineTemplate return h('div', [template.render(), template.render()]) } } ``` component usage: ``` vue ``` Not exactly why you consider this bike shedding. I'm using this in actual production code right now. I am definitely biased towards JSX. I'm not going to deny that, and this feature would definitely line up with the "advanced" features. The render method itself is an "advanced" feature, so I'm not expecting anybody to want this feature with templates. This PR assumes only one function will ever be used, and there is really no reason to have more then one. A function can always pass in more functions that can be used for "named" slots. That said, the ultimate motivation behind this is the inflexibility of slots. Perhaps we can just modify slots they always functions, and we can pass them properties. ``` // Child
{{data_passed_in}}
// Parent ``` Which would compile to ``` render (h) { return this.$slots.myslot({data_passed_in: "Hello, World"}) } ``` My two problems with this are the injected variables are not explicit, and, of course, would break the current APIs. Hey, just a note I'm not leaving this hanging - will probably be part of 2.1 along with a template slot equivalent, thanks for the patience!

author: fergaldoyle
title: Allow setting of compiled render functions via template option
body:
In scenarios where we have pre-compiled templates, `compiler.compileToFunctions()`, you need to set both `render` and `staticRenderFns` in component options or use a mixin.

This PR creates a shortcut, by allowing the `template` option receive an object of complied functions.

In conjunction with something like https://www.npmjs.com/package/vue-template-compiler-loader, the following would be possible (where the imported template is pre-compiled and not a string):

``` javascript
new Vue({
    el: '#app',
    template: require('./template.html')
})
```

or

``` javascript
import template from './component-a.html'
new Vue({
    el: '#app',
    template
})
```
comments:
I'm not sure if I like the idea of overloading `template` for this. Actually you can just do: ``` js import render from './component-a.html' new Vue({ el: '#app', ...render }) ``` I found that just setting the `render` function without `staticRenderFns` lead to errors... I assumed you needed both? e.g. a template of `
` while generate this object: ``` { render: function(){with(this){return _m(0)}}, staticRenderFns: [function(){with(this){return _h('div')}}] } ``` Setting just `render` will give error: `TypeError: this._staticTrees is null` @fergaldoyle You may have missed the object spread operator `...` ;) ``` js new Vue({ el: '#app', // note the ... here, it will spread the `render` object and add its properties to the outer object ...render }) ``` So Evan's idea was that you can make `import render from './component-a.html'` give you an object that is ``` js { render: function(){ /*omitted*/ }, staticRenderFns: [ /*omitted*/ ] } ``` So after the spread you will have ``` js new Vue({ el: '#app', render: function(){ /*omitted*/ }, staticRenderFns: [ /*omitted*/ ] }) ``` Thanks, I did miss that. (Also needed to install `transform-object-rest-spread` plugin for Babel). I'm happy with that approach and for this PR to be closed.

author: Tribex
title: [next] [discussion] Add warning for those using Vue.set with only two arguments, as in Vue 1
body:
Currently using `vm.$set` with only two arguments, as in Vue.js 1 results in a somewhat cryptic TypeError.

```
Uncaught TypeError: Cannot create property [VAL] on string [KEY]
```

Since it would appear that in no scenario can `set` take less than three arguments, I've added a development warning in this case that directs the user to the new documentation for `Vue.set`:

```
Set now requires you to specify the object you are modifying as the first argument. See: http://rc.vuejs.org/api/#Vue-set
```

I understand if this is deemed not needed or potentially volatile due to the fact it references the temporary rc.vuejs.org site. Just thought it might be useful to users who are migrating as the difference isn't immediately clear. I answered this exact question twice on Gittr within two hours.

Thanks!
comments_review:
key: string?
Yes, but to follow JS's standard, objects passed in as key are coerced to strings.
I think it would be better to explicitly say what we talk about. `Set` is also a type in Javascript.

```
Vue.set() / this.$set() now requires ...
```
Good idea. Amended
EDIT: Well that didn't work as expected...
are there a typo?
_specifiy_ to _specify_
Indeed there is. I'll need to re-commit because apparently amending doesn't work anymore.

author: kaorun343
title: Add typescript definition
body:
Hi.

This is a definition file for Vue.js 2.0.
I would like to unite the way of providing these definition files, I think, so I took the same way of Vuex.

I referenced a rc.vuejs.org, and it is not complete. These are the TODO List of this.
I hope that this PR will be merged and modified the files to achieve these things by other people.
- [x] Adding rest definitions since v1.0 such as lifecycle hooks.
- [x] Adding the functions related to `createElement` and writing the interface `VNode` and others.
- [x] Considering the naming of the interfaces, for instance, whether we should use the same name between TS and Flow.
- Adding JSDoc/TSDoc comments for IDE. If allowed, I'd like to refer to the official documents.
- [x] Adding a test if needed as well as we did in DefinitelyTyped
- Modifying `vue-class-component` to use this new definition file when this is finished

Thanks.
comments:
@kaorun343 
Thank you for starting write declarations!
I write some comments for this. Please check them :smile: 
This is awesome, @kaorun343. I was just thinking the other day how much better Vue'd be with the help of Typescript. 

Keep it up! :+1: 
I've done my work.
@kaorun343 
Thanks! I have written the comments for some critical parts.
LGTM if you fix them üëç 
I've done üëç 
Great job üòÑ 
Great Job! This type definition has very high quality. Kudos to @kaorun343 
Is this ready?
Yes!
Great, can we also add:
- a npm script that runs the typescript tests
- include that script in `npm test`
Manually squashed and merged as dfc64e8a110d63177869528e2f9cdc103cf514b4 - Thanks for the hard work!
I have used it locally. There are some issues that block the adoption I think...
1. no [`typings`](https://www.typescriptlang.org/docs/handbook/module-resolution.html) field in package.json. Users have to install type definition one more time. This can be easily fixed.
2. `export = Vue` in index.d.ts actually does not work for TypeScirpt's module resolution. This is the hard part.

For point1 adding a new field is enough. But point2 needs more elaboration.
Vue exposes `Vue` as a whole for API consumer. It is good for non-ES6 module users but in ES6 the _correct_ way to import is `import * as Vue from "vue"`. (Babel support this by `_interopRequireDefault` helper function)

TS cannot export a class as a whole.  The workaround hack is `export = Vue` as submitted in this PR, but [the exported symbol must be a namespace](https://github.com/Microsoft/TypeScript/issues/5073) or merged with namespace declaration.  This is by design, I don't think there is much chance to be changed in TS/ES.
One workaround is changin `index.d.ts` to this

``` typescript
import {Vue as _V} from './vue'
declare class Vue extends _V {}
declare namespace Vue {}
export = Vue
```

`declare namespace` statement is for bypassing export limitation.

`declare class Vue extends _V`  is solely for bypassing import limitation in TS module declaration.

This is hideous hack, and TS users must `import * as Vue from "vue"`, lame. But limits changes in TS specific files.

Another way is adding two private fields to Vue:  `default` pointing to `Vue` itself and `__esModule` being `true`.
This change is compatible with ES5/commonJS/ES6/Babel/TypeScript, and probably future proof. Everyone shall be happy. And TS users can just `import Vue from "vue"`, cool.
But the change needs to be applied to Vue itself.

What's your opinions? @yyx990803 @kaorun343 @ktsn 
I think changing index.d.ts is better solution because it can clearly separate the code for adapting Vue's implementation in that file.
If we can insert `module.exports.default = Vue` and `module.exports.__esModule = true` on _build time_, I think it's also good.
@ktsn You mean change something in Babel preset to support `module.exports.default = Vue`? https://github.com/yyx990803/babel-preset-es2015-rollup-vue

~~after lengthy web search I think TS users should forget import default and just pay taxes for type checking~~
@HerringtonDarkholme 
Yes, or rollup plugin. But I'm not sure whether such plugin is exist or not.
Probably updating d.ts is realistic. :wink: 
This is so nice to have d.ts files in the npm packages (for all central components), I really like the way things a going for Vue, I still miss my constructor for classes, to make TS nicer to dance with :-)

But my real issue are, how will a render function look like ? I like to use the new VNode system, from Typescript, but I cant seem to find the prototype anymore (found it in rc7).

Also, has anyone tried to use TSX in any of the modes ? 
@druppy Thanks for supporting vue. But github issues are mainly for bug report/ feature request. And please file relevant reviews under a pull request.

You can ask question in gitter and forum. And you may also find https://github.com/vuejs/awesome-vue helpful.

author: vird
title: hotreload hook
comments:
What's the use case for this? A normal component should not be concerned with how it's hot-reloaded.
I have some complex component with many subcomponents. I need hidden textarea for input capturing. I create root component with textarea. I need clicks on any subcomponent lead to focus on this textarea. I don't want seek local root component with $parent walking and seeking for magic property.
So I create single object (shared controller) with focus method. So I handle all clicks with some action and maintain focus on textarea.
Now hotreload comes. It triggers rerender of root component and after that replaces state with old one. old state includes old textarea reference.
I think the problem is that you are placing the textarea reference in your component state. Component state should be pure serializable data. The textarea reference doesn't need to be in the state. You can just attach it to the instance in the `ready` hook with `this.sharedController = ...`.
`You can just attach it to the instance in the ready hook with this.sharedController = ....`
No, I can't, because after 'ready' method comes state replace from hotreload.
Do not define `sharedController` inside `data` at all, then it won't be replaced. It's just a normal property on the Vue instance.
I have complex app with multiple editors. I don't know exact count of components. I can bootstrap Vuejs as separate app, but it breaks idea of vuejs components, because now it's two types of components: native vuejs and bootstraping with sharedController provided in props.
I don't think I understand your last comment and how it relates to the solution I suggested. But to be concise, your `sharedController` doesn't need to be defined in `data`. Just do:

``` js
created () {
  this.sharedController = sharedController
}
```

If this doesn't work due to other constraints, then you didn't provide enough context. Either way, this should not be solved by adding a hotreload hook.
Ok. Let's make it simplier.
sharedController is just mediator. It recieves 'focus' messages from all complex component. I need make actual textarea focused when 'focus' event occur.
What happens when I init app.
I need somehow told sharedController what to do on 'focus' event. So I provide closure with actual reference to textarea. All works ok.
Hotreload comes.
New component tree created with new sharedController. All is ok: new tree with new sharedController, old with old one. Ready hook comes. I told new sharedController what to do on 'focus' event.
Now hotreload replaces all my state in new component with old sharedController. How **old** sharedController (from previous state) should be updated? There are no events after hotreload updates state.
Did you understand my suggestion? `sharedController` is not part of the state if you avoid declaring it in `data`.
Hm. It works, but it's kind'a injecting in component. I can accidently replace some important property. I suggested that there is only several safe spaces for state: data, props. 
I tested some time solution with 'created' method. I've found that it works only in this simple case, that I mentioned above.
I have another case, when hotreload hook is much simpler.
I have some two types of components
1. Complex structure DOM-based component with one hidden textarea that capture all keyboard activity
2. Simple canvas-based component with hidden textarea.
I have component for multiple keyboard scheme handling. Problem 1. Current scheme is a state. After hot reload I will be switched to default scheme.
Ok. I extend keyboard_controller for different components with actions specific to that component. Actions could be result of keyboard actions or mouse actions.
So I want handle all mouse events with that controller. Problem 2. Canvas must be pannable, so I must store offset_x, offset_y between hot reloads.

So, I have two solutions:
1. Without hotreload hook. I must make state detachable from controller, because state must preserve with hot reload. After 'ready' I must setTimeout for waiting hotreload applies. Now data has old state, I can attach this state to controller and call update, that would redraw all canvas contents to actual state (not clean canvas, but with elements, pan, other state before hotreload)
2. With hotreload hook. Just update textarea, canvas reference. Then call update.

Pros:
1. If error occurs in hotreload hook, page would be reloaded, due hotreload exception catch logic, not my custom.
2. setTimeout/setImmediate not guarantee that no changes occur between 'ready' and after hotreload, so external data feed can easily break the state. Hotreload hook is sync.
3. I can organize code as I want, framework not limits me.
4. (almost impossible case) It's stable if hotreload would be async and setTimeout would be fired before state replace.

Cons:
1. If controller initialization is long, I want no new controller created at all, so I want fully different path of hooks for hotreload and typical create. It's too much changes and can be fragile.

author: zigomir
title: Allow white spaces inside object literal.
body: Fix for https://github.com/vuejs/vue/issues/3210.
comments:
LGTM. I guess it's worth mentioning in the docs
LGTM
pure regex based approach is a somewhat incomplete fix. For example it would fail for this:

``` js
abc | filter {a:1} {b:2}
```

It would match `{a:1} {b:2}` as a single argument.

Additionally, if we support spaces inside object braces, they should probably work for arrays too:

``` js
abc | filter [1, { a: 2 }]
```

So we either support the full syntax, or not support it at all. A more proper parsing logic would have to do something similar to what the directive parser is doing: keeping track of braces/brackets/quotes state and only delimit an argument if we are not in any pairs.
Fortunately in 2.0 we don't have this issue :o
So maybe we should just drop it and recommend to pass a computed property instead?
@yyx990803 I agree. This isn't proper fix then. I'll see what I can do about it :)
@yyx990803 I was playing around a bit more and come up with new syntax when filter has multiple arguments. If there are more filters they need to be wrapped in `[]` as you can see in spec. I'm not sure if this is the way we want to do it...especially with eval used üòä . 

This also forces us to document this behavior and update the docs/guide. I can do it, if this is the way we want to handle this, otherwise I think it's better we just document you should extract filters to functions or use no spaces like @posva already mentioned :)
We forgot about this. I'll rather keep it the way it is and add some documentation that adding a new syntax to filters which already use a special (non-js) syntax
Can this be closed now? I haven't followed well enough @zigomir 
Yeah, for sure, it was just a silly attempt of mine :)

author: kazupon
title: fix compiler options
body:
I found the compiler options issue.

The below the reproduction minimum codes.
https://jsfiddle.net/kazupon/dfok8du9/3/
comments:
Thanks - this is intentional, because `Vue.compile` is an alias to `compileToFunctions`, which is only used at runtime. But runtimes already include pre-determined modules and directives, and you should not be able to compile the template in a different way.

The test for compile-time modules and directives should be in `test/modules/compiler/compiler-options.spec.js` and should be using the `compile` function exported by `src/entries/web-compiler`.
OK! I gotcha!

> The test for compile-time modules and directives should be in test/modules/compiler/compiler-options.spec.js and should be using the compile function exported by src/entries/web-compiler.

That make sense!
I think this test helpful when the user want to user the compiler.
I'll try to push the other PR. üòâ

author: simplesmiler
title: Fix watcher target not resetting properly
body:
Possible fix for https://github.com/vuejs/vue/issues/3133.

The problem appears to be rooted in [`prevTarget`](https://github.com/vuejs/vue/blob/v2.0.0-alpha.5/src/core/observer/watcher.js#L15) getting funky [during instance mounting](https://github.com/vuejs/vue/blob/v2.0.0-alpha.5/src/core/instance/lifecycle.js#L53). This causes `Dep.target` to never be reset to `null`.

This is most likely not the best solution. Maybe a better place for solution would be around [here](https://github.com/vuejs/vue/blob/v2.0.0-alpha.5/src/core/instance/lifecycle.js#L54) or [here](https://github.com/vuejs/vue/blob/v2.0.0-alpha.5/src/core/observer/watcher.js#L77).

Also I can't come up with a better unit test than the original repro:
- Create two instances, first with a computed property (easiest way to reproduce), make sure computed field is used in the template,
- Change the data of the second instance,
- Make sure that first instance didn't update.

Should I include it anyway?

/cc @yyx990803
comments:
Checking why e2e is failing.
Can not run `node test/e2e/runner.js --env phantomjs` on my windows machine.
Running `node test/e2e/runner.js --env chrome` yields no failures.

Would appreciate a hint.
Hm, maybe I should not be fiddling with prev target, and should be just saving it along with the current target.
e2e is most likely due to CI unstableness. Thanks a lot for discovering the root cause tho! Indeed I think there's a better way to fix this and I've pushed it here: https://github.com/vuejs/vue/commit/2c63e94f692430d3ff48cec31457a27684b085a2
@yyx990803 :+1:

author: knpwrs
title: Add halt event modifier.
comments:
Hi @knpwrs, 

thank you for oyur contribution. It certainly seems to add a useful shortcut, albeight a minor one. Anyone else have an opinion on this?

Anyways, please give us some time to consider this, as we are currently working mostly on shipping 2.0
Give https://davidwalsh.name/javascript-events and https://css-tricks.com/dangers-stopping-event-propagation/ a good read or two before stopping propagation.
That David Walsh article indicates that should this feature be accepted that there should probably be documentation stating to be careful when handling events in libraries intended for distribution.
Thanks for the PR, but I am somehow not in favor of this, because there is no corresponding semantics in the native DOM event API. When I see `.stop`, `.prevent` or `.capture`, I can relate them to what is actually happening, but `.halt` just feels less explicit than `.stop.prevent`. I think this is the case where I'd prefer explicitness over typing several fewer characters.

author: bartlomieju
title: Add delimiters test
body:
ref #2872 

I think it should be somehow emphasized that if we want delimiters to be changed globally we should define `Vue.options.delimiters`. Doing so in a constructor of our root instance will not have effect (check out 'delimiters should only affect vm' spec). I guess this is desirable, for most of users rely on default delimiters, and we want to be able to use 3rd party plugins.

author: bopjesvla
title: Add support for v-bind:content shorthand, including namespaced attributes (supersedes #2858)
body:
I originally submitted this as a PR to phanan's #2858, but that's probably more trouble than it's worth. This PR includes phanan's original PR:

> With this commit, v-bind with an empty expression will imply the expression to be the directive name, i.e. v-bind :content will have the same effect as v-bind:content="content", :href will have the same effect as :href="href" and so on so forth. Note that only attribute bindings are affected by this change. Event, transition, class/style bindings etc. remain untouched.
> 
> Not sure if I'm missing anything here ‚Äì all unit tests passed fine, though. Let me know if there's anything to fix or improve, or just close this PR if you don't intend to support the feature.

But it also includes support and tests for attributes with non-word characters other than hyphens as described here:

> Something I just thought of: v-bind:data-content and v-bind:ns:attr should be equivalent to v-bind:data-content="dataContent" and v-bind:ns:attr="nsAttr", respectively.
comments:
I like this!
Took me some time to respond this because I am not really a fan of this proposal but it wasn't immediately clear to me what turned me off. I tried it out and it just felt weird to me:

``` html
<comp :a :b></comp>
```

Now I realize it's because of the semantic implication of HTML attributes that have no values - they are usually boolean attributes. An attribute with no value indicates the "presence of an attribute" or "truthiness". Implicitly expanding to a binding overloads this perception.

In addition - if a prop in the child component is declared with type `Boolean`, the presence of the attribute indicates a true value. This would cause `prop` and `:prop` to have very different meanings, and is technically a breaking change.
Forgot to mention though - thanks to both @phanan and @bopjesvla for taking a stab at implementing this. Appreciate your effort and sorry for the late response.
üëç Perfect explanation, thanks Evan.

Edit: Note to self: From now on, whenever I see the word "imply" in my PR, I'll need to take a step back and think twice ;)
Zen of python, "explicit is better than implicit" ;)
The solution @sirlancelot proposed in #5835 seems like it should be in this thread:

> If you're using ES6 already (via webpack's vue-loader), you can try
`<my-component v-bind="{ propA, propB, propC }"`>

author: dennisreimann
title: add ssr example
body:
this is not finished yet, as I could not get the hydration part to work. the server-side rendering works fine, but somehow the radio button bindings for the `currentBranch` do not seem to work after hydration.

I'd like to get you opinion on whether or not it makes sense to add this example at the current pre-alpha stage. I think it would be great to have a resource for ssr, as there is not much documentation about it yet ‚Äì¬†I grabbed most of what is in my example from the tests.

If you think this would be a nice addition, can you provide some info on how to make it work?
comments:
Thanks! I think it is probably still to early to have an example, since some of the details and API may still be subject to change. (also need tests for hydration, yes) I think it's better to do this after we enter beta, but I'd appreciate any information on what's not working with hydration at this moment.
Thanks for your answer :)

Well, I'm pretty sure it's me not understanding this correctly or missing something. The [created hook](https://github.com/vuejs/vue/pull/2871/commits/1706ad3b7d8442be781883afae0142ab5d3054c0#diff-16cdbc0c23582da9088930a897ce0e93R18) fires on the client-side, which means the basic setup should be working. I expected `$data` to be populated with [what I set on the server](https://github.com/vuejs/vue/pull/2871/commits/1706ad3b7d8442be781883afae0142ab5d3054c0#diff-a3310005786536aaf72e324eef49cee7R72), but it is `undefined`. (in the current state of the code I tried to set `data` in the app.js, but you can ignore that)

The currentBranch binding also does not seem to work, as changes do not trigger the watch ‚Äì¬†but as I said, I guess t is just me doing something wrong here. That's why I'd be really thankful if you could provide some guidance or point me to the right places in the vue code or test, so I can dig around for myself... even though this is early stage I'd like to get this to work and provide an example others could use to figure out, how ssr and hydration will work :)

Thanks again!

P.S.: In case you would like to try the example, start the server with `node run.js` in the commits-ssr example directory.
Thanks to @moerssl I got it working now - as I guessed it was just me not understanding fully how it is supposed to work. I'll close this PR for now as we have extracted the example into a separate repository, which can be found at https://github.com/dennisreimann/vue-spike :)

author: phanan
title: Add support for v-bind:content shorthand (fixes #2843)
body:
I personally quite like the feature request #2843, so I went ahead and try to support it. 

With this commit, `v-bind` with an empty expression will imply the expression to be the directive name, i.e. `v-bind :content` will have the same effect as `v-bind:content="content"`, `:href` will have the same effect as `:href="href"` and so on so forth. Note that only attribute bindings are affected by this change. Event, transition, class/style bindings etc. remain untouched. 

Not sure if I'm missing anything here ‚Äì all unit tests passed fine, though. Let me know if there's anything to fix or improve, or just close this PR if you don't intend to support the feature.
comments:
Nice! Something I just thought of: `v-bind:data-content` and `v-bind:ns:attr` should be equivalent to `v-bind:data-content="dataContent"` and `v-bind:ns:attr="nsAttr"`, respectively. I can submit a PR to your PR for that.

A second thing, which may be out of the scope of this PR: it'd be nice if custom directives had the ability to enable this behaviour.
> `v-bind:data-content` and `v-bind:ns:attr` should be equivalent to `v-bind:data-content="dataContent"` and `v-bind:ns:attr="nsAttr"`

You're right, I overlooked these (especially the first part). Happy to receive your PR. @yyx990803 may or may not approve this feature btw.
> v-bind:ns:attr="nsAttr"

Is namespacing with colons an accepted syntax with Vue? Not sure if that would be accepted.
@phanan Should we close this PR in favour of #2877 ?
Sure. I don't think @yyx990803 is a fan of this change, though.
All the more reason to not have two PR's about it :-P
comments_review:
Are you sure about this? We don't want this to happen when the value is `null` or `undefined`?
I'm not sure if this is what you mean, but `value` is the expression, not the return value of the expression. So you can still do `v-bind:content="null"`.
You're right, that's the rawValue. My bad!

author: Jinjiang
title: [next][advice]new render mechanism
body:
In web the best practise of first time rendering is just append the whole dom tree once into the body. But in some other virtual dom situation like mobile web or native app, the first time rendering is not as fast as users' expectation. So I tried to make "a little" change to implement "stream rendering" to optimize the first-screen perf. And let it be able to append the whole dom tree either once or node-by-node:
1. changed `__h__(tag, data, children)` into `__r__(__s__(tag, data), children)` so the parent node could be calculate->generate->append first and the children later.
2. supported `stream: true` option and added a new `__stream_patch__` method besides `__patch__` to optimize the first-time rendering logic. If no `stream: true` option set, just render as normal before.
3. supported `atom: true` in `vnode.data` to describe whether this node will be appended with its children together as a atom or child-by-child in "stream rendering" mode.

Additionally, I changed the `class`/`staticClass` from string to array and added an object `staticStyle` for better virtual dom control.
comments:
There are multiple changes (streaming, class changes, style changes) mixed in this big PR, making it harder to review and merge. We should split them into smaller PRs, each addressing a specific issue.

Also re streaming mode: since this feature is very platform-specific, I wonder if it's possible to implement it in a less intrusive / more decoupled fashion. The concern is that these features will mostly be used for weex, but weex itself doesn't live in this repo, so coordinating changes between the two projects will become problematic in the long run.

Ideally, weex-specific feature requirements should live in weex and should be able to be iterated on without relying on Vue core to pull in the changes. One possible approach to achieve that is implementing the minimal changes required in core to expose an interface that allows a platform to customize the patching/codegen process. That might be difficult in the short term, but this patch as it is just seems to be coupling the two projects too much with serious maintenance cost.
Yes your concern is true. My point is that there is no way to get streaming mode based on `__h__`. I can try to make another smaller pr to use `__r__` & `__s__` only but no streaming mode and atom option.

Another thing I think the `class` & `style` process is too tricky for web, not general enough. So another small discuss or pr will be made later.
We have recently introduced a VUE_ENV environment variable. You may be able
to aid support for this by using this.

This way we can opitimize the build to use cases. As Evan said this is
aimed mainly to Weex or other native code implementations, so being able to
target the functionality may be of favour.

On Thu, 12 May 2016 06:17 Âãæ‰∏âËÇ°Âõõ, notifications@github.com wrote:

> Yes your concern is true. My point is that there is no way to get
> streaming mode based on **h**. I can try to make another smaller pr to
> use **r** & **s** only but no streaming mode and atom option.
> 
> Another thing I think the class & style process is too tricky for web,
> not general enough. So another small discuss or pr will be made later.
> 
> ‚Äî
> You are receiving this because you are subscribed to this thread.
> Reply to this email directly or view it on GitHub
> https://github.com/vuejs/vue/pull/2854#issuecomment-218662310
Thx. I will have a check about VUE_ENV

title: fix dynamic Style's position should be located in before static Style
comments:
why does this matter?
Same as class, Look neat.
I intentionally put it at the end so that it doesn't matter if the inline style has an ending `;` or not.

Putting it first you may end up with two `;;` so you will have to check for an ending `;` - this can be avoided by just placing static styles last.

title: use absolute exclude path in `build/webpack.test.config.js` and fix error when recursively traverse an object
body:
- use absolute path to make sure running tests is OK even if it is in node_modules of other project

author: phanan
title: Support for mutiple class names as key (close #2571)
body: This commit adds support for using multiple class names as key when specifying a `:class` object, for example `<div :class="{ 'a b c': flag }">`. Previously, doing so will trigger an uncaught InvalidCharacterError, as spaces are not allowed in DOM tokens. Feature request #2571 should also be satisfied by this commit.

Oh right. I'll look into that.
Let me close this and use a proper, updated, branch instead.

author: skyronic
title: Proof of concept: Detect writing to non-reactive properties
body:
This is very very early proof of concept right now. If a property in a data object is written to while it's not reactive, a warning is shown. This will later be used only in debug mode, but I haven't added a debug mode check yet. The code will be re-written cleanly once it's confirmed working.

Note: this uses no dirty checking and instead uses ES6 proxies, which is supported only on latest chrome and firefox. 

Need help with this:
- Pull my branch `reactive-warn` into your repo.
- edit `changewatch/index.html` with updates 
- find false positives, etc. Things when it should show warnings but doesn't. Or other edge cases.

Example: 
![screen shot 2016-03-24 at 9 49 58 am](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/80173/14008350/e1fa4514-f1a5-11e5-9e4c-0ec3ad1fdac5.png)
comments:
I like the idea - but one problem with proxies is that they become different references and would break cases where the user is doing equality comparisons...
Sigh :( you're right. i confirmed that reference equality isn't preserved.

On the bright side i did learn quite a bit about vue internals from this exercise. I really think this would be a great feature. I am currently out of ideas and am stashing this. Please do see if you can get a nice solution for this problem :) 

Closing PR.

author: rowanwins
title: Adding beforeAttach and beforeDetach event handlers including tests
body:
This is a followup pull request on #2526 which aims to implement the beforeAttach and beforeDetach features discussed in #1469 .

Let me know if anything further is required.
comments:
Looking good! Will take one last pass later today to make sure everything is covered :+1: 
Can you please add to the commit description `Fix #1469` so it also closes the issue?
Gday @yyx990803 just checking that you saw I updated this as per your suggestion, hopefully it's close now :)
@rowanwins it is - it's just this PR has a bit more moving pieces than others so I want to be extra careful. It will probably be part of 1.1 instead of the next patch release, so please be patient :)
Gday @yyx990803 , so Im thinking this pull request may not be required if the [Vue 2.0 write up](https://github.com/vuejs/vue/wiki/2.0-features) is anything to go by... Anyway no biggie if that's the case, was good to poke around in the source and I'm looking forward to seeing what v2 brings :)

Cheers
Rowan
Hey @rowanwins - apologies for letting this PR hang for so long.

In v2, `attached` and `detached` are indeed no longer supported. This is mainly due to their usefulness not justifying the amount of complexity in ensuring correct behavior for these hooks. Given that, `beforeAttach` and `beforeDetach` obviously are not needed as well.

For v1, it would be less than ideal to introduce two hooks that are soon to be gone in v2, so unfortunately that means we will probably have to let this PR go. I know you've put a lot of work into it, so I do want to thank you for that and say sorry ;'(
comments_review:
Is `beforeDetach` missing here?
should check `shouldCallRemove` here too
need to check `shouldCallRemove`
@vuchl it looked like this series of tests was for monitoring adding stuff to the DOM, rather the the removal aspect but I could be wrong...

author: rowanwins
title: beforeDetach hook
body:
Hi,

I've made a start on implementing a fix for  #1469  . Im not convinced I've nailed it 100% but I thought I'd submit what I've got for feedback and direction.

I also need to prepare a test although I've not worked with jasmine or e2e so that'll take a little bit of digging but I'll attempt to get that up and running tomorrow evening.

Cheers
Rowan
comments:
Hi!
That's cool, thanks for the feature. Do you need some help with tests or are you fine on your own?
Thanks @posva I'll have a shot myself over the next few days and get back to you if I get stuck.
Gday @posva I've had a shot at adding something into the tests although Im not sure if what I've added is sufficient.

Oh and I attempted to squash some of my commits but everything got a bit messy sorry and I dont think I actually achieved anything :( 
If you'd like I can kill off this pull request and create a fresh tidy one now that I now what I'm doing a bit more
@rowanwins @posva hey! Should I add the hook into the docs?
Hey @rowanwins - thank you very much for the PR.

The attach/detach hooks are a bit more complicated than it seems. In particular:
- Fragments (the partial compilation construct used internally by `v-for` and `v-if`) also needs to call attach/detach for components contained inside it: https://github.com/vuejs/vue/blob/dev/src/fragment/fragment.js
- lifecycle hooks need proper merging strategy to be defined in [here](https://github.com/vuejs/vue/blob/dev/src/util/options.js#L122-L139)
- we also need the `beforeAttach` counterpart.

Of course this is probably larger than the scope you created this PR for - if you are up for implementing the whole thing, great! But it's absolutely fine if you feel it's too much for you to take on, we can get this specific PR merged and work on top of your improvements :)
Thanks for the comprehensive feedback @yyx990803 , I've had a go at incorporating all your suggestions and it looks like I've even managed to get the tests passing!

If you'd like to to close this pull request and reopen a new one with only 1 commit let me know, Im aware this one is a bit messy, Im still a rookie when it comes to this git stuff!
Nice! Yes 1 commit would be ideal - you can actually just reset/squash into 1 commit and then force push - it will update this PR.
@rowanwins Hey, sorry for not coming back at you. I have nothing more to add :smile: 
@fullfs That'd be great!
I'm closing this in favour of a fresh pull request will only 1 commit, stay tuned!
comments_review:
no need for the if check here - `_callHook` would be a no-op if the hook does not exist.
Also the hook name should be `beforeDetach` (as in `beforeDestroy` and `destroyed`)
this line is not needed because hooks are already called by `_callHook`
should be `child._callHook('beforeDetach')` here.

author: crswll
title: visiblity modifier for v-show
body: I saw #2382 and figured I'd give contributing a shot. I'm almost certain I followed the guidelines but if I didn't let me know.
comments:
Thanks @crswll - sorry I didn't communicate this clearly, I didn't think adding a modifier to `v-show` was the best way to approach this. What he wanted can simply be solved by using a CSS class to toggle the element's opacity with CSS transitions.
I asked https://github.com/vuejs/vue/issues/2382#issuecomment-188131890 because `opacity: 0` and `visibility: hidden` do not produce identical results. Namely, content with `opacity: 0` is interactive (links and buttons can be clicked, inputs are focusable), while content with `visibility: hidden` is not.

`opacity: 0; pointer-events: none` produces similar result to `visibility: hidden`, but only works in IE11+.

Thus I believe a directive for toggling `visibility` instead of `display` is handy, either in core or in ecosystem.
Ah I got you. I was just thinking in terms of getting the transitions right. Honestly I was just kind of bored and wanted to see if I can do it! 
@simplesmiler ah that's true. That's why I exposed the transition API though. With that you can easily write your own `v-visible` directive.

author: brentguf
title: Suggestion for new section in README
body:
To make Vue.js more approachable to a larger number of users‚Äîfrom informed developers to curious passersby and new and interested visitors‚Äî and help them decide whether Vue.js will fit their needs more quickly, I have added a new section to the Vue.js README. 

The section is entitled What to Use Vue.js for and When to Use It. As the name suggests, the new section, a brief paragraph, explains in plain and straightforward language what Vue.js is used for and when one should consider using Vue.js.
comments: Hi @brentguf , thanks a lot for this PR - please see https://github.com/vuejs/vue/pull/2303#issuecomment-180528160 for an explanation - the README is intentionally kept short.

author: meowwwls
title: Add non-developer-friendly description to README.md
body:
As someone who is currently a web development student, I often find it difficult to quickly understand what certain libraries and frameworks set out to accomplish when reading the technical introductions, or to imagine a real-world use case for the technology.

I have written what I hope is a clear, easy to understand, basic introduction to what Vue.js does at its core, one that I hope will be useful to everyone, whether they are seasoned developers, new programmers, or non-technical visitors. The goal is to help expose Vue.js to a broader range of users who at first might otherwise be confused by the more technical, thorough overview.
comments:
Hi, thanks for the PR, and I appreciate the effort in making it more non-dev friendly. However, I intentionally kept the README short and succinct so that people don't miss the points.

Detailed intro can be found on the Vue.js documentation website: http://vuejs.org/guide/overview.html , which provides a very similar explanation. I'd be happy to take a pull request that adds a link to these sections in README instead of pulling in full paragraphs. Thanks!

comments: Thanks for the PR. I believe all DOM APIs automatically apply JavaScript type coercions when DOMString is expected, so when the underlying native method is called, the value has already been coerced. author: Gerhut
title: Feature: warn when mounting to body.
body: [BrowserSync](http://browsersync.io/) sometimes failed when mounting vue instance to `document.body`. Although I have not recognized where the specific cause is, it recovered when mounting to a child element. Whatever, I think warning about this issue is a good idea. Moreover, React [warned about it](https://github.com/facebook/react/blob/3b96650e39ddda5ba49245713ef16dbc52d25e9e/src/renderers/dom/client/ReactMount.js#L398-L406) as well (Discussion: facebook/react#3207)
comments:
[Vue already warns if an instance is mounted to body with `replace: true`](https://github.com/vuejs/vue/blob/dev/src/compiler/transclude.js#L79-L85). Mounting without `replace: true` shouldn't cause problems because it leaves `document.body` untouched. I'd be more interested in figuring out what is actually causing BrowserSync to fail.
OK, I will continue working on it.
