author: jeremyfa
title: make Vue work on node env that forbid `new Function` (ie. Atom)
body:
_Vue_ is excellent at making UI in a simple and expressive way. I wanted to use it to create UI inside an Atom plugin, but Atom environment doesn't allow to use `eval` or `new Function()`.

This pull request provides an alternate implementation of `Function` based on node.js `vm` module when the native `Function` doesn't work. These changes make _Vue_ work fine on Atom (and similar node.js based environment that may have forbidden `new Function()`)

I ran browserify and webpack over the modified project, so far it doesn't break.

EDIT: I saw the csp-compliant build, which works on Atom as well, but when available, the `vm` based implementation may be more efficient than `notevil.Function`.
comments:
Mmmh, seems that I don't respect the indentation. I will fix that.
Well, still having issues. I will look into what I have broken -_-. Stay tuned.
On my side the modified `vue.js` still works just fine in the browser. Not sure if we should worry about the failed tests, that are skipped in the `dev` branch. Should we?
I might have misunderstood purpose of this PR, but.. have you checked **csp** branch? https://github.com/vuejs/vue/releases/tag/v1.0.11-csp
Yes thanks! Just edited the first post of this PR: I did see the **csp** branch, but the `vm` based implementation, when available (node.js/atom) should be more efficient than parsing AST with pure javascript.

Using `vm.runInThisContext` (it's what `loophole` is doing) will create a first class js function _vs_ evaluating AST at every call. I am wondering if it could be considered to use it in that case?
Thanks for this PR, but I don't think this should be part of the main distributed build of Vue.

On the other hand, the advantage of CSP build is that it can be used in environments that enforces CSP but do not have a Node runtime (e.g. Chrome apps).

It may indeed be the most efficient solution in Electron-based environments like Atom. But that's a really narrow use case. I think this could either be used as a fork or a special branch like `vm`.
Yes, makes sense.

The `vm` branch might be a good option (also to be able to do something like `npm install vue@vm`).

I guess for now I will use a fork.

Thanks for the feedback!

author: tilleps
title: Fix package module ID / Cannot find module "vue"
body:
Getting errors while trying to install via npm:

```
npm install vue
```

Was able to install the github version via:

```
npm install vuejs/vue#dev
```

However, I got the following error:

```
Error: Cannot find module 'vue'
```

Looks like the package.json main is pointing to a non-existing file:
`dist/vue.common.js`

I checked both `dev` and `master` branch, neither had the file.  This PR is removing
`dist/vue.common.js` from files and updating the package main to point to `dist.vue.js`
comments:
Thanks, `vue.common.js` is only built and distributed with the npm module.

See updated instructions on using latest source code: http://vuejs.org/guide/installation.html#Dev_Build

author: huangyifu
title: add orderByKeys function
comments:
Thanks for the PR.

Please note that Vue.js core intentionally limits the functionality it provides to keep its size small. Therefore we only provide the most commonly-used filter functions as default ones. If the users need a highly custom sorting algorithm, they can just implement it as a custom filter or a computed property.

The basic idea is, we want avoid shipping code that adds size but only get used in a few very specific scenarios. So unfortunately I don't think we should add yet another sorting filter.

---

Additionally, please make sure to follow the code style and pass the lint/test build flow before submitting PRs.

author: karevn
title: Added reverse filter support for v-for
body: An implementation for this issue: https://github.com/vuejs/vue/issues/1433
comments_review:
I think splitting this here makes the code harder to follow. It's ok that this check stay in the watcher.
Not sure about the method name here. There's no "bubbling" here - maybe something like `syncChanges`?
Yep, you're right.
It's more about responsibilities, IMO. Written this way, misc.js mixin is responsible for both forward and reverse filters, and abstracts forContext existence from the watcher.

Also, `alias === expression` does not look nice (because I easily bypassed this logic in my initial fiddle), so the logic will probably grow and I definitely don't want to put it to watcher (because it is not its responsibility) or for directive (to keep reverse filtering logic reusable just for a case). Any ideas?
When I saw `scope._bubbleChanges` it's a bit confusing, because this is a v-for-scope-only thing, but is attached to Vue's prototype, which imo is the wrong place. It only works because of the prototypal inheritance.
As for expression check - a reverse write should be applied as long as the expression starts with the alias. e.g. `item.test` and `item[test]` both should trigger reverse write. So you need a regular expression, e.g. `new RegExp(alias + '\\b')`. To be more efficient we might want to construct this regex right when we parse the alias in `v-for`.

author: nkovacs
title: Add mixed type properties.
body:
Literal property auto-casting now respects property type(s),
and will not cast a property to boolean or number if it
cannot be a boolean or number.

Fixes #1284, #1148 

There were a few special cases that are a bit different for mixed types, but it should be backwards compatible:
- `default` will always be called even if one of the types is `Function`. But if the only type is `Function`, it won't be called, like before. In practice it probably doesn't makes sense to have a property that can be either a Function or something else.
- If the default is not specified and the property is omitted, the default is undefined, except for Boolean, where it is false. For a mixed type, the default will be undefined even if one of the possible types is Boolean. It might make sense to use false as the default here, but in practice both are falsy, and you can specify a default, so it's not a big issue.
- In contrast to the previous point, if one of the possible types is Boolean (explicitly specified), and the attribute value is omitted (or is an empty string), it will be cast to true, even if String is also an accepted type for the property. This is how it worked previously for Boolean type properties, so I extended that to mixed properties that include Boolean. It made more sense for a property without a value to be true in this case, instead of a falsy empty string.

For example:

```
prop1: [Boolean, String]
prop2: String

<example></example> <!-- undefined undefined -->
<example prop1 prop2></example> <!-- true, '' -->
<example prop1="foo" prop2="foo"></example> <!-- 'foo' 'foo' -->
<example prop1="123" prop2="123"></example> <!-- '123' '123' -->
```
comments:
Hmm I didn't have time to respond to #1285, but with 1.0.0's syntax there's no longer the need for auto casting. Literal values are always strings; boolean and number literals need to be passed via dynamic bindings. The only auto-cast case is omitted value for Boolean props.

The ability to allow multiple types is a good improvement, but I think that should itself be a PR. Also, I somewhat prefer only auto-casting omitted value when Boolean is the only expected type.
>  with 1.0.0's syntax there's no longer the need for auto casting

Why not? For example with `<example prop="123"></example>`, if prop's type is just Number, there's no harm in auto-casting it. Not auto-casting would mean this would not pass validation, and require people to use binding, even though they're not binding to a variable. That feels like a workaround for a bug to me.
Similarly, if the type is [Number, String, Boolean], the user has opted into it, so auto-casting would not cause surprise.
You could disable auto-casting when the type is not specified, but I kept it enabled for backwards compatibility, and because you said in #1148 that most people expect auto-casting.

> I somewhat prefer only auto-casting omitted value when Boolean is the only expected type

What about when the type is [Boolean, Number]? Empty string isn't allowed there, so it makes sense to  cast to true.
The alternative is to auto-cast to true if Boolean is an allowed type, unless String is also an allowed type. But I think it's simpler and more consistent to always auto-cast to true if Boolean is a possible type.
In 1.0.0 `prop="123"` is a literal, thus it is expected to pass "123" as a literal string. If we do autocast, the user would have to do `bind-prop="'123'"` in order to pass the string, which is less intuitive imo. "Literal syntax = string" is a much easier rule to remember.

I'd like to treat multiple types as "any one of these types is allowed". Omitting value = true is a behavior that is strongly tied to boolean attributes only - if the user wants to use this syntax, then the prop needs to be Boolean and Boolean only. Casting it when multiple types are allowed only makes the rules more complicated than necessary.
> If we do autocast, the user would have to do bind-prop="'123'" in order to pass the string, which is less intuitive imo.

Not if the property's type is just String. This would also mean you could never use literals with Number or Boolean properties, it would always fail validation.

The only case where the value is ambiguous is with mixed properties that include String, e.g. `[String, Number]` - should it auto-cast to Number or not? I'm in favor of auto-casting, since you opted into it, and you probably don't want something that looks like a number to be a string if you explicitly said that you accept a number.

For type=null, I could change it to treat it as `[String]` instead of the current backwards compatible behavior. That way by default literal properties would always be strings, and you'd have to opt into casting.

>  Omitting value = true is a behavior that is strongly tied to boolean attributes only - if the user wants to use this syntax, then the prop needs to be Boolean and Boolean only.

If the type doesn't include String, the empty string will create an error, so you can't omit the value. It's an unnecessary restriction. 
For example:

``` js
props: {
  centered: {
    type: [Number, Boolean]
    default: false // not centered by default
  }
}
```

``` html
<column centered></column> <!-- centered === true, i.e. use default width -->
<column centered="3"></column> <!-- centered === 3, explicit width -->
<column></column> <!-- centered === false -->
```

Also this doesn't happen for type=null, so you have to opt into it by listing Boolean as one of the possible values.
The only ambiguity is with `[String, Boolean]` and such, but you can look at that from both sides, for example:

``` html
<example highlighted></example> <!-- use default highlighting -->
<example highlighted="true"></example> <!-- use default highlighting -->
<example highlighted="green"></example> <!-- use green highlighting -->
<example></example> <!-- no highlighting -->
```

If empty string is not cast to true, in this case, the first example would be `'' == false` which is wrong.

A possible solution is to allow the property to specify the value for when the value is empty, e.g.:

``` js
props: {
  highlighted: {
    type: [String, Boolean],
    default: false,
    empty: true,
    validator: function(value) {
      // only allow predefined colors
      return ["green", "blue", "red", true, false].indexOf(value) !== -1;
    }
  }
}
```
The issue I have with your proposal is that the same syntax, e.g. `prop="123"`, will result in different values based on the component's prop type expectations. The consumer of the component will need to understand these complex conversion rules (A only gets casted into B when the props expects type A & B together...) in order to infer what eventual value something will be casted into.

In comparison, a simpler rule set is:
1. `prop="xxx"`: always a string.
2. `:prop="xxx"`: always an expression. `123`, `true` and `false` should use this as well.
3. `prop`: only true when the type is boolean. A special case, but makes sense and easy to tell.
That's true. But I don't think it's a big problem, you already have to know what the component expects when you're using it, so that you don't try to pass a number in a literal property.
The only uncertainty occurs when you're reading a template and you don't know the component's property rules.
Anyway, I can't remove the auto-casting from this, since that would break the expected behavior in 0.12. I'll rework the pull request for 1.0
Thanks, closing this for now.

author: karevn
title: Added throttle util and filter
body: Hello! I think this small addition will be helpful for some cases (at least it was really helpful for my current project).
comments:
Thanks for the PR - can you give some more information on the actual use case? e.g. what type of UI are you using this for?
I am building a "custom cursor" thingie, which should only be displayed when hovering over specific areas of the app. So, I need to check if I should display a custom cursor or default one based on `jQuery(el).closest('bla-blah').size()` call result, which is expensive. But, I don't need an immediate reaction, so if I throttle the event to be only fired once in 100msec - all works fine.

So basically, this thing will be useful for working with mouseover / scroll events when they should be fired "in-between" the action.
is this still open/valid?
It's just sitting and waiting :)
Hey, sorry for letting this sit for so long. The reason I hesitated and decided not to merging this: it's adding weight to the library for a very edge use case, which can be easily implemented as a userland thing. In comparison, `debounce` is in core because it is commonly used on input with `v-model` and there's no easy way for a user to implement that for `v-model`.

Again, thanks for the PR.
comments_review: :clap:

author: karevn
title: Debounce filter
body: An implementation for event debounce filter inspired by this thread: https://github.com/vuejs/Discussion/issues/245
comments:
Btw, why not to make `_.debounce` available as Vue global function?
@karevn it is available as `Vue.util.debounce`.
Actually, I just realized this PR is merging to `master` - could you please open a new one based on `dev` instead?
This PR itself is trying to merge into `master`, but `master` only holds the latest stable release; all PRs should be submitted against `dev`. I don't think you can change the target branch of an open PR, so you will have to make a new one (and preferably make clean commits on top of `dev`)
https://github.com/yyx990803/vue/pull/1145
comments_review:
This implementation doesn't pass on the arguments the handler gets. In fact you can just use the internal `_.debounce` to wrap the handler.
make sure to test receiving proper arguments here

author: pespantelis
title: Hide directive
body: It is the opposite of `show` directive.
comments:
Doesn't this make API more verbose and add more size to library? Why not just `v-show="!show"`?
IMO `v-hide="show"` is more clean and readable from `v-show="!show"`.
Regarding the library, it is increased less than half of KB.
Thanks for the PR, but let me explain why I don't want to add `v-hide`: the general philosophy behind Vue is we want to keep it as lightweight as possible, so when we add code into the codebase, we want to make sure the code either provides substantial improvement to an existing feature, or adds a new functionality that cannot be trivially achieved with the current API. In general, we want to avoid adding code just for the sake of stylistic alternatives. In fact we have been trying to removing stylistic alternatives as much as possible (e.g. `v-with` vs `props`).

`v-hide`, in my opinion, is just a stylistic alternative to `v-show`, and its benefit over `v-show` is somehow subjective and marginal.

Regardless, I appreciate your effort and hope to see you contributing to Vue again in the future :)
Thank you for the detailed explanation :)

author: janschoenherr
title: allow for object definitions as filter arguments
body:
I would like to propose a change to the filter token regex. This will allow for object definitions to be passed as a single argument to the filter. This will only work for shallow objects. For deep objects we would have to use a better parser.

e.g.:

```
{{ '%count% Pull Requests' | trans {count: count} }}
```

currently it works without spaces only:

```
{{ '%count% Pull Requests' | trans {count:count} }}
```
comments:
How would the filter implementation work in this case? Do you `JSON.parse` the thing?
In the custom filter '_trans_' , currently I am using the Vue expression parser to evaluate the expression.

That way _{count:count}_ will actually evaluate to a hash like _{count: 3}_, which is then passed to the translation function.

author: zhongxingdou
title: data define support getter and setter
comments:
It's actually possible to support real ES5 getter/setters by using `getOwnPropertyDescriptor`, but I decided not to do that because:
1. Performance concerns;
2. Vue's data objects are meant to be static, which means they should be JSON.stringify compliant so that they can be easily persisted to the backend.

For dynamic view state we have computed properties. Do you think there are use cases that getter/setters on the data object can be particularly useful?

author: rrrene
title: Add docs badge to README
body:
Hi Evan,

I want to propose to add this badge to the README to show off inline-documentation: [![Inline docs](http://inch-ci.org/github/yyx990803/vue.svg)](http://inch-ci.org/github/yyx990803/vue)

The badge links to [Inch CI](http://inch-ci.org) and shows an evaluation by [InchJS](http://trivelop.de/inchjs), a project that tries to raise the visibility of inline-docs. Besides testing and other coverage, documenting your code is often neglected although it is a very engaging part of Open Source.

So far over 500 **Ruby** projects are sporting these badges to raise awareness for the importance of inline-docs and to show potential contributors that they can expect a certain level of code documentation when they dive into your project's code and motivate them to eventually document their own.

I would really like to do the same for the **JavaScript** community and roll out support for JS over the coming weeks (early adopters are [forever](https://github.com/foreverjs/forever), [node-sass](https://github.com/sass/node-sass) and [Shipit](https://github.com/shipitjs/shipit)).

Although this is "only" a passion project, I really would like to hear your thoughts, critique and suggestions. Your status page is http://inch-ci.org/github/yyx990803/vue

What do you think?

author: dannydulai
title: support for js File array in the model of a <input type="file">
body:
The input type='file' doesnt have a element.value like the rest of the inputs, and it pretty much always operates like a lazy input.

All this change does is make the model populated by the element's File array in element.files, so then you can use FileReader or whatever else to get the contents of the file that was marked for uploading, including it's size and filename and path.
comments:
in the meanwhile, my workaround is:

1) add a `v-el` to your input: `<input v-el='myfileinput' type='file'>`
2) add this to your viewmodel: `compiled: function() var self = this; this.$$.myfileinput.onchange = function(e) { self.files = self.$$.myfileinput.files; }`
3) then you can access `files` on your model to get the files array
Sorry for leaving this one hanging for so long - we will likely revisit input[type="file"] handling post 1.0, so closing this.
comments_review:
It should be noted that `el.files` is a `FileList` object which is array-like, but not really an array (thus when stringifying it looks different from a stringified array). The items inside are also `File` objects. In theory you should only be putting plain objects in the vm's data, so maybe we need to process `el.files` into a proper array of plain objects here.
Oh, but doing that would make it un-passable to other browser APIs, thus making it useless. I think you are missing the point here. File, Blob, ArrayBuffer... they are all objects that live inside the browser's implementation, and not just a JSON object you can fiddle with. They are native, you can't serialize them.
The point is Vue will try to convert the object properties into getter/setters and they may or may not break these native objects, which we need to test. And if we skip conversion for these objects, they won't be able to be used for data-binding.

author: boussou
title: Update dom.js
body: I had to do this to fix exceptions on target (undefined). I don't really see why or when it happens (was not happening on v0.10.6)
comments:
Do you have more info on where this error is happening? Does this patch give you expected behavior? Sorry for the lack of details. It is ultra standard vue usage, with a view object attached to a parent div of the following (I used config to replace mustache style by brackets) ``` html
[[conPlace]]
[[conDate]]
``` there is ajax call during "created" event that updates the model (ajax errors are correclty handled) I had exceptions in that function (value undefined for target) during the vue creation, ending up in no binding at all. Adding this code removes errors, and the data binding works I got this stacktrace ``` exports.replace (vue.js:2161) textNodeLinkFn (vue.js:4966) childLinkFn (vue.js:5014) childLinkFn (vue.js:5017) childLinkFn (vue.js:5017) childLinkFn (vue.js:5017) childLinkFn (vue.js:5017) childLinkFn (vue.js:5017) childLinkFn (vue.js:5017) childLinkFn (vue.js:5017) childLinkFn (vue.js:5017) link (vue.js:4759) exports._compile (vue.js:1674) exports.$mount (vue.js:968) exports._init (vue.js:1260) Vue (vue.js:81) (anonymous function) (app.js:594) n.Callbacks.j (jquery.min.js:2) n.Callbacks.k.fireWith (jquery.min.js:2) n.extend.ready (jquery.min.js:2) K (jquery.min.js:2) ``` versions: Vue.js v0.11.4 jQuery v1.11.0 in function "exports.replace = function (target, el) " ligne 2160 JSON.stringify(this) gives--> {"hasProto":true,"inBrowser":true,"isIE9":false,"transitionProp":"transition","transitionEndEvent":"transitionend","animationProp":"WebkitAnimation","animationEndEvent":"webkitAnimationEnd"}" el gives--> #document-fragment --> parent: undefined target: undefined It's still a bit hard to identify what is really wrong here, since your code sample alone seems to be working fine. I feel that simply checking `target` existence in the replace function doesn't address the root cause. I'd appreciate it if you could provide a live reproduction of the error. Closing (inactivity)

author: skovhus
title: Added v-style support for objects (dev branch)
body:
`v-style` directive now supports objects, see #578

I will have a look at updating the documentation: https://github.com/vuejs/vuejs.org
comments: @yyx990803 When looking at the documentation I'm actually wondering what the use case is for "When there is no argument, Vue.js will use the value to set el.style.cssText." Why would we set `cssText` if the argument cannot be found in the model? Say ``, where `foo` is not found in the model, then we would update the `styleText` to `color`. Is there a use case for this, or is it a feature that should be removed? I see that `v-style="font-size: foo +'px'"` creates a data binding, so when `foo` is updated, the style reflects the change. When using an object with `v-style`, then changing properties in the object, the style is not changed. It only works if `foo` is a computed property. It this as expected? re: no argument - the argument is the plain string before the colon (e.g. `color`). No argument means using it like `v-style="myCSSString"`. If the value is not an object, it could be a raw inline style string, e.g. `"color: red, width: 100%"` re: nested properties inside the object - that's something I also overlooked. To track nested properties we need to use a deep watcher, but previously there wasn't an easy interface to do that. I have added a new directive option `deep` in 1bbaab38bdbe53f7ec7e60d33393832eccf47440 so you can add `deep: true` for `v-style` to make it observe nested properties. (Make sure to rebase against latest commit) But would myCSSString in the Vues data? Or what is the case here? Do you think it makes sense to make it deep? Or should people just use computed? If `myCSSString` is not in data, it will be `undefined`. In that case it will simply be considered an empty string by the browser. Making it deep is fine, since it's easier for the users and the internal perf cost is the same as using computed. Asking them to use computed just for this feature sounds confusing. But if it is not in data, then I don't see any use case for this... I will look at doing it deep. Where should make the change? The user could have deleted the property from the model, in that case we need to remove any existing CSStext. Making it deep is simply adding `deep: true` in the directive definition. (You need to rebase on top of the latest `dev` branch commit) I will make the change for deep. Do you like the pull request? But still I don't see the use case for CssText... Is it if the property was in data, but was removed? In the case of ``` html ``` `spanStyles` can either be ``` js // object { color: 'red', font-weight: 'bold' } ``` or ``` js // plain string 'color: red, font-weight: old' ``` It's just for flexibility's sake. BTW the PR looks good, once you add `deep: true` and a test case for a nested property triggering update it should be good to merge. Cool. Thanks for explaining. @yyx990803 I've updated with deep support and a test for that. : ) Something went wrong while squashing this... The final pull request is here https://github.com/yyx990803/vue/pull/608/files (sorry for the confusion...)

author: moznion
title: Add click listener into checkbox directive to bind value
body:
Ignition order of `click` event and `change` event is dependent on implementation of browsers.

For example;
- Google Chrome:   `change` -> `click`
- Mozilla Firefox: `click` -> `change`

If `click` event is used on Firefox with `v-on` of current vue.js, it cannot use bound value by click.
So added click listener.

Could you review this?
comments:
Can you make a jsfiddle showing the different behaviors? Does the order of adding listeners affect the result? Adding the click listener in v-model would cause the listener to be triggered more than once, so we need to find another solution.
I've tested and it is indeed the case! However, if what you really need is the **changed data**, why not use `$watch` on the bound value instead of a click handler?
A simple example is given below (though you may not need any more).
http://jsfiddle.net/puhgdvjL/
Please try this on chrome and firefox. Probably each behaviors are different.

> However, if what you really need is the changed data, why not use `$watch` on the bound value instead of a click handler?

Yes, I agree with you. However if somebody use as this way, behavior differs depending on browsers. I feel it is weird, so wrote a patch, but it might be my overthinking...
I appreciate the PR, I'm just not sure if this should be handled by Vue, since the behavior will be different even without Vue.
Umm, now that you say that,  Vue might not be responsible for this matter.
For the present, I'll close this isssue.

Thank you so much!

author: rfkm
title: Support namespace prefixed arguments
body:
Hi, Evan. This PR is related to #253.
I think the fix 3180eab is not enough in some case.

See: http://jsfiddle.net/DL5gr/4/

This PR enables us to use v-attr with namespace prefixed arguments by escaping a colon.

Example: 

``` html
<image v-attr="xlink\:href: url" width="200px" height="200px"></image>
```

I think this solution is very ad-hoc, especially around `isXlink`.
If there is a smarter way, please suggest it.
comments:
If something is going to change I would suggest just treat _the last_ `:` as the  delimiter between argument and key path. It looks less ugly and is more common. 
+1 to @gaydenko's recommendation. `xlink\:href` is fairly hard to read.
Yep. The current parser always catches the first `:`. Need to tweak `Directive.parse()` to get around that. Supposedly you should be able to do `v-attr="'xlink:href': url"` but currently it's not working :/
Thank you for your suggestions.
Now I've implemented @gaydenko's solution.

@yyx990803
Yes, I noticed the syntax that uses single quotes (or double quotes).
I like @gaydenko's suggestion, but the quotes style seems to be more useful especially when users write own custom directives.
So I've implemented it too, but I'm not sure that this implementation is along with your intention. See test cases.
@yyx990803 Probably quotes styles mixing  (single and double ones in the same clause) is also slightly disturb that markup cleanness you prefer :) I guess a hash as a directive attribute value - as suggested in the `next` branch - is much more clean.
Nice one ! Got this twice
@rkworks sorry for late input on this, but I have built upon your work and integrated the namespace handling in 0.11's `v-attr`. Thank you very much for this PR!
That's great! I'm looking forward to the update :)
Me, too! Is there a release-date of 0.11?

author: wprater
title: fixed `v-repeat` directive where collection has 1
body:
If there is only 1 item in the collection, don't bother checking for other elements. `nextEl` does not exists and causes an exception.

I assume this would not affect a change in the model where a new collection also has a size of one, but it's a different object.  As the `vm.$reused` would not have been set?
comments:
Can you provide a fiddle where the error is thrown before the fix? There is a invisible comment node at the end no matter what length the collection has, and `nextEl` will point to that in the case of length = 1.
ahh, that's true.  However, the dom has been manipulated, but a third party carousel.  so we cannot count on the comment to be there any longer.

On Jun 23, 2014, at 2:02 PM, Evan You notifications@github.com wrote:

> Can you provide a fiddle where the error is thrown before the fix? There is a invisible comment node at the end no matter what length the collection has, and nextEl will point to that in the case of length = 1.
> 
> ‚Äî
> Reply to this email directly or view it on GitHub.
The comment node is essential for `v-repeat` to work properly. It is not recommended to modify DOM that is already being managed by Vue.

author: dmfilipenko
title: extend current data if exist
body: #297:fix extend current data if exist
comments:
This will cause the data shared between the parent and child vm to become out of sync.

For example, in the child if a property is changed then that change is not reflected in the parent. See [this example](http://jsfiddle.net/YqLx2/), which would fail with your changes applied.
@dlh i don't see any problem in showen example, can you please provide more specific case?
The linked example uses Vue 0.10.5. You need to run it with your modified version to see the problem.
As @dlh pointed out, `v-with` links the parent object and the child's `$data` by reference, so they are sharing the same object. Extending a new copy makes the two out of sync. I'd say the overwriting is expected behavior in this case.
So, what is the best way to create the components with predefined values? how I understand, now it is impossible?
You can either do multiple clause `v-with` to bind individual values from parent, or set values in your child component's `ready` hook.

author: th0r
title: Support for boolean HTML-attributes
body:
Current `v-attr` implementation doesn't support boolean attributes (e.g. `disabled`).
Here is the common use-case:

```
<button type="submit" v-attr="disabled: !submittionAllowed">
```

It doesn't work because `v-attr` uses `this.el.setAttribute` method. So, when `submittionAllowed` equals to `true`, then submit button will look like this:

```
<button type="submit" disabled="false">
```

...which is treated by browser as disabled button.
My proposal is to remove current attribute if it's value is falsy (except zero).
comments:
Hi Yuriy, great suggestion. If you have time, could you please make sure tests are updated and passed according to the [contribution guide](https://github.com/yyx990803/vue/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md)? Thanks.
[![Coverage Status](https://coveralls.io/builds/504418/badge)](https://coveralls.io/builds/504418)

Coverage remained the same when pulling **7bb8ef1525009370230d7a569ecc3bbf86656ea2 on th0r:boolean-attrs-support** into **c71c6a4dde32c41aa388f6edebcd62b04f1df2c6 on yyx990803:master**.

author: duckbox
title: Editing utils method toText to stringify objects
body: Took lead from this todo https://github.com/yyx990803/vue/issues/83
comments:
Hi Chris, thanks for the PR! Two things:
1. Please work on the source file (`/src/utils.js`) instead of the built files in `/dist/`. Built files are not checked in in the dev branch commits, only in release commits.
2. I feel the whole function should be simplified a little bit, but I do want you to take the credit. I will get back with some more detailed feedback later today.
Sorry, just noticing I did my work in the master of the fork, and not the dev branch. _doh_

I absolutely get what you mean by simplifying a bit. Just following the existing flow. Look forward to your feedback! Cheers.
So all I've done is fixing the syntax and comment a little bit to my personal preference:

``` js
/**
 *  Make sure only strings, booleans, numbers and
 *  objects are output to html. otherwise, ouput empty string.
 */
toText: function (value) {
    /* jshint eqeqeq: false */
    var type = typeof value
    return (type === 'string' ||
        type === 'boolean' ||
        (type === 'number' && value == value)) // deal with NaN
            ? value
            : type === 'object' && value !== null
                ? JSON.stringify(value)
                : ''
},
```

The tests are looking good. If you could make a new PR off from the dev branch, and only check in the changes in `src` files, it should be good to merge.
I'll do that now mate.
